paragraph: Versatile, facile, easy, and economical, these are the advantages that immersion precipitation or non-solvent phase separation (NIPS) offers [1-3]. Due to these, NIPS process has been regarded as the most widely-used approach in fabricating flat sheet membranes from a variety of polymers [4]. In addition, NIPS can provide a wide-range of pore size: from microfiltration to nanofiltration [5]. In this process, a polymer of choice is dissolved in a suitable solvent. Once homogeneous, the polymeric solution is cast onto a support and phase-inversion is prompted through direct immersion in a coagulation bath/non-solvent bath (typically water), generating a polymer rich phase that transforms into the membrane matrix after polymer precipitation, and a polymer lean phase which develops into pores after demixing [6].
label: n

paragraph: Polysulfone (PSf) membrane is amongst the most extensively used commercial membranes due to its favorable attributes such as high glass transition temperature (Tg = 190 degC), high mechanical strength, good chemical resistance over a wide-range of pH, good thermal resistance, exceptional biocompatibility, and ease of fabrication [7-9]. PSf membranes are commonly used in wastewater treatment [10-14], hemodialysis [15-17], protein purification [18-22], food processing [23], and so on. Polar solvents like N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) [1,24-27], N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) [9,28-31], and N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) [32-35] are usually used to dissolved PSf polymers. Utilizing these solvents to prepare PSf membranes via NIPS process generally leads to formation of ultrafiltration (UF) membranes with relatively dense surface structure and porous sub-structure. Meanwhile, the cross-section of these membranes is composed of large macrovoids with walls having cellular-like structure [36] which could generate low flux due to the closed-pore structure (the pores are not interconnected with each other) that could potentially slow down the flow of water across the membrane. Additionally, concerns have been expressed on the use of such solvents to prepare polymeric membranes due to their toxicity which can cause adverse effects to our health. Besides, during NIPS process, these solvents are released into the coagulation bath during the membrane formation, and residual solvents are further extracted in the washing bath. These constitute to the release of 20-50 billion liters of contaminated water annually [1,37], and if not properly treated, can create immense damages to the environment. Hence, the use of these solvents in industries are now strictly regulated. In May 2020, the European Union has imposed a mandate on the use of NMP which has led researchers to find "greener" and more sustainable solvents [24,37] that have high affinity towards the PSf polymer. Alongside the prospect of tuning the morphology and suppressing macrovoids using alternative solvents.
label: n

paragraph: As a result of the raising interest to improve the sustainability of PSf membrane production, several different solvents have been investigated in the past with respect to their suitability for replacing harmful solvents. In recent studies conducted by Kahrs and Schwellenbach [38], Wang et al. [39,40], Mousavi and Zadhoush [41], and Mousavi et al. [42] the use of utilizing 2-pyrrolidone (2P) solvent as a substitute for NMP was explored. 2P is an organic compound derived from g-butyrolactone with considerable similarities with NMP as shown in Table 1. To date, there are no known life-threatening risks accompanied by using 2P, making it a potential alternative for NMP.
label: n

paragraph: Standard NIPS process yield skinned asymmetric membranes with large macrovoids that could either have closed pore (cellular) structure or interconnected open pore (bi-continuous structure) [39,43]. Macrovoids are defects that grow perpendicular or near perpendicular to the skin or top layer [44]. They are large in size, and have elongated or teardrop-shaped pores ranging from 10 to 50 mm [45]. The presence of these large macrovoids can weaken the structural integrity of the membranes which can lead to breakage and total failure during operation [46]. Since the first development of phase-inversion process by Leob and Sourirajan in the 1960's [47], macrovoid formation have confounded researchers which has led to the development of different studies to understand macrovoid formation [39,44,48]. Numerous models were proposed for the formation of macrovoids. Early on, Reuvers and Smolders suggested that macrovoids were formed as the result of the nucleation of the polymer poor phase [49]. Strathmann et al. explained that the macrovoid was initiated by the rupture of the polymeric skin caused by shrinkage stress-induced-syneresis [50]. Other researchers considered that macrovoid formation stemmed from the thermodynamics aspects of chemical potential gradient [43,51-53]. Additional theories include Marangoni effects [54], solutocapillary convection mechanism [55-57], osmotic pressure [58] and combination of different mechanisms [59]. Nonetheless, several methods have been investigated to reduce macrovoid formation during immersion precipitation due to their weak mechanical strength. These include (i) choosing a solvent and non-solvent pair with low affinity towards each other; (ii) increasing the viscosity of the casting solution by increasing the polymer concentration or adding additives; and (iii) adding solvent to the coagulation bath [39,43,60-62].
label: n

paragraph: Although adding solvent to the coagulation bath seem to be the easiest option however, this could lead to increased production costs and pollution. The addition of additives has been the most explored strategies to mitigate the growth of macrovoids, and adding amounts of hydrophilic polymers such polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) or polyethylene glycol (PEG) are the most predominant [63-65]. Some studies revealed that the addition of these hydrophilic polymers can enlarge the size of the macrovoids, while other studies reported the opposite as highlighted in the study by Sadrzadeh and Bhattacharjee [64]. These inconsistencies could be due to the fact that PVP and PEG are originally utilized as pore formers for polymeric membranes. They form pores as they leach out of the cast film upon immersion in the coagulation bath. However, depending on the molecular weights of the PVP and PEG [64], some can get trapped in the polymeric matrix. Therefore, the molecular weights of these materials have to be taken into great considerations before being used to suppress macrovoids. On the other hand, other researchers have used non-solvents such as water [24,38,39,66], ethanol [65] and other organic solvents [66,67] to control the exchange rates of the solvent and coagulant. Among these, water appear to be the most logical option due to its accessibility, abundancy, low-cost, and non-toxicity.
label: n

paragraph: As of this writing, there are only 4 published works on PSf/2P system. Mousavi and colleagues intensively worked on the dynamics of using 2P as a sole solvent for PSf, and a co-solvent, and how the rheology of these conditions contributed to the resulting cross-section structure of PSf membranes [41,42]. Since standard NIPS process produce ultrafiltration PSf membrane, Wang et al. in their earlier work [40], explored the use of vapor-induced phase separation (VIPS) process to obtain PSf membranes with highly porous surface and cross-section. Recently, Wang and colleagues observed the macrovoid initiation position in PSf/2P system prepared by NIPS process [39]. These previous works have provided initial understanding on the solvency of PSf in 2P, and on how the viscoelasticity of the casting solution affects the cross-section of PSf membranes. It is important to note that, except for the work on PSf/2P using VIPS process, the other studies only focused on the morphology of the cross-section of PSf membranes, specifically on the growth of macrovoids.
label: n

paragraph: This study encompasses two major objectives: (i) fabrication of highly porous PSf membranes through NIPS process using 2P as the solvent, and (ii) the suppression of macrovoid growth by using water as a non-solvent additive in the PSf/2P casting solution. Although, other studies [38,39] have previously explored the feasibility of this concept, they have not fully determined the amount of water that can be added to achieve macrovoid-free PSf membranes. Moreover, in this study, in-depth evaluations of the physical properties such morphology, porosity, pore size, permeability, and mechanical property of the PSf membranes with respect to the concentration of the additive are thoroughly carried out. Fig. 1 shows the three major parts of this study. The first part, heavily revolves on trying to understand how the nature of solvency of 2P affects the morphology of the PSf membranes, and its viability as a replacement for NMP solvent. Next, once the fundamental concepts of 2P/PSf system are established, the use of water as an additive in the casting solution to suppress macrovoids is examined. Herein, we shall probe into the viscosity of the solution, study the ternary diagram, and investigate the kinetics that took place during phase-inversion. In addition, comprehensive analysis of the physical properties of the membranes such as porosity, pore size, morphology, permeability, and mechanical properties will be examined. Lastly, the potential application of this concept will also be extended to other systems such as PSf/NMP, PSf/DMAc, and PSf/DMF to test the practicality of using water to suppress macrovoids.
label: n

paragraph: The polymer polysulfone (PSf, Udel(r) P-3500, Mw = 50,800 Da, Mn = 33,500 Da, r = 1.24 g/cm3) was acquired from the Amoco Performance Products Inc. (Ridgefield, CT, USA). The solvents N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, r = 1.03 g/cm3), dimethylacetamide (DMAc, r = 0.940 g/cm3) and dimethylformamide (DMF, 0.944 g/cm3) of reagent grades were purchased from Uni-Onward Corp., Taiwan, while reagent grade 2-pyrrolidinone (2P, r = 1.12 g/cm3) was procured from Acros Organics. All the chemicals were used without further purification. DI water was produced in our lab using an Elga Purelab(r) water purification system.
label: y

paragraph: A typical casting solution was prepared by dissolving PSf polymer in 2P solvent. To prepare the pristine casting solutions, 8, 10, 12 and 15 wt% of PSf polymer were added into the 2P solvent. Meanwhile, to prepare the modified casting solutions, respective amount (wt%) of non-solvent additive (water) was added into the bottle containing 2P, and mixed well for a couple of minutes. Followed by the addition of PSf polymer. The amount of water added was determined based on the cloud point experiment (section 2.2.3). All the casting solutions were dissolved at 60 degC in an oil bath for 1-2 days. Both the casting solutions and membranes are named as Px-Dy in which x and y denote the concentrations of PSf and additive in wt%, respectively. For instance, P8-D1.5 indicates 8 wt% of PSf and 1.5 wt% of DI water. As a point of comparison with different systems, casting solutions of PSf/NMP, PSf/NMP/water, PSf/DMAc, PSf/DMAc/water, PSf/DMF, and PSf/DMF/water were also prepared.
label: y

paragraph: All rheological experiments of the casting solutions were evaluated on a TA instrument (Discovery HR20) using parallel plate geometry with a diameter of 20 mm (Peltier plate). All measurements were carried out at 25 degC with test duration ranging from 3 to 4 min per sample. The zero-shear viscosity of PSf/2P, PSf/2P/water, PSf/NMP and PSf/NMP/water solutions were measured at the shear rate of 10/s. Meanwhile, the storage modulus (G') and loss modulus (G'') of the casting solutions were measured at a constant strain rate of 2%, and monitored at angular frequency ranging from 0.5 rad/s to 628 rad/s.
label: n

paragraph: Once the casting solutions homogeneous, they were subsequently stored at room temperature for at least 1 day to remove some air bubbles. Then, the polymer solution was cast on a glass plate with a thickness of 300 mm. After casting, the film was immediately immersed in a water bath to permit the exchange of solvent and water, and to form the membrane. The water bath was changed at least twice. After 24 h, the membrane was dried in air at room temperature, and stored in a cool dry place for subsequent membrane characterizations.
label: n

paragraph: *Simulation of phase diagrams
label: n

paragraph: Simulation of phase diagrams
label: n

paragraph: The phase diagrams of PSf/2P/water, PSf/NMP/water, PSf/DMAc/water systems were constructed using Compaq Visual Fortran 6.6 based on the Flory-Huggins theory. Using this software, the binodal and spinodal lines of these systems can be established which are essential in understanding their thermodynamics stability. Details of this simulation can be found from the previous work of Lai et al. [68].*Cloud point determination
label: n

paragraph: Cloud point determination
label: n

paragraph: Cloud point measurements of PSf/2P/water, PSf/NMP/water, PSf/DMAc/water were determined at 60 degC wherein water was added dropwise into the homogeneous casting solutions. Local phase separation ensues upon the addition of water, but continuous stirring disrupts it, allowing uniform distribution of the non-solvent in the solution. As more water is added into the system, the cloudy state persists. Using the known concentrations of the ternary system, the composition paths can be determined on the phase diagram.*Kinetics of mass transfer during membrane formation
label: n

paragraph: Kinetics of mass transfer during membrane formation
label: n

paragraph: The entailing kinetics of the phase-inversion process were observed and quantified using an optical microscope (Olympus BHT-M-113D). A drop of the casting solution was placed in between two glass slides with a 15 mm Teflon spacer. Next, a drop of water was introduced through the gap to induce phase separation. The microscope is connected to a computer that permits the recording of the phase-inversion process. The captured images were analyzed using an imaging software (Optimas 5.1, Bioscan) to measure the diffusion coefficients.
label: n

paragraph: *Surface and cross-section morphology determination
label: n

paragraph: Surface and cross-section morphology determination
label: n

paragraph: The surface and cross-section morphologies of the membranes were characterized using a Field emission-scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Hitachi S-4000 instrument). For the membranes' cross-section, the membranes were cut while being immersed in liquid nitrogen. The membranes were laid on an electrically conductive adhesive carbon tape placed on a stainless-steel SEM holder, and vacuumed dried overnight to remove excess moisture. Prior to loading the samples in the SEM chamber, electrical conductivity of the samples was increased by sputtering platinum on the surface for 100 s. The FE-SEM analysis were conducted under an accelerating voltage of 15 keV.*Porosity and pore size evaluation
label: n

paragraph: Porosity and pore size evaluation
label: n

paragraph: The porosity of the membranes was evaluated on membrane samples with a diameter of 1.2 cm. The weight of the dry membranes was first recorded before immersing them in n-butanol, which was used as the wetting liquid. After 24 h of immersion, the membranes were dabbed with a soft tissue to remove the superficial alcohol, and then weighed. Equation (1) [69,70] was then used to determine the porosity of the samples, where W2 and W1 denote the weight of the immersed membrane and of the dry membrane, respectively. r1 is the density of PSf (1.24 g/cm3), and r2 is the density of n-butanol (0.81 g/cm3). 5 independent samples were tested.(1)porosity=(W2-W1)r1r1W2+(r2-r1)W1*100%
label: n

paragraph: The pore size of the pristine and modified polysulfone membranes were measured using a capillary flow porometer (CFP-1500-AXLE, PMI Porous Materials, Inc). Prior to testing, 1.2 cm membranes were impregnated with isopropanol (IPA, g = 20.7 Dyne) to fill up the pores overnight. Next, the sample was loaded into the porometer metallic casing casting which was then tightly sealed. The IPA was displaced by the inert N2 gas at increasing pressures, and the pore size of the membrane was measured using the bubble point method.
label: n

paragraph: The mechanical strength of the membranes was evaluated using Instron 544 instrument. Sample having a dimension of 8 cm x 1 cm was loaded between the instrument's clamps which were automatically and gradually pulled apart, starting from an initial distance of 6 cm. The elongation velocity at which the clamps were separated was maintained at 10 mm/min. Stress-strain behavior was automatically measured and the procedure comes to a halt once the sample breaks.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane water permeability was determined in a dead-end mode using a stirred cell from Amicon(r). A membrane of 13.4 cm2 surface area was placed in the filtration module and was secured with an O-ring. The cell was then filled with 50 mL of DI water and was connected to an nitrogen tank pressure reservoir. An overpressure of 1.5 bar was applied to the system for membrane pore compaction step. Then, the pressure was decreased to 1 bar, and the weight of the water permeate was monitored using an analytical balance (Mettler Toledo) connected to a computer.
label: n

paragraph: The nature of the solvent plays a pertinent role in the morphology of the membranes [71]. For many years, Hansen's solubility parameters have been used as a guide in understanding the solubility of the polymer in a particular solvent. In this study, we have used equation (2a) to determine the solubility of PSf polymer in different solvents:(2a)dS-P= [(dD,S- dD,P)2 + (dP,S- dP,P)2 + (dH,S- dH,P)2]0.5Where dD, dP, and dH pertain to the van der Waals or dispersion, polar, and hydrogen bonding forces, respectively. The suffix S and P refer to solvent and polymer. Parameters for different PSf/solvent systems are provided in Table 2. From this, it can be inferred that out of the 3 solvents, PSf has the highest affinity towards DMF, followed by NMP, DMAc and 2P.
label: n

paragraph: Among the different mathematical models used to describe the thermodynamics of ternary systems, Flory-Huggins theory is the most sought after due to its relatively simple mathematical model and good accuracy of the phase behavior [72,73]. It is important to note that by constructing the ternary thermodynamics phase diagram of the phase-inversion process, we can get an insight into the composition paths of the demixed system. The Flory-Huggins interaction parameters (Table 3) of the systems can be estimated using the solubility parameters from Table 2, and their relationship can be transcribed to equation (3a) [73]:(3a)khi3=V1RT(d1-d2)2i=1,2where khi3 is the Flory-Huggins interaction parameter, V1 is the pure molar volume for component 1, and d1 is the solubility parameter for component i. Later, Hansen introduced a correction factor, a:(4)khi3=aV1RT[(d1,d-d2,d)2+0.25(d1,p-d2,p)2+0.25(d1,h-d2,h)2i=1,2
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 2 illustrates the ternary diagrams of (a) PSf/NMP//water and (b) PSf/2P/water. The binary interaction parameters (kh) such as PSf-2P, PSf-water, and 2P-water used in this study were similar to that of Wang's group [40]. In their work, they used the same values of khNMP-water for kh2P-water. According to their calculations (with the data of excess Gibbs free energy reported from Ref. [75]), the values of khNMP-water and kh2P-water at 40 degC are close hence, they assumed that they are also close at 25 degC. They further verified this by measuring the water compositions in the 2P/water and NMP/water when they are in equilibrium with water vapor in the humid air (25 degC, 70% relative humidity) which showed similar values of both binary interactions. Although the similarity between NMP and 2P (Table 1) is quite intriguing in spite of the increased hydrogen bonding of 2P, it was indicated by Aparicio et al. [76], that 2P supposedly favors forming cyclic dimer due to the inter-molecule hydrogen bonding. Instead of forming hydrogen bond with water, it forms a cyclic dimer that weakens its affinity towards water.
label: n

paragraph: In addition, the solvent-polymer interaction (khPSf-2P and khPSf-NMP) also provides a quantitative information on the degree of interaction of polymer and solvent. According to literature [72], if khpolymer-solvent is less than 0.5, the solvent has high affinity towards the polymer, and is considered a good solvent. Conversely, if it is higher than 0.5, it is regarded as a poor solvent. As shown in Tables 2 and 2P is a poorer solvent than NMP therefore, the homogeneous region of PSf/2P/water phase diagram is narrower than PSf/NMP/water. This indicates that it would take less amount of non-solvent (water) to induce demixing in PSf/2P system. The cloud points in Fig. 2 denoted the amount of water needed to demix the system. For PSf/2P system, it takes about 2 wt% of water to phase separate the solution, and as the amount of PSf in the solution is increased, it takes a lesser amount of non-solvent to induce phase-inversion. With this knowledge, we can identify how much non-solvent additive we can add into the casting solution without causing phase-inversion. Another key parameter that must be considered is the relative energy difference (RED) which provides information on whether the parameters of the two molecules (usually a polymer and solvent) are within range. This can be measured according to the following equations [2,77,78]:(5)Ro=(dD2+dP2)0.5-dH(6)Ra2=4(dD,P-dD,S)2+(dP,P-dP,S)2+(dH,P-dH,S)2(7)RED=RaRo
label: n

paragraph: Ro denotes the interaction radius of the polymer, and Ra refers to the solubility parameter distance. The ratio of Ra and Ro tells us that if it is < 1, the polymer is soluble in the chosen solvent, while the opposite transpires if it is > 1, and if the ratio is 1, the polymer can only be partially dissolved in the solvent. The calculated RED of the systems are 0.72, and 0.69 for PSf/2P and PSf/NMP, respectively. Hence, we can confirm that PSf polymer is soluble in 2P, and be can be used as a "greener" solvent replacement for NMP.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 3 shows the comparison of two PSf membranes (having the same concentration) fabricated via NIPS using 2 different solvents. Left-hand figure displays the surface and cross-section morphology of the PSf membrane when NMP was used as a solvent, while the right-hand figure represents the PSf/2P system. Starting with the PSf/NMP system, a dense surface structure was obtained which is consistent with other published works [1,24-27] while, a skinned asymmetric membrane with large finger-like macrovoids extending from the top part to the bottom part of the membranes with walls having cellular-like structure was obtained. In contrast, when 2P was used as a solvent, the surface structure of the PSf membranes have obvious large pores in the microfiltration (MF) range (to be confirmed in sections 3.2 and 3.3). Meanwhile, it appears that the macrovoids were found at the deeper part of the membrane. Zoomed-in images of the membrane reveal that instead of cellular-like structure, 2P solvent generated interconnected pores or bi-continuous structure which is in agreement with the previous studies by Wang et al. [39,40] when 2P is used as a solvent.
label: n

paragraph: Although there are numerous studies tackling phase-inversion of casting solution to form membranes, the concept governing demixing is still tricky to understand. Many studies have suggested that if a solvent has a high affinity or high miscibility with the non-solvent, instantaneous demixing would occur. In other words, the fast exchange between the solvent and non-solvent induces the rapid precipitation of the polymer and formation of the film, within seconds of immersion in the coagulation or non-solvent bath. With this type of demixing, a highly porous cross-section (finger-like macrovoids) is obtained. On the other hand, if the solvent has a low affinity towards the non-solvent, a slow exchange occurs, which decelerates the formation of the film. Membranes with relatively dense top layer and sponge-like substructure are achieved during delayed demixing [4]. However, other studies suggest that instantaneous demixing can help mitigate the formation of macrovoids [79]. With these ambiguities in membrane formation, Hong et al. [39] studied the demixing that transpires during phase separation process.
label: n

paragraph: A homogeneous casting solution can be demixed through nucleation and growth (NG) or spinodal decomposition (SD) depending on the solution composition at which the phase separation occurs [80]. For the demixing to occur via NG, the phase separation composition must lie on the meta-stable or binodal region. Conversely, for SD to happen, the composition path must be found in the unstable or spinodal region. When phase-inversion happens via NG, the resulting morphology consists of nuclei of polymer-poor phase that can grow into macrovoids. Meanwhile, when phase-inversion occurs via SD, the subsequent morphology contains continuous polymer-poor phase but not nuclei type. If the demixing is accompanied by fast solvent and non-solvent exchange, the phase-inversion would typically be via SD, as evidenced by the formation of bi-continuous structure [39].
label: n

paragraph: It was previously stated that NMP has a high affinity towards water hence, one would assume that the exchange of solvent and non-solvent is fast enough to cause SD demixing. However, this claim contradicts our observations in Fig. 3, as cellular-like structures are observed instead of bi-continuous morphology. Meanwhile, 2P has a low miscibility towards water (possible cyclic dimer), so it is expected that phase-inversion would transpire via NG, and poorly interconnected pores on the walls of the macrovoids are to be anticipated. However, the opposite was found on both membranes. To find out why such phenomena were observed, we evaluated the viscosity of both systems as illustrated at the bottom images of Fig. 3. Due to the poorer solvency of PSf in 2P, higher viscosity is attained. For the same concentration (15 wt%), PSf/2P system has 41% higher viscosity than PSf/NMP system. This suggest that the high viscosity of PSf/2P system slowed down the solvent and non-solvent exchange which helped maintain the open porous structure and interconnected pores by mitigating the coarsening process. Conversely, NMP is a good solvent for PSf. Its high affinity for water permitted fast solvent and non-solvent exchanges, while the low viscosity (553 cP) of the system could not prevent coarsening during the phase-inversion process. So, phase-inversion may occur by SD, but the structure is not fixed and can still evolve after phase-separation. As a result, large macrovoids were observed across the membrane with cellular-like structure.
label: n

paragraph: As stated previously, earlier works did not explore the effect of 2P on the surface morphology of PSf membranes via NIPS process. In this study, we found out that by using 2P as solvent, we could easily obtain PSf membranes in the MF range. Normally, NIPS process generates ultrafiltration membranes as a result of the fast solvent and non-solvent exchange that transpires in the coagulation bath which typically results in the formation of a relatively dense top surface also known as skin layer [49,81-84]. Based on the study conducted by Strathmann, asymmetric morphology arises from the steep concentration, and activity gradient of the polymer, solvent and non-solvent. If the affinity of the solvent and non-solvent towards each other is high, as soon as the water is introduced on the surface of the film, the resulting chemical composition at the interface reaches in a short time a value indicating a phase separation has occurred, due to the fast mass transfer kinetics between the solvent and non-solvent. Where in fact, the internal of the film is still very far below the binodal point [85,86]. In order to slow down the exchange at the interface, additives can be introduced into the casting solution to increase its viscosity. That is why researchers commonly incorporate additives such as PEG or PVP to obtain PSf MF. To obtain PSf MF membranes, additives such PEG or PVP are added into the casting solution to increase its viscosity. However, even without additives, PSf/2P system is viscous enough (compared to PSf/NMP) to allow slower mass transfer kinetics during phase-inversion which permitted the formation of porous surface structure as shown in Fig. 4. But it is important to note that the amount of solid content would also influence the viscosity of the solution which could decrease the porosity of the membrane. Hence, it is evident in Fig. 4 that the surface porosity decreases with the polysulfone content (which will be verified later by dedicated measurements).
label: n

paragraph: The preceding results show that by using 2P as a solvent for PSf polymers, membrane with bi-continuous morphology in the entire cross-section can obtained. Having bi-continuous structure would be beneficial for faster permeation unlike cellular-like structure which are closed pores (not interconnected).
label: n

paragraph: In the introduction, we have stated the different ways to suppress macrovoid growth in polymeric membranes. Among these different approaches, adding additives into the casting solution seem to be the easiest and most economical. PVP, PEG, non-solvent, etc., are some of the most used additives to mitigate macrovoid growth. In this study, we chose water as the additive because of its abundancy and availability, cost-effectiveness, and it will not be trapped in the polymer domain (unlike polymeric additives) during the phase-inversion process. Fig. 5 shows the entire cross-section of the different membranes prepared: P8, P10, P12, and P15 which consist of 8, 10, 12 and 15 wt% of PSf in 2P, respectively. The amount of water added into the casting solution was dependent on the cloud point evaluation from Fig. 2, that is to avoid phase-separation of the casting solution. For P8, the amount of DI water was varied from 0 to 1.5 wt%. Meanwhile, for P10 and P12, 0-1.0 wt% of water was added. Lastly, for P12, the concentration of DI water was from 0 to 0.8 wt%. As can be seen below, it is evident that as the concentration of PSf in the casting solution is increased (from P8 to P15), the initiation position of the macrovoid could be found deeper in the cross-section of the membranes. This can be explained by the increase in viscosity of the casting solution, which slowed down the mass transfer kinetics (this will be proven in the next section). After water was added into the casting solution of P8, it was found that the initial position of macrovoid formation appeared deeper in the cross-section of the membrane. Consequently, when more water was added (P8-D1.5), all the macrovoids were suppressed. Similar trends were observed in P8, P12 and P15, as more non-solvent is introduced in the casting solution, complete macrovoid suppression was achieved. In addition, the bi-continuous structure was well maintained in all conditions as evidenced in the SEM images in Fig. 6 which displays the higher magnification of the middle part of the cross-section. Moreover, no skin layer is observable in all PSf membranes as illustrated in Fig. S1. In contrast, it seems that the amount of additive did not directly affect the surface morphology of the membranes (Fig. S2), which all remained highly porous.
label: n

paragraph: It is a known fact that as the amount of solid content in the casting solution is increased, the porosity and pore size of the membranes would decrease. Therefore, a decline in the porosity and pore size of the membranes (P8 > P10 > P12 > P15) is expected, and is proven in Fig. 7. Based on this illustration, the porosity of the pristine membranes gradually decreased from 88% to 76% when the PSf concentration was increased from 8 wt% to 15 wt%. Likewise, the pore size was reduced from 0.65 mm to 0.30 mm. It was also apparent that the incorporation of non-solvent also resulted in a decrease in porosity and pore size of the membranes (in the same PSf concentration). The decrease in porosity of the membranes could be attributed to the disappearance of the large voids across the membranes. However, it is important to note that as the solid content is the same with and without water, we should acknowledge that porosity difference could only be due to the membrane thickness differences (Fig. S3). For a same solid content and a same thickness, the porosity should be the same, regardless of the presence of macrovoids.
label: n

paragraph: The viscosity of the casting solutions holds a vital role in determining the morphology of the membranes [40]. With this, we measured the viscosity of PSf/2P casting solutions and of PSf/2P/water solutions. Since the viscosity of the polymer solution is shear-rate dependent, we report in the following zero-shear viscosity. The solution viscosity logically increased with increasing polymer concentration (Fig. 8). Moreover, the viscosity tended to be low and constant below a certain concentration threshold and then drastically increased. According to polymer solution theory, there is a critical overlap concentration (C*) of polymer coils, which is the crossover concentration between the dilute and the semi-dilute concentration region. If the concentration of the polymer is below C*, the polymer clusters are segregated from each other, and it is commonly referred to as dilute regime. On the other hand, if the concentration is above C*, the solution becomes entangled as a result of the overlap between adjacent macromolecular coils. The concentration of the polymer at which the onset of significant entanglement occurs is pertained to as critical entanglement concentration (Ce), and it is within the semi-dilute entangled regime [87,88]. PSf is predominantly hydrophobic due to the large presence of aryl groups. When water is added into the system, the PSf chains will be oriented in a way that the hydrophilic segments, sulfonyl and ether groups, are exposed which was induced by hydrophobic hydration [89]. This phenomenon triggers the aryl groups to be "coiled up or hidden" to decrease the enthalpy of the system creating spots of cohesion entanglement among the PSf chains (as shown in the insets of Fig. 8). Moreover, as stated in the previous studies of Kahrs and Schellenbach [38], Wang et al. [39,40], Mousavi and Zadhoush [41], and Mousavi et al. [42], the addition of water into the casting solution could lead to interchain hydrogen bonding which can result in increased which can result in decreased solvent power and aggregation of the macromolecules which then induces the viscosity of the system to be enhanced. Therefore, as more water is added into the casting solution, more points of entanglement among the polymer chains are created causing the viscosity to be enhanced.
label: n

paragraph: By taking the straight lines used to fit the curves of the log-log plot of the zero-shear viscosity and PSf concentration (Fig. 9), we were able to determine the critical overlap concentration and the critical entanglement concentration of the casting solutions without additive, and with 0.5 wt% and 1.0 wt% water. In Fig. 9a, in which no additive was additive into the casting solutions, we determined that the C* is 9.7 wt%, and no onset of entanglement occurred from 2 wt% to 18 wt% (it is probable that Ce would occur at higher concentrations). However, when 0.5 wt% and 1.0 wt% of water were added into the casting solution, 2 things could be observed: (1) critical chain entanglement ensued; and (2) both values of C* and Ce decreased with increasing amount of additive added. Correlating these values with the SEM from Fig. 5, we can infer that the addition of water has caused the onset of chain entanglement which evidently increased the viscosity which aided in the mitigation of macrovoid growth. Also, when the polymer concentration in the casting solution is higher than the critical chain entanglement, the initiation position of macrovoids shifted to somewhere below the membrane surface. Conversely, when there is no chain entanglement (PSf-D0), macrovoids are present along the cross-section of the membrane. In addition, when more non-solvent additive is added into the casting solution, the entanglement concentration was found to decrease (increased chain entanglement), suggesting that for a much lower polymer concentration, we can fine-tune the substructure of the membrane. This can provide positive impacts in terms of fabricating membranes at a more cost-effective approach.
label: n

paragraph: Aside from this, we have also analyzed the viscoelastic properties of the casting solution and how it is being influenced by the addition of water. Fig. S4 presents the graph of the storage modulus (G') and loss modulus (G'') as a function of angular frequency. The storage modulus is a measure of the elasticity of the solution and pertains to its ability to store energy. On the other hand, the loss modulus is a measure of the viscosity of the solution and pertains to its ability to dissipate. If G'' > G' the system behaves like a liquid while if the G'' < G' behaves like a gel [87]. Based on Fig. S4, all the systems exhibit a viscous behavior. When water is added, both G' and G'' visibly increased which can be attributed to the enhanced viscosity induced by the hydrogen bonding and subsequent chain entanglement [41].
label: n

paragraph: Aside from probing into the thermodynamics and viscosity of the PSf/2P/water system, it is also essential to investigate the kinetics of the phase-inversion process. We observed the movement of the phase separation front of the casting solutions with varying concentrations of polysulfone under an optical microscope as depicted in Fig. 10. As it was pointed out in the previous sections of this work, higher viscosity could slow down the kinetics of the mass transfer hence, when the concentration of PSf was increased from 8 wt% to 15 wt%, it was clear that it took the non-solvent a longer time to traverse the P15 system.
label: n

paragraph: In fact, when comparing the position of the diffusion front as a function of time for different concentration of PSf in 2P without additives as illustrated in Fig. 11a, after 120 s of phase inversion, the non-solvent travelled a distance of 0.45 mm, 0.32 mm, 0.30 mm, 0.25 mm for P8, P10, P12 and P15, respectively. Meanwhile, Fig. 11b presents the related diffusion distance vs. square root of time plot.
label: n

paragraph: Assuming that the dark ridges found after the interface corresponds to the initial diffusion position of water, then the diffusivity of water in the system (Dw/s) can be determined based on the equation proposed by Strathmann et al. [61].(2b)d2=4(Dw/set)(1-CW1+CW)twhere d denotes the diffusion distance, e/t represents a geometrical factor for the porosity and tortuosity of the membrane being formed, CW is the water concentration at the interface between the non-solvent and the polymeric system, t pertains to time.
label: n

paragraph: Under the supposition that the concentration of water in the solution at the point of precipitation is small relative to unity so, equation (2b) can be simplified to the following expression (equation (3b)) to determine the effective diffusivity De. This De contains the geometrical correction factor e/t.(3b)d=2(Det)0.5
label: n

paragraph: With the above expression, the calculated effective diffusivity of water in P8, P10, P12 and P15 are 3.23 x 10-4, 2.60 x 10-4, 2.51 x 10-4 and 2.08 x 10-4 mm2/s, respectively. Thus, verifying our previous claim that with higher viscosity, kinetics of mass transfer was evidently slowed down.
label: n

paragraph: Next, the kinetics of non-solvent (water) in the PSf/2P/water casting solutions were examined and presented in Fig. 12. In P8 system, no significant trend was seen which could be attributed to the considerably lower viscosity of the system. Moreover, due to the low polymer concentration (8 wt%), the position of the system lies close to the binodal line, which makes it easier to become thermodynamically unstable. On the other hand, in P10 - P15 systems, it was evident that there is an increasing trend in the non-solvent kinetics when the amount of additive was increased. This was then further verified by calculating the diffusion rates of the non-solvent as presented in Fig. 13.
label: n

paragraph: In 2010, Hong et al. proposed a model for the initiation of macrovoids based on the relationship of the initial position of the macrovoid (L) and effective diffusivity (De, which is similar to diffusion coefficient) versus the normalized polymer concentration(C/Ce) [39]. According to their study, the PSf/2P, PSf/2P/water (0.5 wt%), and PSf/NMP systems can be fitted into an exponential growth curve. Similar relationship is also observed in our PSf/2P/water system as presented in Fig. S5.
label: n

paragraph: Although macrovoids permits fast permeability due to their high porosity, they are considered weak points in the membrane because they are prone to compaction under high pressure operation, which eventually leads to poor flux performance over time. From the previous sections, we have provided data that shows the by adding water into the casting solution, we are able to successfully mitigate the growth of these unwanted macrovoids. Moreover, we have offered in-depth analysis as to how the thermodynamics of the ternary system, kinetics and viscosity affect the morphology of the membranes. To further our study, we have investigated the effects of incorporating additives into the casting solution to help suppress macrovoids to the permeability properties and mechanical strengths of the membranes as shown in Figs. 14 and 15, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: Since Figs. 4 and 5 prove that all of the fabricated membranes are suitable for microfiltration, we decided to investigate the pure water flux of the pristine and modified PSf membranes under a transmembrane pressure of 1 bar. Fig. 14 shows that even though the macrovoids disappeared, similar permeabilities are still maintained which could be due to two possible reasons: First, the additive concentration did not directly influence the surface porosity of the membranes having the same polymeric content. Second, although the huge macrovoids were suppressed, the interconnected pores along the cross-section still permitted fast permeation.
label: n

paragraph: Meanwhile, Fig. 15 displays the measured modulus of elasticity of the membranes obtained from tensile stress/strain plots. At the outset, it is important to note that the mechanical strength of the membrane is in correlation to the concentration of the polymer. Therefore, it is obvious that as the concentration of PSf is increased, the modulus of elasticity also increased from 40 to 130 MPa. Besides, as we increased the PSf concentration in 2P, we were also able to prevent the initiation of macrovoid growth near the top part of the membrane and then the formation of the macrovoids across the entire cross-section of the membranes. This has led to the increase in the modulus of elasticity of the modified membranes. Additionally, we compared the mechanical strength of PSf membrane prepared with 2P to that of prepared using NMP (Fig. S6). As expected, the large macrovoids found in PSf/NMP membranes acted as weak spots which contributed to it having lower tensile strength.
label: n

paragraph: To summarize, using 2P as a solvent allowed the easy fabrication of PSf MF (skin-free) membranes through NIPS process, which is deemed difficult to achieve using other solvents such as NMP, DMF, and DMAc without the addition of additives. However, macrovoids are still present along its cross-section. The addition of a sufficient amount of water (which content is dependent upon the phase diagram) permits to totally suppress the macrovoids without sacrificing the pore size and porosity of the membranes. So, skin-free and macrovoids-free PSf membranes can be prepared using 2P as the solvent and water as a non-solvent additive. As the pore connectivity is maintained, so is the membrane permeability. But as the morphology of the cross-section is no longer asymmetric with large macrovoids, instead replaced with symmetric with continuous connected domains, the mechanical strength of the membranes was enhanced without waiving the permeability. These findings could help provide an easy and economical approach to suppress macrovoids without using expensive organic or inorganic additives, or using intricate methods to fabricate macrovoid-free membranes. Fig. 16 illustrates the short summary of these results.
label: n

paragraph: To evaluate the viability of using non-solvent as an additive to suppress macrovoids, we have utilized other solvents such NMP DMAc and DMF to prepare polysulfone membranes. We initially established their respective ternary diagrams (Fig. 2 for PSf/NMP/water and Fig. 17 for PSf/DMAc/water and PSf/DMF/water) to first identify up to how much water could be added into the casting solution before phase separation occurs. Based on the solubility parameters from Table 1, DMF and DMAc solvents are also considered good solvents to PSf polymer. This is also evidenced by the large homogeneous area of PSf/DMAc/water and PSf/DMF/water ternary systems illustrated in Fig. 17. Moreover, the cloud points also revealed that it would take more coagulant (water) to induce demixing of the system.
label: n

paragraph: In order to find out the versatility of the water as a means to prevent macrovoid formation, we have prepared 25% of PSf in NMP, 20% of PSf in DMAc, and 15% of PSf in DMF via the NIPS process. We have varied the concentrations of the additive from 0 to 3 wt% for PSf/NMP, 0-2 wt% for PSf/DMAc and 0-1 wt% for PSf/DMF casting solutions. The SEM cross-section images in Fig. 18 reveal that when water was added into the casting solution of PSf/NMP, the macrovoids were effectively suppressed. Similar phenomena were observed in PSf membranes prepared using DMAc (Fig. 19a) and DMF (Fig. 19b) solvents. These results prove that using water as an additive in the casting solution provides a practical and cost-effective approach to tune the morphology of polysulfone membranes from controlling the growth of macrovoids to its overall suppression.
label: n

paragraph: In this study we first investigated the use of 2P solvent to prepare polysulfone membranes in replace of the more commonly used NMP solvent. Being a poorer solvent than NMP, the nature of solvency of 2P greatly influenced the kinetics, viscosity, and thermodynamics stability of the system. The following major conclusions can be made:*The fabricated membranes are skin-free and fall in the microfiltration range.*The lower affinity of 2P towards polysulfone (compared to NMP) greatly increased the viscosity of the casting solution which prevented coarsening. As a result, bi-continuous substructures were formed. However, macrovoids were still observed.*The higher concentrations of the polymer prompted the growth of the macrovoids along the deeper parts of the membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The fabricated membranes are skin-free and fall in the microfiltration range.
label: n

paragraph: The lower affinity of 2P towards polysulfone (compared to NMP) greatly increased the viscosity of the casting solution which prevented coarsening. As a result, bi-continuous substructures were formed. However, macrovoids were still observed.
label: n

paragraph: The higher concentrations of the polymer prompted the growth of the macrovoids along the deeper parts of the membranes.
label: n

paragraph: After understanding the effects of 2P on the morphology of the membranes, the second part of this study focused on tuning the cross-section morphology to obtain macrovoid-free membranes through the incorporation of water in the casting solution of PSf/2P. The following inferences can be made:*The addition of water caused the viscosity of the system to further increase which consequently influenced the rate of solvent and non-solvent exchange, and then affected the demixing of the solution.*Adding water in the casting solution induced the polymer chains to be entangled causing the macrovoid to be shifted deeper along the cross-section of the membranes.*The modified membranes maintained high porosity (>75%) and large pore size which are still suitable for microfiltration applications.*Even though the macrovoids were successfully mitigated, high water permeability was still achieved, as interconnected pores were retained.*Through the suppression of macrovoids, the mechanical properties of the membranes were drastically improved.*Water as an additive provided a very simple yet effective approach to suppress the macrovoids not just for PSf/2P system but also for PSf/NMP, PSf/DMAc, and PSf/DMF systems.
label: n

paragraph: The addition of water caused the viscosity of the system to further increase which consequently influenced the rate of solvent and non-solvent exchange, and then affected the demixing of the solution.
label: n

paragraph: Adding water in the casting solution induced the polymer chains to be entangled causing the macrovoid to be shifted deeper along the cross-section of the membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The modified membranes maintained high porosity (>75%) and large pore size which are still suitable for microfiltration applications.
label: n

paragraph: Even though the macrovoids were successfully mitigated, high water permeability was still achieved, as interconnected pores were retained.
label: n

paragraph: Through the suppression of macrovoids, the mechanical properties of the membranes were drastically improved.
label: n

paragraph: Water as an additive provided a very simple yet effective approach to suppress the macrovoids not just for PSf/2P system but also for PSf/NMP, PSf/DMAc, and PSf/DMF systems.
label: n

paragraph: All things considered, this work demonstrated the practicality of utilizing 2P as a solvent and water as an additive to obtain skin-free and macrovoid-free symmetric polysulfone membranes. These results could be of major interest for the large-scale fabrication of microfiltration polysulfone membranes with both high strength and permeability.
label: n

paragraph: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.memsci.2022.120597.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane materials stand at the core of membrane separation technology. As the basis of membrane materials, porous membranes are not only widely used in such fields as ultrafiltration, membrane distillation and membrane crystallization, but also can be used as the base membrane of reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, gas separation and other composite membranes. At present, the main research direction of porous membranes is to enhance the mechanical strength, permeability and fouling resistance [1-3].
label: n

paragraph: Nonsolvent induced phase separation (NIPS) is the most established approach for fabricating porous polymer membranes [4,5]. The integration of pore formers (i.e., additives) into dope solutions is one of the most common and effective methods to regulate the permeability of porous membranes [4-7]. However, the excessive addition of pore formers can negatively impact the pore size and mechanical strength of the resulting porous membranes [8,9].
label: n

paragraph: For the method of regulating the permeability by adding additives, the trade-off existing between thermodynamic and kinetic of dope solutions is a very common phenomenon [10]. In NIPS, facilitating the mutual diffusion of water (coagulant) and dope solutions (MDWDS) during the membrane formation process has been acknowledged as an effective method to prepare porous membranes with higher water flux.
label: n

paragraph: Surfactants are considered to be unique additives due to amphiphilic structure [11,12]. Though adding surfactants into dope solutions has been reported in many previous studies, their general focus has been on the effect of surfactant contents on the morphology and properties of porous membranes as shown in Table 1 with the influence of the amphiphilic structure of surfactants on MDWDS being rarely reported. Recent studies revealed that the surfactants at the interface of polymer solutions and water could facilitate MDWDS during NIPS, thus obtaining separation membranes with higher water flux [22,27-29]. For example, Guo et al. [22] added octylphenol polyoxyethylene ether (OP-10, a kind of nonionic surfactant) into dope solutions and found that OP-10 at the polymer/water interface facilitated the diffusion of water into dope solution, thus improving MDWDS. Wang et al. [27] investigated the key role of Pluronic F127 in the forming process of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) membranes and found that Pluronic F127 promoted MDWDS, thus accelerating the phase separation process.
label: n

paragraph: The permeability of porous polymer membranes in these studies was enhanced in varied degrees. Nevertheless, the pore size and tensile strength of the membranes were compromised due to the research method was still the effect of addition amounts of surfactants on the properties and morphology of polymer porous membranes. This arouses extreme zeal for us to further modify NIPS-prepared porous membranes against enlarged pore size and lowered mechanical strength, and eventually improve the efficiency in the preparation process.
label: n

paragraph: Therefore, we propose a method capable of improving water flux while maintaining the pore size and tensile strength of porous membranes via alteration of the conventional NIPS process. Aiming at MDWDS during NIPS, an amphiphilic interface via the addition of surfactants was created. The well-organized interface facilitated MDWDS across the interface (Fig. 1 (b)). Our previous study indicated that the hydrophobic interaction between hydrophobic polymer and the hydrophobic tails of surfactants had great influence on the MDWDS process. Hence, we controlled other possible variables but only changed the hydrophilic interaction force of water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants [29]. The influence of the hydrophilic interaction force on the formation process of membranes prepared by NIPS was thoroughly investigated. This type of phase separation (PS) process with the assistance of self-assembled surfactant is herein called as surfactants assisted nonsolvent induced phase separation (SA-NIPS). Compared with the conventional methods to improve water flux, the addition amounts of surfactants is always 2.0 wt.%, which may have very limited negative effects on the pore size and tensile strength of porous membranes [21]. We believe that this study not only can help to reveal the key role of surfactants during membrane formation of NIPS, but also help researchers to have a deeper understanding of NIPS process, thus preparing a porous membrane with better performance.
label: n

paragraph: Polysulfone (PSF) (Udel P-1700 LCD) was acquired from Solvay Co., LTD. and N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) from Samsung Co. LTD. PEG 4000 was bought from Tianjin Fukang Co. LTD while dodecyl trimethyl ammonium chloride (DTAC), sodium oleate (SO) and sodium dodecyl benzenesulfonate (SDBS) were purchased from Tianjin Siensi Opde technology Co., LTD. Sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) was purchased from Rare Chemical Reagents Factory. Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA) was bought from Beijing PuBoXin biotechnology Co., LTD.
label: y

paragraph: IHN refers to the number of water molecules surrounding an ion [30]. When ionic surfactants are dissolved in solvents, their hydrophilic heads dissociate into ions [31]. Hence, IHN was used to represent the hydrophilic interaction force of water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants at the water/dopes interface. Four typical surfactants with different hydrophilic heads but similar hydrophobic ends are selected, namely, ammonium, carboxylate, sulfonate, and sulfate surfactants. IHN of the surfactants used in this paper is in referenced [30] and listed in Table 2. IHN in the references was obtained by X-ray diffraction methods.
label: n

paragraph: The cloud points were determined by conventional titration method [13]. Homogeneous polymer solutions with different PSF concentration and additives (PEG and surfactants) in DMAc were prepared by stirring for 5 h at 343.15 K. Deionized water was added dropwise into the dope solutions under constant agitation by using pipette until perpetual turbidity was observed. The cloud points were noted when the turbidity of the dope solutions did not disappear for at least 30 min. The composition of the cloud points was obtained by the amount of deionized water.
label: n

paragraph: Digital Viscometer (NDJ-8S, Shanghai Jinghai Instrument Co., LTD.) was used to measure the dopes viscosity. The testing was implemented using a sample container under shear rate of 12.0 rpm at 298.15 K. For each of the solutions, at least five measurements were made and the average values are showed in Table 2.
label: n

paragraph: Polymer solutions with PSF, PEG-4000, and different surfactants were prepared using DMAc as solvent and then was stirred at least 5 h at 343.15 K. The homogenous dope solutions were degassed at 343.15 K until no air bubbles existed. The homogenous dope solutions were evenly casted on a glass plate. Then, the glass plate was promptly immerged into coagulant (water) at 298.15 K. The resulting membrane was then reserved in tap water to clear out the remaining additives and solvent. The detailed compositions of the dope solutions are showed in Table 2.
label: y

paragraph: Dope solution was evenly filled into a special flat beaker with at a 3 mm depth. The beaker was then immersed into water bath at 298.15 K. The Shore rubber hardness tester (TH220, Libo instrument Co. LTD, China) was used to measure the real-time hardness value of dope solution [28,29]. The dope solution was considered to have completely solidified when the real-time value ceased to increase. This time was recorded to as the solidification time of dope solution. Here, the thickness of dope solution tested is far beyond the real thickness of membrane, and the measurement objective of the solidification time is to indicate the change of the kinetics of phase separation.
label: n

paragraph: A scanning electron microscope (Zeiss Group, Oberkochen, Germany) was used to observe the surface and cross-sectional structure of the PSF membranes. Dried membrane samples were evenly sputter-coated with gold-palladium. Image-Pro-Plus 7.0 (Media Cybernetics, USA) software was used to measure the surface porosity of membranes. At least four testing were carried out for one data point and the average value was recorded [32,33]. A gas-liquid porometer (Porolux 1000), purchased from Porometer Co., LTD (Belgium), was utilized to measure the bubble point pore size and pore size distribution. Porewick with 16 dyn/cm was used to saturate the pores of PSF membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The surface roughness of dry membranes was characterized by an atomic force microscope (AFM) (Dimension Icon SPM, Bruker, USA) in AC tapping mode. Scanning on upper surfaces of membranes was done in an area of 5 x 5 mm using a SCANASYST-AIR model tip (Bruker, USA). The contact angle meter (Harke Speca, Japan) was utilized to test the static contact angle of the membrane surfaces in air. The samples were initially dried for 48 h at 35  to remove the moisture. An average of five measurements at different positions for each membrane sample were taken at room temperature and the average value recorded.
label: n

paragraph: The surface chemistry of the PSF membranes was characterized by using Attenuated Total Reflectance Fourier Transformed Infrared Spectrometer (ATR-FTIR) (Vector-22, Germany). The spectra were collected at room temperature with a resolution of 4 cm-1.
label: n

paragraph: Porosity was estimated using the gravimetric method, which was calculated according to Eq. (1):(1)e=(Ww-Wd)/rW(Ww-Wd)/rW+Wd/rpx100%where rp is the density of polymer (i.e., PSF). Ww is the wet weight of PSF membranes, rw = 1.0 g cm-3, Wd is the dry weight of PSF membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The tensile strength of dry membranes was measured using electronic strength tester (YG061F/PC, Laizhou electron instrument Co., LTD, China) at room temperature. The membranes were cut into pieces measuring 10 cm by 2 cm before testing. The ends of samples were clamped and then stretched at a constant tensile rate of 600 mm/min.
label: n

paragraph: The separation performance testing of membranes was conducted using a dead-end filtration system [34]. The actual permeate area was 12.56 cm2. The first testing was the evaluation of the permeability of PSF membranes. First, each membrane was compacted at 0.20 MPa for 20 min to obtain steady state. Then the transmembrane pressure was adjusted to 0.10 MPa and controlled by using a pressure valve. The pure water flux (PWP) was evaluated at 0.10 MPa and calculated according to Eq. (2):(2)PWP=DVA*twhere ^V is the volume of permeated water (L), A is the actual permeation area (m2), t is the operation time (h).
label: n

paragraph: The second testing was the evaluation of the rejection of membranes. The feed solution was 0.1 gL-1 solution of BSA. The ultraviolet spectrophotometer (TU-1810 UV), purchased from Beijing Purkinje General Instrument co. LTD (China), was utilized to measure the concentrations of BSA in the filtration and feed solutions at a wavelength of 280 nm. The rejection (R) was calculated using the following equation:(3)R=(1-CpCf)x100%where Cp and Cf are the concentrations of BSA in the filtration and feed solutions, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 2(a) illustrates the phase diagram for PSF/DMAc/water system and the influence of surfactants with different hydrophilic heads on the cloud point. Results show that the cloud point curves are pretty much unaffected by the addition of a small quantity (2.0 wt%) of different surfactants into polymer solution. This indicated that the addition of surfactants with different hydrophilic heads does not greatly impact the thermodynamics of the system [13,35].
label: n

paragraph: The viscosities of dope solutions, which can influence the exchange rate of water and dope solutions during NIPS process, are shown in Fig. 2(b). For this reason, the molecular weight of surfactants used in this study are close to each other and less than 1000 Da, and the addition amounts of surfactants in dope solutions is constant (2.0 wt%). As expected, the addition of small molecule surfactants with different hydrophilic heads does not significantly affect the viscosity of dope solutions.
label: n

paragraph: However, notable change in the kinetics of PS is observed in Fig. 2(c). Fig. 2(c) shows that the addition of surfactants is found to decrease the solidification time compared to PSF-O due to surfactant is amphiphilic which can improve MDWDS [22,27-29]. Interestingly, the solidification time further decreases as the IHN of surfactants increases. Surfactants used in the current work are hydrocarbon surfactants, that is, the hydrophobic interaction between hydrophobic polymer and the hydrophobic tails of surfactants remains unchanged. The coagulation bath used here is tap water at 298.15 K. Hence, the only variable in this study is the hydrophilic interaction force of water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants, which may account for the trend in Fig. 2(c). This is because surfactants will directionally align at the water/dope interface with the hydrophilic heads toward the polar phase (water) and the hydrophobic tails toward the non-polar phase (dope solutions) to minimize the interfacial free energy. The surfactants attract water into dope solutions by hydrophilic interaction. This can improve the exchange rate of dope solutions and water during NIPS process. The hydrophilic interaction force between water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants is then altered as the hydrophilic heads of surfactants are modified [31,36,37], eventually affecting the MDWDS. With the heightened hydrophilic interaction force between water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants (i.e., with the increase of the surfactant IHN in Fig. 2(c)), the surfactants attract water into the dope solution faster and efficiently. Hence, MDWDS is further facilitated. Kinetically, it can be concluded from Fig. 2(c) that the solidification time further decreases as the IHN of surfactants increases.
label: n

paragraph: The addition of surfactants into dope solutions has been reported in numerous previous studies, but they were added to improve the water flux of membrane by empirically increasing the addition amounts of the surfactants into dope solutions. This approach normally has obvious negative influences on the pore size and mechanical strength of the fabricated membranes. Notably, the regulation of MDWDS in NIPS by changing the hydrophilic heads of surfactants has not been reported before. Herein, this process is denoted "surfactants assisted nonsolvent induced phase separation" (SA-NIPS). SA-NIPS offers an essentially different viewpoint about the influence of surfactants on the MDWDS and the overall PS process.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 3 presents the SEM images of the upper surface morphology of the PSF membranes prepared without (PSF-O) and with different surfactants. Fig. 3 indicates that the upper surface of the virgin PSF membrane (PSF-O) is relatively dense, which would inhibit permeability. However, SA-NIPS increases the pore number on the upper surface of PSF membranes (i.e., IHN = 4, 6, 9 and 12) at various degrees.
label: n

paragraph: In order to reveal the key role of surfactant IHN during the surface pore formation of PSF membranes, Image J software is utilized to quantify the surface porosity of PSF membranes. As expected, Fig. 4 indicates that the surface porosity of the PSF membranes increased with an increase of surfactant IHN. This is because as the IHN increased (i.e., with the elevation the hydrophilic interaction force of water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants), the surfactants attracted more water into dope solution. This process opens up the dope solution interface (i.e., played a pore-forming role at the interface), thus splitting PSF dope solution into more and smaller PSF rich-phase. Hence, the MDWDS is further facilitated (Fig. 2(c)). This phenomenon normally increases the surface porosity of polymer membranes [28,29,38,39].
label: n

paragraph: In general, the surface roughness of porous membranes changes as surface porosity changes. Hence, the upper surface roughness of the PSF membranes was studied by AFM. Table 3 shows that the mean surface roughness increased with an increase of the IHN. This is because increasing the IHN improved the surface porosity of PSF membranes, which led to the formation of a rougher surface [28,40].
label: n

paragraph: The hydrophilicity of PSF membranes was measured via static water contact angle method. It can be observed in Table 3 that the contact angle of the PSF membranes varied negligibly. This is because the post-treatment technology in this research (see Section 2.4) eliminated all traces of the additives (surfactants and PEG) and solvent. To support this deduction, ATR-FTIR spectra of the upper surfaces of the PSF membranes were collected. For all samples, there are no the stretching vibrations of hydroxyl groups at 3300 cm-1 in Fig. 5, indicating the remaining additives (surfactants and PEG) were cleared out. This also implied SA-NIPS doesn't affect the surface hydrophilicity of PSF membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The cross-sectional images of PSF membranes are displayed in Fig. 6. All PSF membranes show a representative asymmetric morphology, composed of a skin-layer supported by elongated finger-like voids. The PSF membranes prepared by SA-NIPS displayed somewhat wider finger-like voids in the sub-layers in comparison with the virgin PSF membranes (PSF-O). The size of finger-like voids somewhat increased as the increase of the IHN. The phenomenon can be ascribed to the faster MDWDS during NIPS [23,29]. In other words, the size of finger-like voids somewhat increased as the increase of the rate of MDWDS (i.e., solidification time decreases in Fig. 2(c)).
label: n

paragraph: Effects of surfactant IHN on the pure water flux of PSF membranes is displayed in Fig. 7. The virgin PSF membrane demonstrated the lowest pure water flux of 282 L m-1h-1bar-1 due to the dense upper surface of PSF-O (Fig. 3). It is worth noting that pure water flux improved with the increase of surfactant IHN as expected, which is attributed to the increase in surface porosity (Fig. 4). Compared to the virgin PSF membrane (PSF-O), the pure water flux of the PSF membranes prepared by SA-NIPS increased by a maximum of 2.9 times.
label: n

paragraph: There are multiple techniques used to characterize membrane pore size, such as mercury intrusion method, bubble-point method, solute rejection measurements and so on [40]. Though pore size data generated from each of these methods is different, there is a common association among them. In view of this, bubble-point method and solute rejection measurements were used to investigate the influence of the IHN on the pore size of PSF membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 8(a) shows that both BSA rejection method and bubble-point method indicate that the addition of surfactants into dope solutions and the increase of surfactant IHN do not markedly influence the BSA rejection and bubble-point pore size of PSF membranes. This is because the dominating factors affecting pore size of polymer membranes [28,39] are the kinds and quantities of the main pore-forming additives and the membrane material concentration, etc. In this work, the dominating factors are almost constant, and the only variable is the small addition (2.0 wt.%) of surfactants with low molecular weight (less than 1000 Da). This indicates that the surfactants in the work primarily function as improving the pore numbers of PSF membrane. The pore size of PSF membrane is mostly determined by macromolecular additives such as PEG. It suggests that increasing the IHN of surfactants can significantly improve the pure water flux of PSF membrane, but not significantly affect the membrane pore size.
label: n

paragraph: For porous membranes, the peak of pore size distribution is close to the maximum pore size of membrane indicating the enhancement of the membrane sieving performance [28,29]. Fig. 8(b) displays the pore size distribution of PSF membranes, measured by pore size analyzer based on gas/liquid displacement method. The peak of pore size distribution located from 0.019 mm to 0.022 mm, indicating that SA-NIPS does not dramatically impact the pore size of PSF membranes. Specifically, the peak of pore size distribution shifted to the maximum pore size with the increase in surfactant IHN, indicating the pore size distribution of PSF membranes was optimized.
label: n

paragraph: Porosity measured by the gravimetric method is negatively correlated with the mechanical strength of porous membranes [41,42]. Obvious increase in porosity can lower the mechanical strength of porous membranes. Hence, the porosity of the PSF membranes is investigated, and displayed in Fig. 9(a). The porosity of the virgin PSF membrane (PSF-O) was 85.7%, which was a little higher than that of the PSF membranes prepared by SA-NIPS. The porosity of the PSF membranes prepared by SA-NIPS showed no obvious change with the increase of the IHN. This indicates SA-NIPS does not affect the porosity of PSF membranes obviously.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 9(b) shows the elongation and tensile strength of PSF membranes. The tensile strength of PSF membranes did not considerably change. Several factors, such as the kinds and adding amounts of main pore-forming additives, membrane material concentration, etc., are known to influence the tensile strength of membranes [39,40]. These factors are kept constant in this work and the only variable is the addition of trace amount (2.0 wt.%) of surfactants with low molecular weight (less than 1000 Da). This further indicates that the proposed method solves the trade-off bottleneck in which increasing membrane flux by adding additives into dope solutions results in lower the mechanical strength of polymer membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Herein, we reported that the membrane formation process of NIPS was successfully modified by adjusting the hydrophilic interaction force of water and the hydrophilic heads of ionic surfactants for the first time, thus successfully preparing PSF membranes with more through-pores. Elevating the hydrophilic interaction force between water and the hydrophilic heads of surfactants (i.e., increasing the IHN of surfactants) was conducive for the surfactants to efficiently attract more water into dope solutions, eventually promoting MDWDS during NIPS. This process increased the surface porosity and optimized the pore size distribution of the membranes. It was observed that the water flux of as-prepared membranes was significantly increased (up to 2.9 times increase, maximumly). Due to the addition of small amounts of surfactants with low molecular weight, the proposed method improved the water flux of PSF membrane without lowering the tensile strength and enlarging pore size of porous membranes markedly. Other testing results showed that the surface roughness increased slightly and the pure water contact angle was not significantly affected. This research on the pore-forming mechanism of surfactants is still in the preliminary stage, and there are still many shortcomings. However, it may provide some new ideas for the preparation of high-performance porous membranes.
label: n

paragraph: No data was used for the research described in the article.
