paragraph: In the last decades, wastewaters have resulted in a huge damage to the nature due to releasing to the environment with no suitable treatment. Hence, state-of-the-art and sustainable water purification techniques are necessary for addressing the water scarcity issue, producing potable water from polluted water, and saving the ecosystem from pollution [12,49]. The conventional treatment strategies proved not to be efficient for the elimination of pollutants. Membrane-based methods have shown a high efficiency while consuming lower energies than the conventional ones, e.g., distillation [13,48]. Nowadays, nanofiltration (NF) has been applied in different industries, e.g., wastewater treatment, as a promising route. It has proved satisfactory in separation and purification of different mixtures in a wide range of applications, e.g., food, chemical and pharmaceutical industries, arising from its low investment cost, low energy demand and significant separation efficiency [27,50].
label: n

paragraph: In the recent decade, several phase inversion methods have been widely utilized the fabrication of mixed matrix membranes, including non-solvent-induced phase separation (NIPS), temperature-induced phase separation (TIPS), and vapor-induced phase separation (VIPS). Among them, the NIPS method is considered as the oldest strategy extensively utilized in the preparation of numerous polymeric membranes [4,7,8]. Nevertheless, it is well-known that this process leads to the formation of membranes with macro-voids [17,43], considered as a big issue in this field of study. Hence, the VIPS method has emerged as a new strategy to overcome this drawback. In this approach, during the exposure of the membrane to the vapor medium, because a slow mass transfer of water is occurred from the vapor phase to the casting solution, a uniform spongy structure is created in the membrane with no macro-voids [3,31,44]. As an example, it was reported by Su et al. that after the formation of polysulfone membranes using the VIPS approach, a completely cellular morphology was formed by applying a relatively long exposure time [19,24,51]. Furthermore, it is also worth mentioning that the coupled VIPS-NIPS strategy has been also employed in recent years to prepare novel membranes. In these systems, the non-solvent is often water, and so, the phase separation can be promoted via the water vapor transfer. The vapor's role is so crucial in the polymer precipitation, which is completed in the non-solvent bath [23].
label: n

paragraph: Polysulfones, which are categorized as thermoplastic polymers, has been widely employed in the production of the membranes for separation technology, arising from their low cost and ease of processing, and thermal and chemical stability [9]. Polysulfone (PSf) is an extensively utilized material for membrane fabrication while polyphenylsulfone (PPSU) is a relatively new polymer having extraordinary properties in comparison to the more frequently applied PSF and polyethersulfone (PES). PPSU provides superior impact strength than PSF and PES. It is also significantly chemical resistant, and shows a remarkably low rate of water absorption, making it appropriate for applications involving superheated steam sterilization and alkali washing. It also possesses excellent dimensional stability and superb resistance to high-energy radiation and heat. All these properties make PPSU a promising candidate for design of novel membranes [35,36]. Nevertheless, no examples have been reported of the application on membranes based on PPSU in industry, originating from its low flux. For example, pristine ultrafiltration PPSU membranes prepared using the NIPS method provide very low water flux of 0-10 L.m-2.h-1 at 0.1 MPa [29]. The low flux of PPSU membranes can be attributed to the restriction of the variation of casting solution composition because of low miscibility of PPSU with commonly utilized pore-forming additives (polyethylene glycol (PEG), polyvinypyrrolidone (PVP)) in aprotic amide solvents (N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) etc.) [34]. Accordingly, it is an urgent need to modify PPSU membranes for the purpose of enhancing their separation performance, hydrophilicity and antifouling resistance for practical applications. One of the strategies to enhance membrane separation and antifouling performance is blending, which can be done through the introduction of hydrophilic water-soluble polymers and oligomers to the PPSU casting solution, surfactants, low molecular weight substances, inorganic nanoparticles, and metal organic frameworks [26,35,42]. The incorporation of additives has proven so efficient, which is usually done through the incorporation of three different types of additives: (a) inorganic additives, e.g., ZnO [41], SiO2 (Sonawane et al., 2022), TiO2[33], and MOFs [20]; (b) organic additives, e.g., PVP and PEG copolymers (Vidal et al., 2021; Falahati et al., 2019), GO (Tantiwatcharothai et al., 2020), MWCNT [45], and surfactants [11]; (c) additives as the non-solvent, e.g., H2O (Javanbakht et al., 2020), di-alcohols [28], and alcohols [30].
label: n

paragraph: Polysaccharides can be extracted from a variety of sources, including plants, such as cellulose, microorganisms, such as dextran, seaweeds, such as carrageenan, animals, such as chitosan, and seeds [21]. Basil seed, a tiny black seed which is native to different countries in Asia, i.e., Iran and India, is made up of three major components possessing various molecular weights, including polysaccharides (92%), proteins (2.37%), and uronic acids (6.51%) [33,41]. When the seeds are soaked in water, their outer pericarp swells into a hydrogel, which is called mucilage [32]. Because of the fact that basil seeds are easily available with a low price, the fabrication of each gram of mucilage is done by a lower price when compared to that of synthetic polymers [37].
label: n

paragraph: In this research work, neat and mixed matrix polyphenylsulfone-polysulfone membranes incorporated with basil seed mucilage hydrogel were prepared using the VIPS-NIPS technique, in which 1,4-dioxane was utilized as the co-solvent. Membranes with sponge-like morphology with small macro-voids were formed. BSM was used in this study due to its significant hydrophilicity, leading to a considerable enhancement in the flux performance of the mixed matrix membranes. Different mucilage hydrogel contents were incorporated into the membranes to fabricate a variety of membranes with different properties, and achieve a membrane possessing outstanding performance in terms of rejecting different dyes.
label: n

paragraph: Basil seeds were supplied via Reyhan Gum Parsian, Iran. Commercial polyphenylsulfone (PPSU, Ultrason P3010 MR; Mw=35,000 g.mol-1) and polysulfone (PSf, Ultrason(r) 6010 P) were supplied via BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany). Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP; k30), direct yellow, and Methyl Green were obtained from Merck, Germany. Methylene blue, 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1,4-dioxane, and Crystal Violet were supplied by PubChem.
label: y

paragraph: Here, for enhancing the basil seeds purity, impurities washed away with DI water and ethanol, consecutively, and then, the seeds dried at 25 degC. Next, the purified basil seeds were soaked in DI water at 25 degC for 40 min, leading to swelling their outer layer as a gelatinous layer around the seeds. After that, in order to improve the extraction efficiency, NaOH solution (2%wt.) was added drop-wise into the BSM mixture solution under stirring until adjusting pH to 8, which was conducted for 9 h at 70 degC, after which the extracted BSM and the seeds were completely separated from each other. Eventually, using decantation and centrifuging at 8000 rpm for 20 min, BSM was separated. The mucilage hydrogel extraction process is shown in Scheme 1.
label: y

paragraph: First, for the fabrication of the mixed matrix membranes, different amounts of the BSM hydrogel were first added into the DMF/1,4-dioxane/PVP mixtures, followed by sonication for 2 h to prepare homogeneous mixtures. In the next step, PPSf/PSf with a concentration of 18 wt% was added into the as-prepared mixtures and completely dissolved after continuously stirring at RT for 24 h. The homogenous polymer solution was de-gassed using a desiccator apparatus for 30 min and cast on a glass plate in a climatic box (relative humidity of 65 +- 5% and temperature 40 degC) for 10 s using a Doctor Blade device with a gap of 200 um (the VIPS step), and then, transferred to coagulation bath (the NIPS step). Finally, the prepared membranes were taken out of the bath and kept in DI water until conducting the separation tests. The neat membrane was also prepared by the same method, except that no BSM was added to the polymer mixture. The composition of casting solutions are exhibited in Table 1.
label: y

paragraph: Scheme 2 shows the dead-end filtration set-up used for determining both the rejection and flux performance. For determining the flux performance, DI water was added to the above-mentioned cell and permeated under the pressure of 7 bar. Then, flux was determined using Eq. 1, as follows:(1)F=VAxtWhere A, V, t, and F are ascribed to the effective surface area (m2), the permeate volume (L), the test time interval (h), and flux (L.m-2.h-1).
label: n

paragraph: Dyes rejection performance was also studied via adding a 30 ppm dye/water solution to the dead-end cell, followed via permeating under N2 gas pressure (7 bar; 25 degC).
label: n

paragraph: Dyes rejection of the neat and mixed matrix membranes were also determined via Eq. 2, as follows:(2)R=CF-CPCFx100%Where CF, R, and Cp are the feed solution concentration, the dye rejection percentage, and the permeate solution concentration, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the permeate solution concentration was evaluated by investigating its lmax using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Thermo, Biomate5, USA).
label: n

paragraph: BET analysis, Belsorp mini II, Japan, was done to determine the extracted mucilage hydrogel pore size. The hydrogel was also investigated with FT-IR (Perkin Elmer-spectrum 65); Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; TA, Q600, USA); XRD analysis (PHILIPS, PW1730, Netherland) ranged in 2O = 5-90deg; and FESEM, EDS and SEM Mapping analyses (TESCAN, MIRA III). The neat and mixed matrix polyphenylsulfone-polysulfone membranes were also investigated by ATR FT-IR (Bruker, Tensor 27, Equinox 55); AFM analysis (NT-MDT, semi-contact mode); XRD analysis (Diffractometer D8, SIEMENS) ranged in 2O = 10-80deg; FESEM, EDS and SEM Mapping analyses (TESCAN, MIRA III); and static water contact angle (WCA, Dataphysics, OCA 15 plus);.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. S1a exhibits the FT-IR spectrum related to the chemical structure of the extracted mucilage hydrogel. Based on the spectrum, the peaks emerged at 1096, 1165, 1248, 1455 and 1644 cm-1, corresponding to the CO and COC stretching vibrations of the glycosidic linkage in polysaccharides, C-H vibration, and the symmetric and asymmetric COO stretching vibrations, respectively [47]. Additionally, there are also two peaks which have emerged at 1535 and 1746 cm-1 correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric CO stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups, respectively. Furthermore, the peaks appeared at 2854, 2935 and 3006 cm-1 are also related to the CH absorption, CH2 bending, and CH stretching vibrations, respectively [11]. Also, the board peak at 3100-3500 cm-1 correspond to the alcohol -OH groups.
label: n

paragraph: Crystallinity of the extracted mucilage hydrogel was evaluated by XRD analysis (Fig. S1b), based on which it can be discerned that the mucilage hydrogel is an amorphous natural polymer, which can be demonstrated by the broad peak emerged at 2th = 12-28deg [14,22].
label: n

paragraph: TGA analysis was done to study the thermal stability of the extracted mucilage hydrogel (Fig. S2a). Accordingly, it can be seen that the TGA curve shows a four-step decomposition by raising temperature from 0deg to 800degC. The first weight loss step has appeared at 60-150 degC, which is owing to the moisture and solvent elimination. The second weight-loss step is observed at the temperature range of 250-350 degC, which is because of the decomposition of both the hemicellulose polysaccharides and glycosidic links of cellulose [46]. The third weight-loss step and the fourth one have also appeared at the temperature ranges of 360-470 degC and 480-600 degC, which are originated from the decomposition of the cellulose and lignin, respectively [45]. Based on the above-mentioned results, the mucilage hydrogel can be stable in the reactions with the temperature of < 150 degC.
label: n

paragraph: The pores characteristics of the extracted BSM, BET analysis was performed in terms of evaluating the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S2b). It is demonstrated by the results that BSM has a mesoporous structure by having a type IV isotherm with H4-type hysteresis loops (IUPAC classification) [10]. Furthermore, it was indicated that BSM has the BET surface area (as,BET) of 1.09 m2/g, pore volume of 0.27 cm3/g and mean pore diameter of 5.57 nm. Additionally, based on the BJH curve, the pores in the BSM structure mostly have the radius of 1.86 nm.
label: n

paragraph: EDX and SEM Mapping analyses were also conducted to investigate the elemental structure and the elements distribution, respectively, in the extracted BSM (Fig. S3). According to the EDX analysis, it is indicated that BSM is composed of three different elements, i.e., N, C, and O, in which the C and O elements content is dominant. SEM Mapping analysis also indicates that the elements have a good dispersion in the BSM structure.
label: n

paragraph: SEM analysis was also done to study the morphology of the extracted mucilage hydrogel (Fig. 1). Based on Fig. 1, it is discernible that the hydrogel has not only a rough surface with large wrinkles but also some network structures. Based on the literature, this morphology is able to considerably enhance the direct dye rejection [18].
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 2a exhibits the FTIR spectra of the PSf/PPSU, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.1, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 membranes. Based on Fig. 2a, it can be discerned that two strong peaks have emerged around 1493 and 1560 cm-1 in all the spectra, corresponding to the aromatic vibrational bonding of CC in the PSf and PPSU backbones. Moreover, it is also obvious that strong peaks have emerged at 1158 and 1233 cm-1 in all the spectra, which are ascribed to the vibrational bonding of C-O-C and OSO, respectively, in the PSf and PPSU backbones. Additionally, the peaks appeared around 3041 and 2966 cm-1 are attributed to the vibrational =C-H bonding in the aromatic ring of PSf and PPSU backbones and the aliphatic vibrational -C-H bonding of the PSf backbone, respectively [6,25]. Also, two peaks have appeared around 1310 and 1320 cm-1, corresponding to the vibrational region of the sulfone group [30]. By drawing a comparison between the neat and mixed matrix membranes, it can be found that most of the peaks of BSM and those of the membrane matrix have overlapped. Nevertheless, the broad peak appeared at 3100-3400 cm-1 is attributed to the hydroxyl groups of BSM, which confirms the successful incorporation of BSM into the membranes matrix.
label: n

paragraph: XRD analysis was done to evaluate the crystalline nature of the fabricated neat and mixed matrix membranes. Based on Fig. 2b, a broad peak has appeared around 2th= 18deg, which corresponds to the amorphous nature of both polyphenylsulfone and polysulfone [2,39]. Additionally, the peaks corresponding to the MMMs have been broadened somewhat, arising from the incorporation of the mucilage hydrogel between the polymeric chains. It is also noteworthy that the hydrogel broad peak, at about 2th = 20deg, has overlapped with the strong broad peak of the matrix, and therefore, it is not distinguishable.
label: n

paragraph: The elemental analysis was done using EDX analysis, as depicted in Fig. S4. Accordingly, it is clear that the neat membrane is only composed of C, O, and S elements, while the mixed matrix membranes are composed of C, O, S, and N elements, strongly demonstrating the successful incorporation of BSM hydrogel. Furthermore, it is clear that the more the BSM content has increased, the more the N wt% has increased in the composition.
label: n

paragraph: The surface FESEM images of PSf/PPSU, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.1, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2, and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 are exhibited in Fig. 3. Accordingly, it can be seen that the neat membrane has a uniform surface without any hydrogel and impurities. By the incorporation of the BSM hydrogel into the mixed matrix membranes matrix, the BSM hydrogel has also appeared on the surface of the modified membranes. Furthermore, the more the BSM content hydrogel increased, the more hydrogels have been loaded on the membranes surface. It is also worth noting that the hydrogel has been dispersed uniformly on the membranes surface, enhancing their efficiency in separation performance.
label: n

paragraph: SEM-Mapping analysis was conducted to investigate the elemental distribution on the surface of the PSf/PPSU and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 membranes (Fig. 4). It is clear from the images that all the elements are distributed uniformly on the surface of the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 membrane, demonstrating good dispersion of the BSM hydrogel. Moreover, the appearance of the N element on the surface of the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 membrane confirms the successful incorporation of the BSM hydrogel in the matrix of the membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The high- and low-magnification cross-sectional FESEM images of PSf/PPSU, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.1, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2, and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 are shown in Fig. 5. Accordingly, it can be seen in low-magnification images that the neat and modified membranes are made up of an asymmetric morphology with finger-like structures because of employing considerable DMF concentration in the dope solution [40]. Additionally, based on high-magnification images, the neat and modified membranes are also comprised of an open cellular spongy morphology, because in the VIPS-NIPS route, a slower absorption of water molecules occurs in comparison with the NIPS one, delaying the phase inversion process, and so, results in the creation of a sponge-like morphology [38].
label: n

paragraph: It is also obvious that the finger-like pores are larger in the neat membrane structure in comparison to those of the modified membranes. Furthermore, the more the BSM content increases, the more the finger-like pores size decreases, indicating that the phase separation slows down by increasing the BSM content [5]. This can be attributed to the increase in viscosity of the polymer casting solution through increasing the BSM content (0.8, 0.89, 0.97, and 1.18 Pa.s corresponding to the PSf/PPSU, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.1, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2, and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 samples, respectively), leading to a decrease in water molecules diffusion through the polymer matrix. According to the literature, the increased viscosity of the casting solution takes the part of a physical roadblock against the mass transfer between non-solvent and solvent, by which a delayed demixing occurs during the membrane preparation process [52].
label: n

paragraph: The roughness parameters of the PSf/PPSU, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.1, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 membranes were evaluated by conducting the AFM analysis (5 umx5 um). According to Fig. 6, roughness of the mixed. Moreover, in the mixed matrix membranes, by increasing the BSM content, roughness has also increased. Table S1 also shows the roughness parameters in terms of ten-point average roughness, average roughness (Ra), root mean square (Rq), and height difference between the highest peak and the lowest valley (Ry). Accordingly, it can also be demonstrated that by incorporating BSM, the roughness parameters have also increased. Additionally, it is worth pointing out that the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 membrane possesses a much higher roughness than the other membranes because of the great BSM content incorporated in the membrane matrix [1].
label: n

paragraph: To evaluate the effect of the incorporated BSM on the hydrophilicity of the prepared mixed matrix membranes, contact angle analysis was performed, as shown in Fig. 7. according to the literature, the more the hydrophilic nature, the less the contact angle [16,26]. Accordingly, it is easily discernible that by incorporating BSM into the membrane matrix, hydrophilicity has significantly enhanced. The more BSM has incorporated into the membrane matrix, the more CA has decreased [15,28]. All these findings are in a complete accordance with the enhancement in the mixed matrix membranes flux.
label: n

paragraph: The prepared membranes performance was investigated in terms of flux and dye rejection ability, as exhibited in Fig. 8. It is discernible that the neat membrane sample has provided lower rejection and flux in comparison to the mixed matrix membranes. After the addition of BSM, both rejection and water flux have been greatly enhanced. Although the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 sample provided a lower flux than the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 membrane sample, it showed the highest rejection performance, and therefore, it was selected as the optimum membrane.
label: n

paragraph: Long-term stability of the optimum membrane, i.e., PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2, was studied in terms of evaluating flux and dye rejection performance of the membrane after running the experiments for ten days (Fig. 9). Accordingly, as can be observed, the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 sample could provide a superb dye rejection performance with negligible changes after long periods. Additionally, flux exhibited negligible decline owing to dilution and fouling effect. All these observations indicates great long-term stability of the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 sample in terms of both flux and dye rejection, which showed negligible deterioration by passing time.
label: n

paragraph: In this step, the dynamic fouling trend of the BSM hydrogel-incorporated membranes was evaluated in terms of their flux change throughout the alternative filtration of pure water and BSA solution. Based on Fig. 10, it can be found that all of the modified membranes could provide much higher fluxes (water flux, BSA solution flux and water flux after cleaning) than the unmodified membrane. When the pure water was replaced via the BSA solution in the filtration cell, flux of all the membranes decreased. The protein flux reduction compared to the pure water flux of the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 membrane was lower than that of the neat membrane, which demonstrated less fouling tendency of the modified membranes in comparison to the unmodified one. After the protein filtration, the flux recovery property of the membranes was evaluated through determining their subsequent pure water flux, as shown in Fig. 11. After the water cleaning process, the PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.1, PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.2 and PSf/PPSU@BSM 0.5 membranes recovered around 89%, 96% and 94% of their primary water flux, respectively, while the unmodified membrane recovered only 75% of its initial flux, indicating that the cleaning action had affected the BSM hydrogel-incorporated membranes with more efficiency. The outstanding fouling resistance with BSM hydrogel loadings could happen owing to the increased hydrophilicity of the modified membranes, which could prevent the undesired adhesion of hydrophobic foulants because of the formation of a thin water layer.
label: n

paragraph: Here, basil seed mucilage hydrogel was incorporated in mixed matrix blend membranes containing polyphenylsulfone/polysulfone using the VIPS-NIPS strategy, by which membranes with sponge-like morphology with small macro-voids were formed. BSM was utilized in this study due to its significant hydrophilicity, leading to a considerable enhancement in the flux performance of the mixed matrix membranes. Different mucilage hydrogel contents were incorporated in the membranes to fabricate a variety of membranes with different properties, and achieve a membrane possessing outstanding performance in terms of rejecting different dyes. By drawing a comparison between the neat and the mixed matrix membranes, it was found that excellent rejection performance and water flux were achieved after the incorporation of BSM. Long-term durability of the membrane containing 0.2 wt% BSM also demonstrated that after ten days, dye rejection and flux performance showed negligible changes.
label: n

paragraph: Effective treatments of waste waters are highly desired for many industries [1,2], including dye and textile industries, in which dye molecules were separated and recycled by methods including electro-chemical separation, adsorption and deposition [3-7]. Recently, membrane based separation technologies are adopted in these processes in the treatment of high-salinity textile waste water to reduce energy consumption, improve efficiency and simplified operations [8-11]. Since conventional ultra-filtration (UF) membranes had too big pore sizes (0.2-0.01 mm) to retain dyes [1,12,13], and nanofiltration (NF) membranes had too small pore sizes (<2 nm)for dye/salt separation, tight ultra-filtration (TUF) (or "loose" nanofiltration) membranes with pore sizes between 2 and 10 nm were developed to have high efficiency for separating dye molecules from inorganic salts [1,2].
label: n

paragraph: Various processes had been developed to prepare TUF membranes. Lan [14] et al. developed nano-porous phenolic resins based TUF membranes. Chen [15] et al. improved dye retention of ceramic TUF membranes by grafting amino silanes (KH-551). Polyether sulfone (PES) and sulphonated polysulfone (SPSF) based TUF membranes were also developed for dye/salt separation [16]. However, the trade-off between water flux and dye retention selectivity, had thwarted the applications of TUF membranes [17]. There is a strong need in developing high flux TUF membranes with high dye retention selectivity.
label: n

paragraph: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), such as zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs), assembled from inorganic ions and organic ligand [18,19], bearing controllable internal water selective permeating channels to promote water permeation [20,21]. They could be grown on porous substrates by the processes of in-situ chemical, electrochemical [22], layered [23], or stepwise liquid-phase epitaxial deposition [24] to form high performance MOF membranes [25-27]. Flexible mixed matrix membranes (MMMs) could be prepared by adding ZIF particles into polymers matrices [28-31]. However, agglomeration of ZIF particles in these membranes could form non-selective defects, leading to reduced dye rejection rates.
label: n

paragraph: In this work, a novel strategy was developed involving in-situ growing of ZIF particles during the non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS) process. The central divalent cations, such as Zn2+, were pre-loaded on the supporting non-woven fabrics(NWF), and then reacted with 2-methimidazole (2MIM) released from the casting solutions during NIPS processes. ZIF particles were in-situ grown, embedded in and packed under the thinned polysulfone porous surface layer to promote water permeation while the molecular weight cut off (MWCO) Stokes pore sizes were effectively controlled by tuning the inter-particulate spaces of the embedded and packed ZIF particles. The impact from variations in Zn (II) loading level, 2MIM content, reaction time, and amount of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) on the porosity and performance of the formed ZIF/PSF TUF-MMMs was systematically investigated.
label: n

paragraph: N,N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP, >=99.0% purity) purchased from Shanghai Taitan, Ltd. (Shanghai, China) was used as solvent and deionized water was used as non-solvent in the NIPS processes. Polysulfone (PSF, S6010) was purchased from Dongguan Haosheng Plastic Material Company and dried under vacuum at 60 degC for 12 h before use. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, >98%)) and 2-methylimidazole (2MIM, Analytical Grade) were purchased from Aladdin, Shanghai. Zn (NO3) 2*6H2O was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company. Congo Red (CR), Methyl Orange (MO) and Methylene Blue (MBe) were purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai) Reagent Company, Shanghai Maclean Biochemical Technology Company and Sinopharm Chemical Reagent company respectively. Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) NWF was purchased from Hangzhou Water Treatment Center.
label: y

paragraph: Preparation of ZIF-8 particles: Zinc nitrate hexahydrate was dissolved in DI water at a concentration of 1.23 g/100 ml and ultrasound for 20 min. At the same time, 2MIM was dissolved in Methanol at a concentration of 0.9 g/100 ml and ultrasound for 20 min. Then 2-MeIM solution were poured into zinc nitrate solution at a 1:6 vol ratio and let alone for another 12 h. The ZIF-8 particles were separated using centrifuging device, and dried at 30 degC in oven for 1 h before use.
label: y

paragraph: 18 g of polysulfone (PSF), and various amount of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and 2-methylimidazole (2MIM) were added to 74 g of N,N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), as shown in Table 1. By continuous stirring in an oil bath at 50 degC (200 rpm), a homogeneous casting solution was obtained and then stand still overnight to be fully de-foamed. The PET NWF were cut into 16cm x 16 cm piece and then was poured and completely wet by a 30 g/L Zn (NO3) 2*6H2O aqueous solution. After removal of excess liquid, the solution loading weight was measured for the calculation of Zn (NO3)2 loading. The Zn (II)-loaded NWF was then dried in oven at 30 degC for 0.5 h before use. The fully defoamed cast solution was then cast onto the Zn (II)-loaded NWF at a thickness of 250 mm using a coating machine. The coated film was then clamped into two poly-tetrafluoro-ethylene (PTFE) frames with inner diameters 0f 14cm x 14 cm, and then immersed into a 50 degC deionized (DI) water bath for a certain time for phase separation. During the phase separation process, 2MIM from the casting solution and Zn2+ from NWF were continuously ligated to form ZIF-8 NPs in the PSF matrix. In the end, the formed mixed matrix membrane was dried at 30 degC in an oven for 40 min and then sealed and stored in DI-water for testing.
label: y

paragraph: 18 g of polysulfone (PSF), 6 g of ZIF-8 particles, and 2 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) were added to N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP), with a total mass of 100 g. By continuous stirring in an oil bath at 50 degC (200 rpm), a casting suspension was obtained and then stand still overnight to be fully de-foamed. The fully de-foamed suspension was then cast onto the pristine PET NWF at a thickness of 250 mm using a coating machine. The coated film was then clamped into two PTFE frames with inner diameters of 14cm x 14 cm, and then immersed into a 50 degC de-ionized (DI) water bath for 45 min for phase separation. In the end, the formed mixed matrix membrane was dried at 30 degC in an oven for 40 min and then sealed and stored in DI-water for testing.
label: y

paragraph: Prior to taking cross sectional images, the membrane samples were frozen in liquid nitrogen and then ruptured to avoid excessive damage. The surface and cross sectional morphology were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SU8010, Hitachi HITACHI, Japan) at an accelerating voltage of 10 kV with a thin layer of gold sputtered to improve electron conductivity.
label: n

paragraph: The roughness was measured using an AFM (AFM, Dimension Icon, Bruker, USA) using average from three 5mm x 5 mm areas selected. X-ray diffraction measurements of ZIFs were conducted using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Thermo ARL, SCINTAGX'TRA) at 40 kV and 40 mA with Cu-Pb radiations. The samples were scanned in the 2th range of 5-40deg at a step size of 0.02deg and a scanning speed of 0.2 s per step.
label: n

paragraph: The hydrophilicity was evaluated using a contact angle measuring instrument (OCA-15EC Olympus, SZH 10). To obtain the exact contact angle for each sample, the average of five different areas was reported. Surface charges of the membranes were inspected using a zeta potential analyzer (Anton Paar SurPass 3, Austria) with the pH ranging from 3 to 10. Each datum point was averaged from three results in the same pH value. The chemical compositions of the membrane surface were estimated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250XI, USA). The concentration of zinc ions was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Elan DRC-e, USA). The values of the concentration were obtained from the average of three random areas. BET N2 adsorption isotherm were determined using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3020 system at Bath Temperature of -195.850 degC. Surface area was calculated using multi-point method.
label: n

paragraph: The capillary pore diameter (dc) distribution were analyzed using the NV Porolux500 system, Germany. Peak sharpness could be calculated by dividing the peak height value with peak width value at half the peak height for each peak.
label: n

paragraph: Solute MWCO Stokes pore size distribution was determined using the method by Zhu et at [32]. The Stokes diameters of the membrane were calculated from following equation:(1)dp=2*0.0397xM0.43where M was the molecular weight of PEG at 90% rejection.
label: n

paragraph: Then the pore size distribution of the membrane was expressed as follows:(2)dR(rp)drp=1rplnsp2Pexp[-(lnrp-lnmp)22(lnsp)2]where mp was the geometric mean radius of the solute at R = 50%, and sp was geometric standard deviation, equals to the solute radius ratio at R = 84.13% over that at 50%, obtained from modeled straight lines between R over log rs.
label: n

paragraph: rs, the stokes radius of PEG solutes could be calculated using following equation:(3)log rs = -1.4854 + 0.461 log Mwwhere, Mw was the molecular weight of PEG solute used.
label: n

paragraph: Pure water flux (PWF) was measured using a dead-end filtration system with an effective area of 19.645 cm2 at 25 degC and 1 bar. The pure water permeating volume were taken every 15 min until reaching a constant value. The pure water flux (Jw1) can be calculated using the following equation.(4)Jw1=QADtwhere Q was the volume of permeate water (L), A was the effective membrane area (m2), and Dt was the permeation time (h).
label: n

paragraph: The membrane rejection performance was determined using solutions of 0.1 g/L dyes or 1 g/L Na2SO4 after compressed at 1 bar for 1 h in the feed cell. UV-Vis spectro photometers with wavelengths of 497 nm (CR), 463 nm (MO), and 662 nm (MBe) were used, respectively, to determine the dye concentrations in the feed and permeate cells. The concentration of inorganic salts were determined by electrical conductivity meter (FE 38, Mettler Toledo). The rejection ratio could be calculated by the following equation:(5)R(%)=(1-CpCf)x100%where Cp and Cf were the concentrations of the solute in the feed cell and the permeate cell, respectively. Retention selectivity of the membrane between component A over B was calculated by following formula:(6)SA/B = RA/RBwhere RA and RB refer to the rejection ratio of the membrane to component A and B respectively.
label: n

paragraph: All the values presented in the figures were averages from five separated measurement of different samples while the error values were the standard deviation of the five measurements.
label: n

paragraph: As shown in Fig. 1, ZIF/PSF TUF-MMMs were prepared by in-situ growing ZIF particles during the NIPS process. The central divalent cations, such as Zn2+, were pre-loaded on PET NWF from nitrate solutions, and then reacted with the 2MIM released from the PSF casting solutions during NIPS processes. As shown in Table 1, the Zn(II), PVP and 2MIM loading levels as well as NIPS time were varied to study the structures and performance of the formed TUF-MMMs. Congo red (CR), methylene blue (MBe) and methyl orange (MO) in addition to Na2SO4 were used as solutes to differentiate the filtration performance of the membranes.
label: n

paragraph: XRD diffraction and infrared (IR) spectroscopy analyses were performed on the membranes to confirm that the grown particles were indeed ZIF-8. The presence of ZIF particles in TUF-Zn- PVP- 2MIM (TUF-326) and TUF-PVP-ZIF (TUF-020-d6) could be clearly proved by the characteristic peaks at 10.5deg, 12.86deg, 16.62deg and 18.22 degin Fig. 2a. In Fig. 2b-c, the IR peaks for SO from polysulfone at 1145 cm-1, for N-C from PVP at 1234 cm-1, together with the new peaks at 1660 cm-1 and 3487 cm-1 for CN and N-H bonds from 2MIM, and the increasing surface Zn content from XPS and EDX elemental scan (Figure S-2 and Fig. 3 in supporting information), could fully support the formation of ZIF particles in ZIF/PSF TUF-MMMs. Additional XRD characterization on the ZIF particles made with and without PVP in Figure S-1, also proved that the presence of PVP did not alter the crystalline frameworks of ZIF particles.
label: n

paragraph: The structure and properties of TUF-PVP (TUF-020), TUF-Zn-PVP (TUF-320), TUF-Zn-PVP-2MIM (TUF-326) and TUF-PVP-ZIF (TUF-020-d6) membranes were compared to reveal the unique characteristics of TUF-MMMs made from in-situ ZIF growing NIPS process. In Fig. 3c, ZIF particles in the sizes of 200-500 nm could be observed in the surface separating layers of ZIF/PSF TUF MMMs (TUF-326) not in the structures of TUF-PVP (TUF-020) and TUF-Zn-PVP (TUF-320). ZIF-8 particles of TUF-PVP-ZIF (TUF-020-d6) were added directly in the casting solution and fully sealed inside the PSF matrix as shown in Fig. 3d. These agreed well with its low BET surface area values (14.73 m2/g) shown in Fig. 4d.
label: n

paragraph: The in-situ formation of ZIF particles in the NIPS process had also greatly thinned the top PSF skin layers, from 937 nm (TUF-020), 893 nm (TUF-320) and 762 nm (TUF-020-d6), to 338 nm in TUF-326, leading to greatly reduced permeation resistance. In-situ formed ZIF particles in TUF-326 had fresh and open internal channels for solvent adsorption. These hydrophilic internal channels cross the fresh crystalline bodies of the embedded ZIF particles served as short-cuts for water permeating as illustrated in Scheme 1, leading to the highest water flux value of 247 L/(m2*h) (Tables S-6, Fig. 5c), 7.2 times higher than that of TUF-020.
label: n

paragraph: The internal pores of ZIF-8 particles were too small in size for N2 to penetrate, but the external surface of the formed ZIF-8 particles had added more than 2 m2/g open specific surfaces to the total available open surfaces of TUF-326 although TUF-020, TUF -320, and TUF-326 had specific surface areas in the same ranges of 40-43 m2/g in Fig. 4. Directly added pre-made ZIF-8 particles actually reduced the available adsorption specific surface area to 23.47 m2/g by altering the structure of the formed membranes, indicating very little outer surfaces of added ZIF-8 particles were available for N2 adsorption.
label: n

paragraph: Due to the molecular sieving effect of their internal channels in the sizes of 0.30-0.34 nm, the embedded or packed ZIF-8 particles only selectively enhanced the transportation of water molecules with smaller dynamic diameters of 0.27-0.32 nm. Larger filtrate particles including dye molecules or hydrated ions could only permeate through the gaps between the particles, or the boundary voids between the particles and the PSU substrates. In the formed PSF separating layer, water molecules should see a lot of short-cuts to pass through inside the ZIF-8 particulate crystalline bodies, while the filtrates dissolved in it would see a lot of impenetrable balls blocking their movements. Inclusion of non-porous particle or particles with larger internal channels would not have the same selective effects. As illustrated in Scheme 1, multiple dimensional pores were formed on the surfaces of ZIF/PSF MMMs embedded in and packed under situ grown ZIF particles, including capillary solvent absorbing pores from the PSF matrix with the diameters of dc (80-185 nm), MWCO Stokes solute rejecting pores between the ZIF particles with the gap diameters of dr (2.8-10.2 nm) and also internal water permeating pores of ZIF particles with the diameters of di (0.30-0.34 nm).
label: n

paragraph: As shown in Tables S-3, the longest dimension of dye molecules were in the range of 1.1-2.5 nm. Due to the existence of functional groups (-SO3-, and -NH2) in the dye molecular structures, Donan charge effects and agglomeration of dye molecules had caused their rejections by TUF membranes with larger MWCO Stokes solute rejecting pores of 2.8-10.2 nm. Therefore, ZIF particles embedded in and packed under the surface separating layers could promote water permeation and block solute permeation, so solute MWCO Stokes pore sizes were actually controlled by narrowest inter-particulate spaces of the embedded and packed ZIF particles. As shown in Fig. 5a and b, in-situ formed ZIF particles embedded in and packed under the separating layers had reduced capillary solvent filling diameters (dc) and solute rejection Stokes diameters (dr), and increased pore size distribution sharpness for TUF-326, resulting in improved dye rejection rates and retention selectivity over Na2SO4 (Fig. 5, Tables S-4).
label: n

paragraph: For comparison, TUF-020-d6 prepared using pre-made ZIF particles directly added in the casting solution had also shown reduced capillary absorption diameter (dc) and solute rejection diameters (dr), but with less peak sharpness. Directly added pre-made bulky ZIF-8 particles in the water of NIPS process may not be able to be effectively immobilized into the porous surfaces of formed PSF membranes while directly added bulky ZIF-8 particles in the organic phase casting solution could not migrate to the inter-phasal boundary areas during the NIPS process. They were mostly sealed inside the PSF matrix with limited open surface area and water permeating internal pores (Fig. 3d), leading to less water flux, dye rejection rates and retention selectivity (Fig. 5c and d) than TUF-326. Only in the in situ formation process could the hydrophilic 2MIM ligand molecules be migrated to and enriched in the inter-phasal boundary areas to form exposed ZIF-balls that were embedded in or packed under the newly formed PSF porous separating layers for superior filtration performance.
label: n

paragraph: As discussed above, in-situ formed ZIF particles embedded in and packed under the PSF separating layer could promote both water permeation and dye retention selectivity, which could be further optimized by adjusting the parameters of the NIPS processes, including the concentrations of PVP, 2MIM and Zn(II)as well as the NIPS reaction time. Following experiments were conducted to fully illustrated the effects.
label: n

paragraph: Membranes TUF-304, 314, 324 and 344 were prepared with the PVP loading in casting solution increased from 0, 1, 2-4 g/100 ml, respectively when the concentration of zinc nitrate hexahydrate pre-loading solution was kept at 30 g/L, the concentration of PSF was kept at 18 wt%, and the content of and 2MIM in casting solution was kept at 4 g/100 ml. From Fig. 8, it is clear that with the increase of the PVP content in the casting solution, capillary diameter (dc) (Fig. 8a, Tables S-8) peak value was increased from 79.6 to 107.5 nm with decreased peak sharpness. The particle sizes of ZIF-8 embedded and entrapped were kept between about 250 and 300 nm while the top skin thickness was kept in the range of 325-375 nm (Figs. 6-7).
label: n

paragraph: As shown in Fig. 7, the surface roughness was increased with improved hydrophilicity from more PVP loading. The water flux was gradually increased from 35.6 to 247.4 L/(m2*h) from TUF-304 to TUF-344 due to increased capillary pore sizes and surface hydrophilicity after the formation of more embedded ZIF particles. However, the solute rejection rates of the membranes were gradually decreased due to the enlarged solute rejection pore size (dr) and reduced pore distribution sharpness as shown in Fig. 8b. The retention selectivity between CR and Na2SO4 were greatly increased from 7 to 19 due to the faster reduction in Na2SO4 salt rejection rate. Balancing between the flux and rejection, PVP level was kept at 2 g/100 ml in casting solution to have maximize MO/Na2SO4 retention selectivity for further experiments.
label: n

paragraph: Membranes TUF-320, 322, 324 and 326 were prepared with 2MIM loading in casting solution increased from 0, 2, 4-6 g/100 ml when the concentration of zinc nitrate hexahydrate pre-loading solution was kept at 30 g/L, the concentration of PSF was kept at 18 wt%, and the content of and PVP in casting solution was kept at 2 g/100 ml. More ZIF-8 particles were formed from more 2MIM loaded, leading to improved surface hydrophilicity, decreased capillary pore diameter dc and MWCO Stokes solute rejection diameter dr, and no obvious changes on surface roughness (Figs. S6-7).
label: n

paragraph: The in-situ growing of the ZIF particles during the NIPS process involved the migration of Zn2+, from the PET NWF to the interphasal boundary and then reacted with the 2MIM released from the PSF casting solutions during NIPS processes. As discussed before, in-situ formed ZIF particles embedded in and packed under the surface separating layers had reduced PSF skin thickness and provided hydrophilic internal channels to promote water permeation. As expected, when the top skin PSF layer thickness was gradually reduced from 570, 476, 337 to 275 nm with more 2MIM loading, the water flux was increased from 105.2, 127.2, 197.5-247.4 L/(m2*h) (Fig. 9c). At the same time, the MWCO Stokes solute rejecting pore size (dr) was reduced from 14.6 to 9 nm) with increased distribution peak sharpness (Fig. 9b), leading to greatly improved dye rejection rates and retention selectivity over salts (Fig. 9c and d). The optimal concentration of 2MIM was selected at 4% when most of the Zn(II) released had been converted to ZIF particles and the retention selectivity of dyes/salt started to level off at this point as revealed in Fig. 9d.
label: n

paragraph: Membranes TUF-024, 324, 624 and 924 were prepared with the Zn(NO3)2*6H2O in pre-loaded solution increased from 0, 30, 60-90 g/100 ml, when the concentration of 2MIM, PSF and PVP was kept at 4, 18 and 2 g/100 ml in casting solution, respectively. As shown in Fig. S9, more Zn2+ had formed more ZIF-8 particles on the membrane surfaces as well as in the separating layers while the surface skin thickness was kept in the range of 300-500 nm. Surface roughness was increased with reduced water contact angles (Fig. S10).
label: n

paragraph: Pre-loaded Zn (II) salts had significantly increased capillary diameter (dc) due to the accelerated diffusion of aqueous phase into organic phase driven by co-ordination reaction of Zn(II) with PVP molecules during the NIPS process. Although the capillary solvent adsorption pore sizes was increased with more Zn(II) content, the MWCO Stokes pore size was decreased with improved distribution peak sharpness. The water flux was increased due to increased capillary pore sizes while dye/salt retention selectivity was decreased due to reduced Stokes pore size (Fig. 10).
label: n

paragraph: Membranes TUF-324 samples. were prepared with varied NIPS time from 15, 30, 45-60 min when Zn(NO3)2*6H2O in pre-loaded solution was kept at 30 g/100 ml, the concentration of 2MIM, PSF and PVP was kept at 4, 18 and 2 g/100 ml in casting solution, respectively. There is no significant change in membrane surface and cross-sectional images, PSF skin thickness, surface roughness and water contact angle (Figs. S12-13). Surface capillary diameter was slightly decreased with reduced distribution peak sharpness while its MWCO Stokes solute rejection diameter was decreased with increased peak distribution sharpness (Fig. S14). It is worth noting that a portion of ZIF-8 particles may have been lost during the sample preparation process, so the actual content may be more than observed in the cross-section images. Water flux was maximized at 45 min while the retention selectivity of dye/Na2SO4 was maximized at 30 min of NIPS time (Fig. 11). The best NIPS reaction time should be controlled from 30 to 45 min.
label: n

paragraph: To test the operational efficiency of TUF membranes, the performance of TUF-324 and TUF-020 were compared in the dye/salt separation experiments using 1 L solutions containing 0.1 g of CR and 1.0 g of Na2SO4 in the same mixture. The water permeance of TUF-324 was maintained in the range of 157.4 to 148.2 L/(m2 h bar), about 7 times higher than those (23.5-19.6 L/(m2 h bar)) of TUF-020. TUF-324 also showed much higher CR/Na2SO4 retention selectivity of 15-16 than those of TUF-020. TUF-324 also showed higher anti-fouling capacity than TUF-020 with less CR rejection decay over time (Fig. 12).
label: n

paragraph: By comparing the filtration performance in this work with those reported in the literature, it is clear that ZIF/PSF TUF membranes with in-situ grown ZIF particles, TUF-326, 324, 624 and 924, had broken the Roberson trade-off outer bound between water permeance and retention selectivity (S) for CR/Na2SO4 [33-37], MO/Na2SO4 [38-42], MBe/Na2SO4 [38,39,43-45], bearing high potential to be used in recycling and purifying dyes for dye and textile industries (Fig. 13).
label: n

paragraph: A new strategy has been developed to prepared ZIF/PSF TUF membranes with ultra-high water permeance and improved dye/salt retention selectivity involving in-situ grown ZIF particles during the NIPS process that embedded in and packed under the thinned PSF skin layers.
label: n

paragraph: More PVP loading in the casting solution increased capillary pore diameter (dc), Stokes solute rejection pore diameters (dr), surface roughness and hydrophilicity, resulting in increased water permeance and dye/salt retention selectivity, and decreased solute rejection rates. More 2MIM loading in the casting solution increased ZIF particle formation, improved surface hydrophilicity, reduced PSF skin thickness, capillary diameters and Stokes solute rejection diameters, leading to increased water flux, dye rejection rates and retention selectivity over salts. More Zn2+ formed more ZIF-8 particles, leading to higher surface roughness and reduced water contact angles, as well as increased water flux and decreased dye/salt retention selectivity. More reaction time led to decreased solute rejection diameter. Water flux was maximized at 45 min reaction time while the retention selectivity of dye/Na2SO4 was maximized at 30 min.
label: n

paragraph: With thinned PSF separating layer (200-500 nm) and embedding water permeating short-cuts from the ZIF particles, ZIF/PSF TUF membranes showed greatly increased water permeance, up to 250 L/(m2 h bar), and increased rejection rates (30-99%) for dyes and dye/salt retention selectivity, bearing high potential for applications in dye and textile waste water treatment processes.
label: n

Congjie Gao: Reviewing. Xue lixin: Draft writing, conceptualization, visualization, reviewing and editing, supervising.

paragraph: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.memsci.2022.121136.
label: n

paragraph: In the early 1980s, nanofiltration (NF) membranes were first introduced with several promising characteristics between ultrafiltration (UF) and reverse osmosis (RO) [1]. In recent decades, Nanofiltration (NF) has become the center of attention in separation and purification of aqueous and non-aqueous mixtures several applications including food, pharmaceutical, biotechnology, and petrochemical industries, possessing the several advantages including flexible operation, low energy consumption, cost-efficiency and compactness of design [2-4]. It is noteworthy that the retention of dyes from water is considered as one of the largest applications in which nanofiltration membranes are utilized [5,6]. However, developing new membrane materials and exploring facile membrane fabrication methods, which are considered as the determining factors for the performance of the final membrane, are still required in this field [7,8].
label: n

paragraph: In the phase inversion method, the mixture of polymer and its solvent are brought to instability through several means, including: non-solvent-induced phase separation (NIPS), temperature-induced phase separation (TIPS) or vapor-induced phase separation (VIPS). So far, the NIPS process has been widely used to fabricate polymeric membranes, including reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration, microfiltration and MD [9,10]. Nonetheless, the membranes fabricated by using this technique are comprised of an asymmetrical structure with macro-voids [11], which is regarded as a drawback in this field. Accordingly, the VIPS technique can be utilized as a promising alternative to address the issues shown by the NIPS one. In the VIPS method, before the immersion of the membrane into the coagulation bath, the spread polymer solution is exposed to a non-solvent vapor environment, which is generally humid air, for a certain time. It is worth pointing out that the mass transfer of water is slow from the vapor phase to casting solution when the membrane is exposed to the vapor environment, leading to the formation of a uniform spongy architecture in the membrane structure with no macro-voids [12-14]. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that, through controlling the fabrication conditions, including exposure time and relative humidity, the membrane morphology can be controlled [15]. For instance, Su et al. reported the fabrication of polysulfone membranes by the VIPS method, based on which it was demonstrated that the membrane morphology changed from the bi-continuous structure to the cellular one with longer exposure time [16].
label: n

paragraph: Through combining the above-mentioned methods, the formation of pin-holes on the dense layer, which deteriorates the selectivity of the membrane, can be successfully avoided [17]. Accordingly, coupled VIPS-NIPS methods have been also utilized as a promising approach for the fabrication of membranes [18]. In this approach, a preliminary stage, in which the nascent film is first exposed to fixed humid air, precedes the immersion in the coagulation bath. It is well-known that in these kinds of systems, the non-solvent is usually water, and therefore, by the water vapor transfer, the phase separation is promoted. The moist air takes an important part for the polymer precipitation, subsequently accomplished in the non-solvent bath.
label: n

paragraph: In recent years, Polysulfone (PSF) has been among the commonly utilized membrane materials, arising from its excellent properties including good mechanical, chemical and thermal stabilities along with excellent film-forming properties. Accordingly, Polysulfone is widely utilized for the fabrication of porous microfiltration (MF), ultrafiltration (UF) and nanofiltration (NF) membranes [19,20]. Nonetheless, in spite of all the above-mentioned merits, Polysulfone membranes suffer from the tendency to be contaminated because of their hydrophobicity, which leads to declining of flux and lifespan of the fabricated membrane [21]. It has been demonstrated that the formation of mixed matrix membranes (MMM) can result in an enhancement in the permeance and selectivity of polymeric membranes [22].
label: n

paragraph: Mixed matrix membranes are fabricated through embedding inorganic fillers, such as zeolites, CNTs, SiO2, etc. in a polymer matrix, which provides a preferential flow path for the target species [2]. Nonetheless, if defects present at the filler/polymer interface are removed, they might overcome the tradeoff between membrane permeability and selectivity [23]. In recent years, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted numerous attention as a promising alternative to inorganic fillers utilized in MMMs [24]. MOFs are a class of hybrid inorganic-organic solid compounds which are made up of continuous bonding of transition metals and transition metal oxides with organic ligands, forming 1-D, 2-D, or 3-D porous structures [25]. MOFs can provide a variety of excellent properties including flexible structure, high surface area, controlled porosity, tunable chemical composition, functionalizable pore walls, excellent chemical, structural and thermal stability, and affinity for certain molecules [26]. It is worth pointing out that the organic linkage existing in the MOFs architecture is capable of providing a superior affinity for polymeric matrices when compared to the above-mentioned inorganic fillers, which is much easier to control MOF-polymer interactions. Hence, the formation of nonselective defects at the filler/polymer interface can be successfully prevented [27]. For instance, Basu et al. reported that, by incorporating modified MOFs into a matrix of polydimethylsiloxane membrane supported on polyimide, dye rejection can be considerably enhanced, while no considerable changes is observed in the permeance [28]. In another research work, Dai et al. fabricated defect-free polyphenylsulfone/ZIF-8 core-shell microsphere membranes, in which the MOF microspheres not only prevented the formation of nonselective defects but also enhanced the SRNF performance of polyphenylsulfone membranes [29].
label: n

paragraph: In this study, VIPS-NIPS method was utilized for the fabrication of a MIL-53(Al)-polysulfone mixed matrix membrane by using 1,4-Dioxane as the co-solvent. MIL-53(Al) was used in this research work as the MOF because of not only excellent water stability at room temperature but also small pore size [2]. Accordingly, different membrane compositions with various amounts of MIL-53(Al) were fabricated in order to achieve a membrane with superior performance for dye rejection application. Then, the rejection of different dyes, including Reactive Red (RR), Methyl Green (MG), Crystal Violet (CV), Direct Yellow (DY), Methylene Blue (MB), was investigated by the prepared membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Commercial polysulfone (PSf) with molecular weight of 35,000 g.mol-1 (Ultrason(r) 6010P) was supplied by BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany). Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), Al(NO3)3*9H2O (99.99%) and 1,4-dioxane were purchased from Merck Co. Ltd. (Darmstadt, Germany). The dyes including Reactive red, Direct yellow, Methyl green and crystal violet were all supplied by Sigma-Aldrich Co.
label: y

paragraph: The hydrothermally synthesis of MIL-53 (Al) was conducted according to the literature [30]. Accordingly, in the first step, Al(NO3)3*9H2O, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid and DI water were mixed together with a molar ratio of 2:1:160. Subsequently, the as-prepared mixture was placed into a Teflon lined steel autoclave at the temperature of 220 degC for 72 h. After the accomplishment of the reaction, the steel autoclave was gradually cooled down to room temperature (RT). In the next step, a white product with the yield of 97%, based on the organic ligand, was achieved by centrifugation, followed via washing with DI water and drying in a vacuum oven at RT. Finally, the elimination of the excessive 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid which had been adsorbed in the pores was done by using heat treatment at 320 degC for 72 h in air.
label: y

paragraph: The PSf membranes were prepared by using vapor-induced phase inversion (VIPS) method coupled with non-solvent-induced phase inversion (NIPS) technique (VIPS-NIPS). It is well-known that the addition of a volatile co-solvent into the polymer solution along with applying an evaporation step before immersing the as-cast films into a coagulation bath have been reported for the successfully formation of integrally skinned asymmetric membranes [30]. Hence, a mixture of DMF, as the solvent, and 1,4-dioxane, as the volatile co-solvent, at a 3:1 wt ratio was utilized in this study for the fabrication of dope solutions. Accordingly, precise amounts of MIL-53(Al) were first added into the DMF/1,4-dioxane mixtures, followed by sonication for 180 min in order to prepare homogeneous dispersions. In the next step, PSf with a concentration of 18 wt% was added into the as-prepared dispersions, and completely dissolved after continuously stirring at RT for 2 days. The MIL-53(Al) loading in the final dopes varied from 0 to 7 mg/g of MIL-53(Al) (i.e. 0, 1, 3, 5 and 7 mg/g). The homogenous polymer solution was de-aerated by using a vacuum process for 120 min and cast on a glass plate in a climatic box (relative humidity of 65 +- 5% and temperature 40 degC) by using a Doctor Blade device with a gap of 200 um. Only the MNIPS sample was formed by the NIPS process, and the other membranes were formed by the VIPS-NIPS method. By the coagulation step, the fabricated PSf membranes were separated from the glass plate. The fabricated membranes were stored in a soaking bath containing DI water for 1 day for the complete elimination of the residual solvent, followed by drying at RT. The fabricated MMMs were labelled as M0, M1, M2, M3 and M4, according to the weight percentage of MIL-53(Al). The neat PSf membrane with 0 wt% of MIL-53(Al) was fabricated as the neat membrane and was labelled as M0. Furthermore, to draw a comparison, a membrane was also fabricated by the NIPS method, labelled as MNIPS. The compositions of the casting solutions are exhibited in Table 1.
label: y

paragraph: In this study, by using a self-made dead-end filtration apparatus, the water flux and dyes rejection of all the fabricated membranes were measured. A feed including a 30 ppm dye aqueous solution (Table 2) was added to the filtration apparatus and pushed to permeate through the fabricated membrane (effective surface area of 7 cm2) under the pressure of 5 bar. The experiments were conducted at 25 degC. Finally, data were measured via the following equations:(1)F=VAxt(2)R=CF-CPCFx100%In equation (1), F corresponds to the water flux (L/m2.h), A denotes the effective surface area of the prepared membranes (m2), V is ascribed to the permeate volume (L), and t is related to the interval of the test time (h). In equation (2), R denotes the rejection (%), and Cf and Cp are related to the feed and permeate solution concentrations which were determined via UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Pharo 300, Merck).
label: n

paragraph: The X-ray diffraction patterns of the fabricated membranes were collected by using a Philips PW1730 spectrometer with a Cu-Ka radiation source in the region of 2 from 5deg to 50deg. The EDS, SEM mapping (detector: Oxford Instrument), and surface and cross sectional morphology of the fabricated membranes were investigated by using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), SIGMA VP, ZEISS, Germany. AFM analysis, NT-MDT, operating in a semi contact mode, was utilized in order to investigate the surface morphology of the fabricated membranes. Static water contact angle (WCA) test was also conducted by using Dataphysics, OCA 15 plus, to study the hydrophilic nature of the surface of the fabricated membranes. Attenuated Total Reflection-Fourier Transform Infrared spectrometer (ATR-FTIR, Avatar 370, Thermo), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; ESCA 2000, MultiLab) analyses were also conducted to investigate the changes in chemical structure of the membranes after each step. The loading amount of MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles was investigated through evaluating the loading amount of Al elements via inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Varian Vista-MPX. Accordingly, 1 cm2 of the prepared membranes was dissolved in 2 ml of aqua regia (1.5 ml HCl/0.5 ml HNO3) at 100 degC for 6 h, followed by diluting with DI water in order to reduce the acid concentration to <= 10% (v/v).
label: n

paragraph: The FTIR spectrum related to MIL-53 (Al) and all the prepared membranes are exhibited in Fig. 1. It is obvious in the spectrum of neat PSf that two strong absorptions have been emerged at 1489 and 1575 cm-1, related to the aromatic vibrational bonding of C = C in the PSf backbone. Additionally, the strong absorption peak present at about 1151 cm-1 is also attributed to the vibrational bonding of O = S = O in the PSf backbone. The absorption peak emerged at 1229 cm-1 also corresponds to the vibrational bonding of C-O-C in the ether group. Furthermore, the peak observed at 3049 cm-1 is also related to the vibrational bonding of = C-H in the aromatic ring of PSf backbone, and the two strong absorption bands appeared at about 1301 and 1318 cm-1 also shows the vibrational region of the sulfone group [31]. It can be discerned in the spectra of the membranes possessing MIL-53 (Al) that a new peak has appeared at 1665 cm-1 which is related to the vibration of carboxylic functional groups, indicating the presence of MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles in the prepared mixed matrix membranes [32].
label: n

paragraph: The elemental analysis was carried out on the surface of the MNIPS, M0, M1, M2, M3, M4 samples to evaluate the changes in the chemical composition of the fabricated membranes, as shown in Fig. 2. It is easily discernible that, after the addition of MIL-53 (Al) to the membranes matrix, the Al element has been detected by this analysis, demonstrating the successful introduction of MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles to the PSF matrix in the M1, M2, M3, M4 samples.
label: n

paragraph: The loading amount of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles was studied by evaluating the loading amount of Al elements via ICP-OES analysis. Based on the obtained results, the Al loading amounts were assessed at 0.04, 0.136, 0.232, and 0.329 mg/cm2 corresponding to M1, M2, M3, and M4 samples, respectively, demonstrating that high amounts of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles have been loaded in the membrane matrixes.
label: n

paragraph: X-ray diffraction analysis was conducted to evaluate the crystalline structure of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles and the prepared mixed matrix membranes (Fig. 3). It is discernible in this Figure that the corresponding peaks of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles, emerged at 2th = 8.4deg, 10.7deg, 15.5deg, 18.4deg, 21.1deg and 26.1deg [33], are almost unchanged in the fabricated mixed matrix membranes, demonstrating that the crystalline morphology and phase purity of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles are also maintained in the mixed matrix membranes.
label: n

paragraph: XPS analysis was also performed to demonstrate the incorporation of MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles into the M2 membrane matrix, as depicted in Fig. 4. The survey XPS spectrum of the M2 membrane not only shows the presence of Al elements, which are not observed in the survey XPS spectrum of the M0 membrane, but also exhibits the O 1 s peak with a higher intensity when compared to that of the M0 membrane. All these findings demonstrate the successful incorporation of MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles into the MMMs.
label: n

paragraph: The SEM images of the fabricated membranes surface are exhibited in Fig. 5. It is obvious that a dense skin layer has been formed on the top surface of the membranes. Moreover, the presence of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles is easily discernable on the surface of the M1, M2, M3, M4 samples with two different structures of sphere-like and rod-like. It can be confirmed that the more the amount of MIL-53(Al) nanoparticles has increased in the composition of the membranes, the more the structure the nanoparticles has shifted from sphere-like to rod-like.
label: n

paragraph: Cross-sectional SEM images of all the fabricated membranes are exhibited in Fig. 6. It is obvious in low-magnification images that an asymmetric morphology with finger-like structures has been formed in the architecture of the prepared membranes, arising from the use of high DMF concentration in the dope solution [31]. Furthermore, it is easily discernable in high-magnification images that an open cellular spongy morphology has been formed in the structure of the membranes prepared by the VIPS-NIPS method, i.e. M0, M1, M2, M3, M4 samples. It is well-known that, in the VIPS-NIPS approach, a slower absorption of water molecules takes place when compared to the NIPS one, which delays the phase inversion procedure, and consecutively, leads to the generation of a sponge-like morphology [34].
label: n

paragraph: By drawing a comparison between the untreated membrane (M0) and the other membranes prepared via the VIPS-NIPS method (M1, M2, M3, M4), it seems that the size of the cells firstly increases and then decreases for M3 and M4 samples, based on which it can be concluded that the phase separation is initially faster and then slows down [35]. Through the addition of MIL-53(Al), an enhancement in the solvent diffusion velocity from the polymer matrix takes place, arising from the decrease in the interactions between the polymer chains and solvent molecules through the hindrance effect of the introduced nanofillers [36]. Nevertheless, it is worth pointing out that the viscosity of the polymer casting solution increases by the increasing the MIL-53(Al) content, by which the diffusion of water molecules through the polymer matrix is slowed down. The reason for this observation is that the increased viscosity of the casting solution plays the role of a physical roadblock for the mass transfer between non-solvent and solvent, resulting in a delayed demixing throughout the membrane formation procedure [2].
label: n

paragraph: The surface roughness of the MNIPS, M0, M1, M2, M3, M4 samples was studied by using AFM analysis at a scan size of 5 mm x 5 mm, as depicted in Fig. 7 and listed in Table 3. It is obvious that Ra increases from 4.89 nm (M0 membrane) to 8.36 nm (M1 membrane), 11.41 nm (M2 membrane), 17.36 nm (M3 membrane) to 22.23 nm (M4 membrane). It was confirmed by AFM analysis that the roughness of the membranes surface have increased by introducing MIL-53(Al) to the membrane matrix. Furthermore, it is worth pointing out that the more the MIL-53(Al) content increased in the membrane matrix, the more the roughness increased. The "valleys" in the rough membrane surface lead to an improvement in the contact area, and therefore, enhances the water flux [37,38]. The data are in accordance with the water permeability of the fabricated membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Contact angle analysis was conducted to study the surface hydrophilicity of the prepared membranes, as exhibited in Fig. 8. It is well-known that the higher contact angle, the lower surface hydrophilic nature [39,40]. Accordingly, it is discernable that both of the untreated membranes, i.e. MNIPS and M0, have the highest contact angles among all the prepared membranes, demonstrating the hydrophobic nature of the surface of the untreated membranes. However, after the addition of MIL-53(Al), it can be seen that the contact angles of the treated membranes have decreased. The more MIL-53(Al) was added to the matrix of the treated membranes, the more contact angles decreased, confirming the improvement in the surface hydrophilicity of the treated membranes. Several membrane batches were prepared in order to evaluate repeatability, as represented in Table 4 (See Fig. 9.).
label: n

paragraph: The investigation of water Flux and dyes rejection performance of all the membranes was carried out in terms of the removal ability of MG, DY, CV and MB in an aqueous solution (Fig. 7). The membrane fabricated by the NIPS (MNIPS) method provided a much lower rejection ability when compared to the membrane prepared via the VIPS-NIPS (M0). Furthermore, it was found that the M2 membrane sample could provide the highest rejection ability among all the prepared membranes. It is also noteworthy that the M2 membrane sample provided the highest rejection ability for MG, with the highest molecular weight, and the lowest rejection ability for MB, with the lowest molecular weight. Additionally, water Flux of the M0, M1, M2, M3 and M4 membranes followed the order of M0 < M1 < M2 < M3 < M4, which can be attributed to the MIL-53 (Al) content in these membranes. The effect of MIL-53 (Al) on rejection and water Flux performance of the prepared membranes is schematically represented in Scheme 1. MIL-53 (Al) has proved to be a superb candidate filler for MMMs in aqueous solutions because of its permanent porosity, and great structural stability. The ordered porous structure and intensive hydrophilic surface of MOFs are essential for both the high dye rejection and the high-flux, because the homogeneously dispersed nanoparticles in a polymer matrix is able to provide additional small water passages along with an increase in the effective contact area of the prepared MMM to facilitate the channel of water molecules [27,41]. Moreover, the M0 membrane sample exhibited a slightly lower water Flux than that of the MNIPS sample, which can be attributed to its higher contact angle and denser top layer, which is in accordance with the literature [42]. Several membrane batches were fabricated to study repeatability, as listed in Table 4 (See Fig. 10.).
label: n

paragraph: It is evident in Fig. 11 that Almost an enhancement has been achieved in the permeate flux through the incorporation of nanoparticles in the M2 membrane. All these experimental results confirm that the antifouling performance of the prepared M2 mixed matrix membrane has been considerably improved as a result of the incorporation of MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles, resulting in exhibiting negligible changes in Flux through passing time. This enhancement can be originated from the effect of the incorporated MIL-53 (Al) nanoparticles in enhancing permeation pathways for water.
label: n

paragraph: Long-term durability of the prepared M2 membrane was carried out to investigate the flux and dye rejection ability of the membrane through running the experiments for ten days, as exhibited in Fig. 8. It was found that the M2 membrane had an outstanding performance in the rejection of the dyes utilized in this study for long periods. Even though flux has continuously declined because of dilution and fouling effect, the dye rejection showed negligible changes after ten days. This demonstrated that the M2 mixed matrix membrane performance, in terms of dye rejection, did not deteriorate by passing time.
label: n

paragraph: Comparison of nanofiltration membranes reported by other articles and the M2 sample prepared in this study is listed in Table 5, based on which it can be strongly confirmed that the membrane prepared in our work has a superior performance.
label: n

paragraph: In this study, a combination of two different methods, i.e. VIPS and NIPS techniques, were used for the preparation of polysulfone-MIL-53(Al) mixed matrix membranes. Because of possessing small pore sizes, hydrophilic nature and excellent water stability, we decided to introduce the MIL-53(Al) nanoparticle into the polysulfone membrane matrix and investigate its effects on the Flux performance and dyes rejection ability of the final mixed matrix membranes. Accordingly, various membrane compositions with different MIL-53(Al) weight percentages were prepared. It was found that the membrane with 0.06 wt% of MIL-53(Al) provided the highest rejection performance for all the dyes utilized in this study along with a suitable Flux, demonstrating its promising properties in this field.
label: n
