label: n

paragraph: Thin-film composite (TFC) membranes have been extensively applied in nanofiltration (NF), reverse osmosis (RO) and forward osmosis (FO) owing to their excellent selectivity, high permeability and energy efficiency [1]. A TFC membrane has a thin selective layer on the support membrane which is composed of non-woven fabrics (NWFs) substrate layer and porous support layer. Generally, the performance of the TFC membrane could be influenced by regulating the membrane structure, the physicochemical properties and the special function of different layers. Numerous studies are focused on the selective layer owing to its decisive effect on the performance of TFC membranes [2,3]. However, the porous support layer and the NWFs can regulate the transport pathway of water and solutes through the membrane [4-6], which also affects the performance of TFC membrane [7,8]. With good mechanical strength, acid and alkali resistance and chemical stability [9], polysulfone (PSf) membranes which are fabricated by non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS) method have been preferred chosen as support layer in many commercial TFC membranes [10-12]. The pore structure and morphologies of PSf membranes formed via NIPS are classified as finger-like pores and sponge-like pores, which are mainly influenced by liquid-liquid and solid-liquid phase separation or polymer precipitation rates [13-15]. In general, the delayed phase separation produces membranes with "sponge-like" structure, while transient phase separation produces membranes with large "finger-like" substructure [16-18]. Additionally, several studies have shown that an ideal support layer with thin sponge-like structure was much more beneficial in designing high-performance TFC membranes due to its withstand high pressures [19]. As known, the support membrane with finger-like structure, similar to other porous ultrafiltration (UF) membranes, had poor pressure resistance and can only suffer low pressure (~0.2 MPa) [20], which greatly limited its application in pressure separation, especially in NF or RO application. However, the support membrane with sponge-like structure exhibited better compressive performance and breaking strength than that of the membrane with finger-like pore structure, which was beneficial to be used as the support layer of NF or RO membranes [21,22]. Therefore, it was necessary to prepare sponge-like structure PSf membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Currently, the research of the formation and morphology of support layer mainly focuses on the composition of casting solution [23-25], the composition and conditions of coagulation bath and the non-solvent additives [26], etc. Ismail [24] and Wang [25] et al. systematically investigated the influence of PSf concentration on the membrane structure. It was reported that higher PSf concentrations increased the viscosity of the system, resulting in longer phase separation times and gelation times. The thickness of the prepared PSf membrane increased, the skin structure was dense, and the membrane permeability was correspondingly reduced. Ali [27] et al. added ethanol to the coagulation bath to slow down the entry of non-solvents into the casting solution while preparing the PES support layer for NF membrane. Both the polymer precipitation and retarded phase separation were slowed down, which eventually resulted in the formation of sponge-like pores. Blanco [28] et al. studied the effects of coagulation bath temperature on the morphology of the PSF + SPSF co-blends supporting layer in NF membranes. It was found that the size and numbers of the finger-like pore structure increased as the coagulation bath temperature declined as the result of a lower diffusion of non-solvent in and solvent out. As a non-solvent additive, polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) played an important role in the thermodynamic and kinetic characteristics of the PSf casting solution, especially for its generated membrane structure. Han [26] et al. found that the viscosity of the casting solution raised significantly as the PVP content increased (PVP mass fraction >20%), leading to a lower rate of solvent/non-solvent exchange, which delayed the phase separation of the casting solution and inhibited the macro-porous structure of the membrane. Although extensive studies have focused on preparing PSf membranes with various structures, the influence of different fabrication parameters for PSf support layer with sponge-like structure is not systematically studied.
label: n

paragraph: Additionally, the structure and performance of porous support membranes are also influenced by different materials and properties of the NWFs substrate layer. Sairam [29] et al. used nylon woven fabric to prepare FO membrane. The results indicated that the coating solution penetrated into the fabric to form a defected low permeability cellulose acetate (CA) membrane. Conversely, a dense nonwoven could lead to a lower adhesion between the polymer and the fabric layer resulting in membrane delamination and defects. Goettmann [30] et al. found that using dense fabric in the film-forming process would lead to the delamination of the polymer layer. Additionally, Vilakati [31] et al. used two different materials NWFs of polyester and polyphenylenesulphide as supports to prepare TFC membranes, and they found that pure water fluxes (PWF) and NaCl rejections of the TFC membranes were affected by different NWFs materials. Tang [32] et al. systematically investigated the influence of fabrics properties on the morphologies and separation performance of the PSf membrane. The results indicated that PSf casting solution was easily infiltrated into the NWFs pores with low fiber density, which reduced the thickness of the PSf layer, widened the finger-like pore structure, and increased the permeation flux. Recently, Wang [33] et al. used two kinds of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) NWFs with different thicknesses to study their effects on the performance of the PVDF-gPEGMA UF membranes. They found that the PVDF membranes using thin PET fabrics had higher PWF than that with thick PET fabrics, which was attributed to the thinner and higher porosity of the PET fabric. To summarize, the polymer, the phase transformation conditions, the fabric characteristics and the interaction between these properties must be considered in the membrane-forming process. However, to the best of our knowledge, few studies were focused on fabricating PSf membrane with sponge-like structure via changing PET substrates with different properties. Herein, the fabrication parameters, the fabric support properties and their influencing mechanism must be taken into account in the preparation of PSf membrane with sponge-like structure.
label: n

paragraph: In this work, PSf porous support membranes were prepared via NIPS method, and three different PET NWFs were selected as the substrate layer. The morphologies of the support membranes were adjusted by changing the coagulation bath temperature, pre-evaporation time, relative humidity and scraping membrane thickness. Then, the effects of the PET NWFs properties on the sponge pore support membranes were investigated. Finally, the optimal fabricating parameters and the PET NWFs fabric were confirmed with the PWF, BSA rejection and anti-fouling of the PSf membrane. This work may provide a reference for optimizing the support membrane structure and selecting the PET NWFs substrate layers to fabricate TFC membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Three kinds of PET NWFs named as NWF-01, NWF-02 and NWF-03 (PET, Hirose Co., Japan) were purchased for support fabrication. Commercial HT PSf ultrafiltration membrane named as PSf-HT were pruchased from VONTR (PSf, Beijing VONTRON Co., LTD, China).
label: y

paragraph: Polysulfone (PSf, P-3500 LCD MB7, Mw = 77,000-83,000 g/mol, Solvay, Belgium) was chosen to fabricate the membrane. N, N-dimethyl acetamide (DMAc, Mw = 87.12 g/mol, Peking Reagent, China) was used as the solvent and polyethylene glycol (PEG, Mw = 400 g/mol, MERYER, China) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, Mw = 8000 g/mol, Innochem, China) were used as the additive in the casting solution. Deionized (DI) water was obtained using a Merck Mili-Q purification system among the whole experiment. Bovine serum albumin (BSA, Mw = 67,000 g/mol, Macklin, China) dissolved in phosphate buffer (pH = 7.0-7.2) was used to evaluate membrane rejection. The concentration of BSA in the solution was 1000 ppm. All reagents were utilized directly without further treatment.
label: y

paragraph: The casting solution was composed of 19 wt% PSf, 7 wt% PEG, 0.5 wt% PVP and 73.5 wt% DMAc which were filled into a 500 mL flask. Then, the flask was heated to 95 degC by an oil bath. The homogenous casting solution was obtained after continuous stirring for 7 h at 2600 rpm (DF-101S Collective thermostatic heating magnetic stirrer, Shanghai Zhenjie Experimental Equipment Co., China). Lastly, the resulting casting solution was put into a vacuum oven at 25 degC for at least 24 h.
label: y

paragraph: PSf support membranes were prepared via NIPS method. NWFs were attached to the steel plate and then the dope solution was casted uniformly by an automatic film applicator (Elcometer 4340 Automatic Film Applicator, Elcometer Co., England) with a steel knife. The relative humidity was determined by adjusting the intensity of automatic humidifier (SC-3K40 air humidifier, Midea Group, China) and using indoor humidity measuring instrument (LondiSun LS-207 electronic moisture meter, Shanghai Diyi Zhan Trading Co., China). The nascent membranes were exposed to atmosphere for several seconds and then soaked into the coagulating bath with different temperature for 30 min to proceed the phase inversion. The prepared membranes were kept in DI water before test. The PSf membranes formed on three different PET NWFs (NWF-01, NWF-02 and NWF-03) were denoted as PSf-NWF-01, PSf-NWF-02, and PSf-NWF-03 membranes, respectively.
label: y

paragraph: The PWF and BSA rejection (R) of the PSf membranes were assessed by the dead-end filtering device (HP4750 Stirred Cell, pcsr-tech). The PSf membranes were pre-pressurized with DI water at 0.2 MPa for 0.5 h before being tested. The rejection of PSf membrane was measured by 1000 ppm BSA feed solution at 0.10 MPa under room temperature. The PWF (J, L/(m2*h)) and BSA rejection (R, %) of the PSf membranes were calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2)[34]:(1)J=VAxDt(2)R=(1-cpcf)x100%where V (L) is the volume of permeated water over a certain period of time Dt (h)at different pressure, A (m2) is the effective membrane area (14.6 cm2). CF and CP are the BSA concentrations in the feed and permeate, respectively, which were measured by UV-visible spectrophotometer (TU-1810, Beijing Puxi, China) at the wavelength of 280 nm [35].
label: n

paragraph: To access the anti-fouling performance of the PSF membranes, 1000 ppm BSA solution was used as the evaluation system for filtration tests. The BSA flux was recorded every 15 min during continuous filtration at 0.2 MPa for 2 h. Normalized flux (J/J0) was used to represent the extent of membrane fouling, where J and J0 were the BSA flux at a certain time and initial BSA flux, respectively. Theoretically, a high value of normalized flux indicated a low level of membrane fouling.
label: n

paragraph: The membranes were soaked in dilute NaOH solution (0.4 g/L) for 12 h after BSA filtration for 2 h. The PWF (Jw) of the cleaned membrane was measured again and the flux recovery rate (FRR) of the membranes was measured using Eq. (3):(3)FRR=Jw1Jwwhere Jw1 and Jw represent PWF of the membrane before and after BSA solution filtration, respectively. In general, membrane fouling includes reversible fouling (Rr) and irreversible fouling (Rir). Rr was caused by concentration polarization and the formation of a gel layer on the membrane surface, while Rir was caused by adsorption on the membrane pore surface [36]. Rr and Rir can be calculated as follows:(4)Rr=Jw1-JpJwx100%(5)Rir=Jw-Jw1Jwx100%where Jp is the BSA solution flux of the membrane, expressed in L/(m2*h).
label: n

paragraph: The chemical compositions of the PSf membranes were determined by a Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) which was configured with a Nicolet 6700 Spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific Corporation, USA).
label: n

paragraph: The morphologies of the PET NWFs and PSf membranes were obtained by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-7401, Tokyo, Japan) under an accelerating voltage of 3 kV. Samples were kept in the drying oven at 60 degC at least 2 h before sputter-coated with platinum. Samples were pretreated and fractured in liquid nitrogen before observing its cross-sectional morphologies.
label: n

paragraph: The water contact angles (WCAs) of PET NWFs and PSf membranes were measured by an optical contact angle goniometer (OCA20, Data physics Co., Ltd., Germany) which was set to the sessile drop method. Both static and dynamic WCAs for the samples were measured at least 5 times [31].
label: n

paragraph: In order to reduce the influence of physical forces and chemical agents on the structure of PSf membrane, the characterization of PET NWFs and PSf membrane were measured together as a whole. Firstly, the samples were immersed in DI water for 48 h and weighed after brushing off water on the surface. Then the wet samples were dried in an oven at 60 degC for 24 h and weighed again. The weight and effective area of samples should be recorded. The porosity (e) of PET NWFs and PSf membranes was determined by Eq.(6)[37,38]:(6)e=Ww-WdrAsx100%
label: n

paragraph: The tortuosity (t) of the fabric was calculated by Archie's law basing on the e measurements and evaluated by Eq. (7) as follows [39],(7)t=1e0.3where Ww and Wd(g) are the weights of the wet and dry samples, respectively. r, A(cm2) and d(mm) are the water density (1.0 x 103 kg/m3), effective area and the thickness of the wet samples, respectively. Additionally, the surface mean pore size and porosity (es) of PSf membranes were analyzed by ImageJ software through SEM images [35,40].
label: n

paragraph: The physical property parameters of PET NWFs were measured and calculated to study the effect on the performance of PSf membranes. The structure parameter (S) is the average distance of molecules passing through the support layer from the bulk solution, or the barrier diffusion path caused by the membrane structure, which is defined as [41],(8)S=KD=tstewhere K, D, ts, t and e are the resistance to solute diffusion, the solute diffusivity, the thickness of the support, the tortuosity and the bulk porosity of the PET NWFs and PSf membrane, respectively [19].
label: n

paragraph: Furthermore, the pore size of the PET NWFs is calculated by the Hagen-Poiseuille model using the air permeability. And the permeability(Lp) can be determined by.(9)Lp=erp28mttswhere rp and m are the pore radius and the viscosity of air at 20 degC, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: Exploring the interaction forces between the polymer, coagulant and PET NWFs provides a better understanding of how the PET NWFs affect the formation of the membrane. The uptake of the polymer solution by the fabric can be judged by capillary pressure. The Young-Laplace equation is taken to calculate the capillary pressure (pc) in the pores of the fabric [42],(10)pc=2gLcosthcrp
label: n

paragraph: Positive capillary pressure states that the PET NWFs pull the polymer solution into the pores spaces interstitial spaces, leading to a high adhesion between PET NWFs and the PSf layer. Conversely, the negative capillary pressure reveals that the polymer solution is excluded from the interstitial spaces to the PET NWFs surface causing a low adhesion between the two layers. Additionally, the solid-liquid interfacial energy (-DGSL) is determined by [31].(11)-DGSL=gL[1+costhc]where gL is the liquid surface tension for pure water (72.8 mJ/m2) at 20 degC [43,44]. The larger value of -DGSL, the higher interaction energy between the surface and the liquid [31].
label: n

paragraph: Initially, NWF-02 fabric was chosen to prepare the PSf support membrane. The effects of membrane fabrication parameters (such as coagulation bath temperature, relative humidity, pre-evaporation time, and membrane thickness) on the membrane structure were discussed. Relatively uniform membrane preparation conditions would be obtained eventually for preparing PSf support membrane with sponge-like pores.
label: n

paragraph: The effects of different coagulation bath temperatures (set at 25 degC, 40 degC, 50 degC and 60 degC) on the surface and cross-sectional structure of PSf membrane prepared by NIPS were investigated in this section. The membrane fabrication parameters of relative humidity, pre-evaporation time and membrane thickness were fixed as 20%, 30 s and 60 mm, respectively. As shown in Fig. 1, the pore size of the membrane surface and the thickness of the skin layer increased as the coagulation bath temperatures raised. Interestingly, the cross-section morphologies of the membrane transformed gradually from finger-like macro-voids to short and narrow finger-like structure with dense sponge-like top layer, and finally formed uniform sponge-like structure at 60 degC. The solvents and additives continuously diffuse into the coagulation bath, while the non-solvent enters from the coagulation bath into the as-cast membrane in NIPS process [17,24]. The diffusion rates of solvents and non-solvent between the polymer solution and non-solvent interface determine the final membrane structure [45]. With the raising of the coagulation bath temperature, the diffusion rate of the two and the phase inversion rate were accelerated. Hence, a large amount of non-solvent entered the as-cast membrane, and the membrane was in a high swelling state, contributing to a looser and larger pore for the membrane surface as the coagulation bath temperature raised. Basically, the above diffusion rates are affected by the heat transfer rate and the mass transfer rate of the casting solution in the coagulation bath at different temperatures. When the coagulation bath temperature was lower than the casting solution's cloud point, the mass transfer rate played a dominant role in forming finger-like structure in PSf membrane. As the coagulation bath temperature raised to the cloud point, the cloud point curve would approach the polymer-nonsolvent axis. At the moment, heat transfer became the main driving force for the formation of the membrane, and the sponge-like structure was formed [21,46]. Therefore, the cross-section morphologies of the PSf membrane transformed gradually from finger-like macro-voids to short and narrow finger-like structure, and finally to uniform sponge-like structure as the coagulation bath temperature increased. Moreover, the solubility of hydrophilic PEG in the casting solution increased as the coagulation bath temperature raised, resulting in a lower precipitation rate of polymer and ultimately changing the shape of the macrovoids from finger-like to sponge-like pores [47]. In a word, the instantaneous phase separation was gradually replaced by the delayed phase separation as the coagulation bath temperature increased, which led to more sponge-like pores [48]. Therefore, the coagulating bath temperature of 60 degC was taken as the optimal condition to obtain PSf membrane with sponge-like structure.
label: n

paragraph: Adjusting the humidity of air can also be used to control the morphology of the membrane. The other preparation conditions were kept constant (coagulation bath temperatures: 60 degC; pre-evaporation time: 30 s; casting thickness: 60 mm). The effects of relative humidity of air on the morphology of PSf membrane were presented in Fig. 2. As the relative humidity of air increased from 20% to 30%, 40%, 50%, the pore density and the pore size of membrane surface increased [49]. Meanwhile, the cross-sectional structure of PSf membrane drastically changed from homogeneous sponge-like to a macrovoid, loose sponge-like. Specifically, the dense skin layer of the top surface almost disappeared and the cross-sectional structure of the membrane became a symmetrical loose sponge-like structure as the relative humidity increased from 20% to 40%. When the relative humidity increased to 50%, much more macrovoid sponge-like pores were formed in the cross-sectional structure of PSf membrane. By exposing the nascent membrane to humidity, the polymer precipitation rate slowed down, promoting a delayed exchange between the solvent and the non-solvent, giving rise to sponge-like pores structure. Furthermore, the mass transfer rate of solvent outward in the casting solution was greater than that of non-solvent inward in NIPS process, which was conducive to form dense surface. Conversely, if the mass transfer rate of non-solvent inward was greater than that of solvent outward, porous membranes tend to be formed [16,50]. Therefore, at the initial phase inversion state, the composition of the nascent membrane was most affected by the water vapor, and the mass transfer rate of moisture in the air diffusing into the membrane increased as the relative humidity increased, resulting in more porous structure on the surface and more loose sponge-like macrovoid structure throughout the support layer [51]. We aimed to obtain a PSf membrane with small pore size, a relative humidity condition of 20% was selected.
label: n

paragraph: The pre-evaporation time referred to the time when the casting solution was exposed to the air before immersion in the coagulating bath. The pre-evaporation time was set as four gradients (20 s, 30 s, 40 s and 60 s respectively) to explore its influence on the PSf membrane structure while other conditions were maintained constant (coagulation bath temperature: 60 degC, relative humidity: 20% and theoretical thickness: 60 mm). As shown in Fig. 3, the pore on the membrane surface was smaller in size and less in number with the extension of evaporation time. Meanwhile, the macrovoids in the cross sectional structure were gradually replaced by uniform sponge pores, and the thickness of skin layer was gradually increased. Finally, a compact and dense skin layer was formed when the pre-evaporation time was more than 40 s. When the evaporation time was extended to the 60 s, the pore on the membrane surface was gradually reduced and the thickness of the skin layer increased further. The polymer concentration on the surface of as-cast membrane could be increased as the pre-evaporation time prolongs, and further affecting the membrane structure [52-54]. The above results also verified that the pre-evaporation time had an essential influence on the compactness of the membrane surface. The formation of the dense skin layer on the PSf membrane was caused by the increase of PSf polymer concentration on the as-cast membrane surface as the evaporation of the volatile solvent [24]. The increased PSf polymer concentration led to an increase in the degree of entanglement or interaction between the polymer molecular chains on the surface [55], which increased the resistance of the non-solvent to enter the as-cast membrane and then delayed phase separation occurred, and eventually sponge-like structure formed [56,57]. To sum up, we chose the pre-evaporation time of 30 s as the optimal condition for follow-up investigation to obtain PSf membrane with uniform sponge-like and thin skin layer.
label: n

paragraph: The effects of membrane thickness on PSf membrane structure were studied in this section (coagulation bath temperature: 60 degC, relative humidity: 20% and pre-evaporation time: 30 s). A proper casting knife was used leading to membranes of thickness ranging from 30 to 160 mm (a:30 mm; b: 60 mm; c: 100 mm; d: 160 mm). As seen in Fig. 4, the thickness of the PSf membranes were 30 mm, 64 mm, 98 mm, and 161 mm, respectively. The pore size of the membrane surface became smaller and the cross-sectional structure transformed from sponge-like pores to finger-like pores as the membrane thickness increased. The surface porosity decreased with the increase of membrane thickness. The main reason was that the thickening of the membrane increased the mass transfer resistance, leading to the reduction of the solvent and non-solvent exchange rate. Therefore, the pore size and porosity of the membrane surface decreased [58]. When the membrane thickness increased from 30 mm to 160 mm, many more, longer and narrower finger-like pores formed, and also the thinner top skin layer and thicker bottom dense layer gradually appeared. The possible reason was that much space was provided for the growth of internal pore sizes as the membrane thickness increased [59]. Therefore, the finger-like pores growing-up step was then hindered as the space between the top surface and bottom in thin as-cast membrane narrowed (i.e. membrane thickness decreased), and then sponge-like pore structure formed. In addition, the PET NWFs were used as the support layer, it prevented the non-solvent entering the casting solution from bottom to top [32], and the bottom phase inversion slowed down to form a sponge-like pore structure [17,60]. Briefly, the scraping thickness was controlled at about 60 mm to obtain the PSf membrane with sponge-like structure with small pore size.
label: n

paragraph: As stated above, the PSf membranes with much more, smaller surface pore and higher porosity could be prepared while the membrane fabrication parameters of coagulating bath temperature, relative humidity, evaporation time and the membrane thickness were 60 degC, 20%, 30 s and 60 um, respectively. Therefore, the above optimal fabrication parameters were expected to be selected for studying the influence of PET NWFs on PSf membrane, which will be discussed in the next section.
label: n

paragraph: The surface chemical structures of all the NWFs were determined by ATR-FTIR spectra, as presented in Fig. 5. Some peaks corresponding to CO bond stretching vibration, CO bond stretching vibration, OCO asymmetric stretching and CH2 bending vibration were emerged at 1712 cm-1, 1240 cm-1, 1092 cm-1 and 721 cm-1, respectively. Based on the above results, the three NWFs were proved to polyethylene terephthalate (PET).
label: n

paragraph: Besides the chemical composition, the morphologies and surface properties of all the PET NWFs (named NWF-01, NWF-02, and NWF-03) were also characterized, as shown in Fig. 6 and listed in Table 1. All of the NWF-01, NWF-02, and NWF-03 had uniform fiber thickness (Fig. 6). The thickness and the fiber thickness of PET NWFs followed this order: NWF-03 > NWF-02 > NWF-01, and the NWF-01 had fine and tightly packed fibers might with a lower gas permeability. This speculation was verified by gas penetration test, and some physical parameters of the PET NWFs were also presented in Table 1. The bulk porosity and the structural parameters were NWF-03 > NWF-02 > NWF-01 in descending order. Meanwhile, the air permeability of NWF-01, NWF-02 and NWF-03 were 489.19, 508.35 and 522.20 mm/Pas, respectively. It indicated that the airtightness of the NWF-01 was better than that of others, reflecting its higher degree of denseness. As known, gas permeability can be affected by multiple physical parameters of PET NWFs, which could be positively related to fiber diameter and bulk porosity and negatively to the thickness and structural parameters [61]. Although the thickness of NWF-03 was the thickest, its volume porosity was the largest, which led to lower resistance for gas transport path through it, ultimately resulting in a higher gas permeability compared to the other PET NWFs [62,63]. Additionally, the WCA values of the three PET NWFs were presented in Fig. 7, and the specific data were NWF-03 (90.55deg) > NWF-02 (87.09deg) > NWF-01 (82.19deg). Actually, all the three NWFs were polyethylene terephthalate (Fig. 5). Therefore, the roughness variation of the NWF substrate was the main reason for the difference in the WCA [64]. Fig. 8 showed the rough characterization of the three PET NWFs. Generally speaking, the greater the roughness, the better the hydrophilicity when the WCA was lower than 90deg. It can be seen that the roughness of NWF-01 (396 nm), NWF-02 (331 nm) and NWF-03 (314 nm) decreased successively. Therefore, the hydrophilicity of NWF-01 was better than that of other PET NWFs. In addition, the increase of roughness also affected the bonding force between the casting solution and the PET NWFs. The PET NWFs with larger roughness had greater adhesion to the casting solution [32]. Thus, the structure of PSf membrane would be affected by the PET NWFs with different hydrophilic and roughness, which would be discussed in the next section.
label: n

paragraph: To further investigate the influence of the substrate hydrophilicity and roughness on the morphology and performance of the resulting PSf membranes, the above three kinds of PET NWFs were used as substrates to prepare sponge-like structured PSf membranes under the same optimal preparation conditions which were established in Section 4.1. The composition, preparation method and process of casting solution were the same as those described in Section 2.2. Subsequently, the properties, the PWF and BSA rejection for the three kinds of PSf membranes (named PSf-NWF-01, PSf-NWF-02 and PSf-NWF-03 membrane) were tested and discussed in detail. Herein, Fig. 9 showed the ATR-FTIR spectra of the different PSf membranes. Compared to the PET NWFs (Fig. 5), it could be seen that the stretching vibration peaks of SO2 group at 1584 cm-1, 1149 cm-1, and 1296 cm-1, the bending vibration peak of CH3 at 1487 cm-1 and 1240 cm-1 were appeared, which illustrated that the PSf membrane was successfully formed on the PET NWFs [65].The surface and cross-sectional micrographs of the prepared PSf membranes were presented in Fig. 10. It showed that all the PSf layers via a typically delayed phase separation produced membranes with "sponge-like" structure. The thickness of PSf-NWF-01, PSf-NWF-02 and PSf-NWF-03 membranes were 41.38, 42.78 and 64.03 mm, respectively. Although the top surfaces of all the membranes appeared to be smooth and porous, the PSf-NWF-01 membrane had the lowest surface average pore size (30.40 nm) and the highest pore density (9.77 x 10-3) (Table 2). To be specifically, the PSf-NWF-01 membrane showed a higher surface pore density and volume porosity than all the other PSf membranes, which was consistent with the higher hydrophilicity of NWF-01. During phase inversion, the PET NWFs offered a barrier for water intrusion to nascent PSf membrane from the bottom and then delay the solidification process, which was accelerated by the hydrophilicity of the PET NWFs. In contrast to the other PET NWFs, NWF-01 with higher hydrophilicity intensified the rate of the solvent/water exchange in the coagulation bath, resulting in a higher porosity of the resulting PSf membranes [57].
label: n

paragraph: Finally, the PWF and BSA rejection performance of the three self-made PSf membranes and a commercial membrane (PSf-HT, properties in Table 2) were illustrated in Fig. 11. Specifically, the order of PWF was PSf-NWF-01 (463.69 L/(m2*h)) > PSf-NWF-02 (285.27 L/(m2*h)) > PSf-HT (243.13 L/(m2*h)) > PSf-NWF-03 (147.26 L/(m2*h)). The PWF of PSf-NWF-01 membrane was much higher than that of other PSf membranes. It was explained by that the PSf-NWF-01 membrane had a thinner thickness, a smaller tortuosity, a higher surface pore density and volume porosity (Table 2), which had a positive impact on the permeation flux. Additionally, the BSA rejections for PSf-HT (98.1%) and PSf-NWF-01 (97.58 %) membranes were much higher than those of other PSf membranes (<95%), the main reason was that the pore size and its distribution (Table 2) for PSf-HT and PSf-NWF-01 membranes were smaller and uniform. To summarize, the self-made PSf-NWF-01 membrane had the optimum performance among the above membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Actually, the PET NWFs offered a barrier for water intrusion to the nascent PSf membrane which can delay the solidification in NIPS process, but it can be accelerated by the hydrophilicity of the PET NWFs, and then a thinner and porous PSf membrane could be formed. The increase in the porosity of membrane structure would open the diffusion path, thereby improving the permeability [31]. Many researchers proposed that PSf membrane with better structure and pore properties can be formed on PET NWFs with higher hydrophilicity, maximum roughness and compact fiber accumulation [31,32,66], which were also proved in our study. Based on the above results, PET NWFs with different roughness were considered to play an essential role in the formation of membrane morphology. As presented in Fig. 12, the capillary pressure of the three PET NWFs had a good correlation with the solid-liquid interface energy, while the water flux of the membrane was also closely related to capillary pressure and solid-liquid interfacial energy [67]. According to the Young-Laplace equation, NWF-01 with higher roughness and hydrophilicity had the highest capillary force owing to their higher solid-liquid interfacial energy and stronger binding force, which meant the polymer casting solution could be better absorbed by NWF-01 to form a thinner PSf layer. Thus, the gap between the PSf layer and the NWF-01 layer was narrowed and the transmission path of water was shortened with a lower transmission resistance, which contributed to a higher water flux. On the contrary, there was a larger repulsion between NWF-03 and PSf casting solution due to its higher hydrophobic, lower roughness and minimum negative capillary force. Therefore, the lowest adhesion between NWF-03 and PSf membrane resulted in poor performance of PSf-NWF-03 membrane. Above all, the increase in membrane thickness would effectively increase the length of the water diffusion path, thereby reducing the water flux [65]. It was concluded that sponge-like structure PSf support membrane with better pore properties was easier to form on hydrophilic PET NWFs with higher roughness.
label: n

paragraph: To evaluate the anti-fouling ability of the PSf membranes, the BSA protein solution filtration tests were carried out, and the results were shown in Fig. 13. The decreasing amplitude of membrane flux in descending order was PSf-NWF-01, PSF-HT, PSf-NWF-02 and PSf-NWF-03. In the process of BSA filtration, the flux attenuation of the four membranes generally went through three stages: rapidly decaying in the initial stage (about 0-60 min), then slowing down in the middle stage (about 60-120 min) and keeping stable in the late stage (about 120-210 min). Such flux decay trends were also found in other studies [68]. The reason was that the adsorption of some protein molecules on the membrane surface at the early filtration stage, resulted in a rapid decrease in flux. Then, the fouling rate gradually decreased until the flux was stable in the middle and late stages, which was due to the formation of filter cake layer [68]. Additionally, the flux recovery rate (FRR) and fouling resistances (Ri or Rir) were important parameters to evaluate the antifouling performance of the membranes. As shown in Fig. 14, the FRR of the membranes were PSf-NWF-01 (88.59%), PSf-HT (88.29%), PSf-NWF-02 (87.29%) and PSf-NWF-03 (85.41%). Meanwhile, the values of Rir followed by PSf-NWF-01(11.41%) < PSf-HT (11.71%) < PSf-NWF-02 (12.71%) < PSf-NWF-03 (14.59%). Combining the previous membrane properties, it concluded that PSf-NWF-01 membrane with a higher hydrophilicity (Fig. 15), smaller surface pores and a smooth surface morphology (Fig. 10) leading to higher FRR and lower Rir, and also illustrated its higher anti-fouling performance. Correspondingly, the PSf-NWF-03 membrane was fouled easily, mainly because BSA protein molecules were easier to enter the membrane surface with large pore size. The increase of protein adsorption in membrane surface can aggravate the blockage degree of membrane pores and eventually lead to the deterioration of membrane fouling [69-71]. Overall, the PSf-NWF-01 membrane prepared on the higher hydrophilic PET NWFs not only had uniform sponge pore structure, but also had high PWF, rejection and anti-fouling ability.
label: n

paragraph: In this work, a series of PSf support membranes with sponge-like structure were fabricated by NIPS using three different PET NWFs as the substrate layers. The influences of membrane fabrication parameters and PET NWFs' properties on sponge-like structure PSf membrane with high performance were systematically studied. Sponge-like structure PSf support membranes can be obtained by adjusting the fabrication parameters while the coagulation bath temperature, relative humidity, pre-evaporation time and scraping membrane thickness were 60 degC, 20%, 30 s, 60 mm, respectively. Moreover, the fiber diameter, thickness, volume porosity, structural parameters, hydrophobicity and capillary pressure of all the NWF-01, NWF-02, and NWF-03 were characterized. The results showed that the hydrophilicity of PET NWFs was positively correlated with the performance of PSf membranes according to Young-Laplace equation, which indicated the adhesion degree between PSf and NWFs. Accordingly, NWF-01 had a stronger adhesion to PSf casting solution resulting from its higher hydrophilic, and then a thinner and porous PSf layer was formed. Hence, the PSf-NWF-01 membrane showed an ideal performance compared with other self-made PSf or HT commercial membrane, with PWF and BSA rejection were 463.69 L/(m2*h) and 97.58%, respectively. Moreover, the PSf-NWF-01 membrane also exhibited the highest flux recovery ratio of 88.59% and the lowest irreversible fouling of 11.41%. This work was expected to provide a reference for optimizing the preparation conditions of the sponge-like structure PSf membrane and selecting appropriate PET NWFs for manufacturing TFC membranes.
label: n
