paragraph: Data will be made available on request.
label: n

paragraph: As one of the emerging agriculture-based industries, natural rubber mills unavoidably produce a large amount of wastewater. The excessive generation of wastewater from local rubber industries results in severe air and water pollution, contributing to environmental damage. To address this issue, there is a window of opportunity to develop an effective rubber-laden wastewater (NRW) treatment. Commonly, NRW is treated using coagulation-flocculation [1] or biological treatment [2] prior to its disposal in the water body. Unfortunately, these methods generate sludge as a by-product that requires further treatment before discharging to the landfill. This post-treatment requires additional expenses, which contributes to an increase in operational costs for wastewater treatment.
label: n

paragraph: In recent years, membrane technology has been widely implemented for water and wastewater treatments due to its technical applicability and outstanding removal performances as compared to other processes. The advantages of membrane technology include continuous separation, efficient and clean energy consumption, versatility to be integrated with other physicochemical separations, adjustable physical and separation properties, less chemical consumption, applicability for separating thermally-sensitive solutions (biological and organic solutions), and less sludge generation [3-5]. Particularly, membrane reactor technology has been extensively applied for many wastewater treatments [6,7]. A membrane reactor is an integrated technology that combines filtration and reaction processes in a single unit simultaneously. However, this method still struggles with limitations, including low pollutant rejection, fouling formation, lack of reusability, and poor durability [8,9]. New membranes with superior characteristics that can tackle those problems are urgently needed for membrane reactor technology. As a type of membrane reactor technology, the photocatalytic membrane became a popular method for treating wastewater that contains complicated contaminants [10-12]. The semiconductor materials as the photocatalysts are incorporated into the polymer matrix to synthesize the photocatalytic membrane composite [10,13].
label: n

paragraph: Semiconductor oxides have been widely utilized as photocatalysts, such as tin oxide (SnO2), zinc oxide (ZnO), magnetite (Fe3O4), silver phosphate (Ag3PO4), tungsten oxide (WO3), titanium oxide (TiO2), cerium oxide (CeO2), bismuth tungstate (Bi2WO6), and graphene oxide (GO) [14-22]. They have been applied for degrading pollutants, including dyes, organic pollutants, natural organic matters, and pharmaceutical substances [12,23,24]. Among them, TiO2 has attracted extensive attention from scientists and engineers because of its chemical stability, ease to activate, low toxicity, modifiable, and water-insoluble, showing promising application for wastewater treatment [10]. ZnO has a similarity with TiO2 regarding the photocatalytic characteristics such as similar bandgap (3.10 - 3.37 eV), UV light-driven activation, large availability, chemically, and thermally stable [25,26]. Previous studies reported that ZnO performed better photocatalytic degradation efficiency for removing organic pollutants than that TiO2, which was caused by the effective charge transport on its large surface area [27]. Nevertheless, pure ZnO photocatalyst usually exhibits low photo-sensitivity and a high rate of electron-hole recombination, hence, resulting in limiting its usability in large-scale application of the photocatalytic process. Theoretically, to achieve better performance of the photocatalytic activity of photocatalysts, the electron-hole recombination rate should be maintained as low as possible.
label: n

paragraph: Several studies to improve the performance of photocatalysts have been reported, including compounding, doping, decorating, and catalyzer carrier [27,28]. Those methods have been implemented to enhance the photocatalytic properties of ZnO. Constructing heterojunction structures on ZnO with other semiconductors to engineer the photo-sensitivity bandgap energy seems to be an effective method. This method can also reduce the electron-hole recombination rate and subsequently enhance the photodegradation efficiency of the ZnO-based photocatalyst. There are some materials that are widely used as complementary photocatalysts to construct the heterojunction structure, such as carbon nitride (C3N4) [29], reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [30], GO [31], and manganese oxide (MnO2) [28], WO3[32], and molybdenum sulfide (MoS2) [33]. Some studies also investigated those noble metals (Au, Ag, and Pt) and transition metals (Fe, Cr, and Mn) can enhance the photocatalytic degradation of various dyes [34]. Amongst those, MnO2 has gained significant attention as a complementary photocatalyst, supercapacitor material, and lithium-ion battery additive. This is due to its immense natural availability, outstanding electrochemical characteristics, low bandgap energy, and high specific capacitance. By integrating MnO2 with conventional semiconductors such as ZnO, the photo-induced electrons of the semiconductor are transferred and captured by the MnO2 structure, which restrains the possibility of electron-hole recombination. The embedded MnO2 particles can also reduce the overall bandgap energy of the composite by inducing oxygen vacancies in the lattice structure of ZnO [35]. Moreover, the embedded MnO2 can also improve the photocatalytic properties by increasing the lifetime photo-induced charge transport and enhancing the charge transfer process.
label: n

paragraph: Furthermore, efficient photocatalysts should have a large surface area to provide massive active sites for photocatalysis. Silicon dioxide (SiO2) has been widely utilized as catalyst support for semiconductor photocatalysts [34,36]. The incorporation of SiO2 influences some fundamental characteristics of TiO2 and improves its photocatalytic properties [34,36]. Balachandran and coworkers reported that the specific surface area improved from 65 m2/g for TiO2 to 75 m2/g for TiO2/SiO2 composite [37]. Moreover, the addition of SiO2 into TiO2 improved the thermal stability of the TiO2/SiO2 composite, thus, inhibiting the TiO2's crystalline conversion from the anatase into the rutile phase [38]. Utilizing SiO2 as catalyst support also provides pollutant adsorption that brings the pollutant molecules closer to the active sites of the catalyst, thus resulting in a higher rate of photodegradation [39]. Due to these advantages, SiO2 was selected as the catalyst support to enhance the photocatalytic ability of the synthesized ZnO-MnO2 catalyst.
label: n

paragraph: Basically, performing photocatalytic properties on the membrane's surface can provide a simultaneous filtration and photocatalytic process at a single time. Furthermore, the membrane process is susceptible to fouling formation; therefore, performing the photocatalytic process on the membrane's surface can also prevent fouling formation by degrading the attached foulants with the generated radical molecules, which can provide overall membrane performance improvements. In this present study, the MnO2 doping into ZnO with SiO2 as the matrix (ZnO-MnO2@SiO2) composite was synthesized via the sol-gel process, and the membranes were prepared using the non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS) method. The synthesized photocatalyst composite was expected to improve the photocatalytic activity, hydrophilicity, and antifouling performance of the modified PSf membrane. Based on our review, none has conducted the study regarding synthesis, characterization, and performance evaluation of the UV light-driven photocatalytic PSf membrane incorporated by ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite as the photocatalyst for simultaneous membrane filtration and photocatalytic process for NRW treatment. This study explored, evaluated, and compared the membrane performance in dark conditions and under UV light exposure. The photodegradation performance, photocatalytic degradation kinetics, effects of scavengers, and photocatalytic mechanisms of the membranes were also investigated. Therefore, this study can provide a better option for enhancing photocatalysts activity to improve the overall membrane performance, which can prolong the membrane's lifetime for a reliable method of NRW treatment.
label: n

paragraph: Polysulfone (PSf, 99 %) pellets (UDEL (r) PSU P-1700 NT) as the polymeric membrane material was obtained from Solvay Advanced Materials, USA. N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 99.9 %) as the solvent to dissolve the PSf pellet was supplied by Merck, Germany. Silicon dioxide (SiO2, 99 %), zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO, 99 %), and manganese oxide (MnO2, 99 %) nanoparticles were provided by Nano Center Indonesia. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98 %) and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36 %) as required chemicals in the sol-gel process were obtained from Merck, Germany. Potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7, 99 %) for COD measurement and HACH 183,699 test kit for phenol content analysis were purchased from Meditek Sarta, Indonesia. HI3824-025 for ammonia nitrogen (NH3-N) analysis was supplied from Hanna Instruments, Singapore. Analytical grades of oxalic acid (H2C2O4, 99 %), benzoquinone (C6H4O2, 99 %), and methanol (CH3OH, 99 %) for trapping test were obtained from Mada Kimia, Indonesia. Deionized (DI) water was used in chemical solution preparation and all experiment. The sample of natural rubber-laden wastewater (NRW) was collected from PTPN VII, located in Bengkulu, Indonesia. The detailed characteristics of the wastewater are presented in Table 1.
label: y

paragraph: The sol-gel method was applied with some modifications to synthesize the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite [40,41]. Firstly, 25 g of SiO2 was constantly mixed in a 125 mL NaOH 2 M for 2 h at 150 degC. After the mixture cooled down, it was filtered through a filter paper (Whatman No. 42) to separate the undissolved SiO2 from the mixture. Then, 1.25 g of ZnO and 1.25 g of MnO2 were added to 25 mL of the filtrate solution, and it was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The mixture was placed into an ultrasonic homogenizer at a frequency of 50 kHz for 60 min in order to get better particle dispersions. Dilute solution containing HCl 1 M was added dropwise into the mixture under constant stirring until the mixture turned into gels. The gels were left overnight for the compaction process. Subsequently, the spent solution was removed from the gels using a vacuum filter, and the damp gels were dried in an oven at 110 degC for 12 h. The dried gels were calcinated in a furnace at 500 degC for 5 h to remove the remaining organic substances and bonded water molecules and activate the photocatalysts. Then, it was crushed using a planetary ball mill machine, and the product was sieved to get finer powders.
label: y

paragraph: The composite membranes were fabricated by referring to the (NIPS) process [42,43]. Table 2 shows the variation of membrane compositions prepared in this study. In the beginning, a certain amount of PSf pellets were mixed into a 50 mL of NMP solvent until the PSf pellets wholly dissolved. Then, the nanoparticle with a specific amount was introduced into the solution under constant stirring for 12 h. Subsequently, the mixture was put into an ultrasonic bath with an operating frequency of 60 kHz for 60 min to remove the trapped bubbles and create a better dispersion of nanoparticles. The membrane solution was cast onto a flat glass plate using a casting knife. Then, the casted solution was immersed in a DI water bath to form the membrane sheets, and it was left for 24 h to remove the spent solvent inside the membrane. Finally, membrane sheets were dried at an ambient condition.
label: y

paragraph: The scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL Series, JSM-6510-LA, Japan) was used to observe the surface micromorphology and cross-section images of as-synthesized photocatalysts and the fabricated membranes. The energy dispersive X-ray (EDX, JEOL Series, Japan) was performed to capture the chemical composition, including elemental and oxide contents of the fabricated membrane. The particle size distribution of the photocatalyst was determined using a laser particle size analyzer (PSA, Labtron Instruments, UK). The atomic force microscopy (AFM, Hitachi, Japan) was applied for the fabricated membranes' surface roughness and topography observation. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR, Perkin Elmer, USA) was used to characterize the chemical functional groups of as-synthesized photocatalysts and the fabricated membranes. X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD, Shimadzu, Japan) was used to investigate the crystalline structure and crystal phases of the photocatalysts and the fabricated membranes. The diffractograms were recorded using Cu Ka at 30 mA and 30 kV with a scanning speed of 3deg min-1 for a diffraction angle (2th) of 10deg-70deg.
label: n

paragraph: The assessment of photocatalytic activity of the nanoparticles and the optical analysis of diffuse reflectance spectrometry (DRS) was carried out. It was performed using a UV-vis (ultraviolet-visible) spectrophotometer (UV-vis Spectrophotometer, Shimadzu, Japan) and conducted at 250-700 nm. This analysis provided the absorbance interaction of the nanoparticles upon the photon energy from different wavelengths ranging from UV to visible light spectra. The energy gaps of the nanoparticle were then estimated using the method of Tauc plot. Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET, Quantachrome, Switzerland) with nitrogen (N2) as working gas was applied to observe the hysteresis loop, sorption behavior, and the specific surface area of the photocatalysts.
label: n

paragraph: The porosity measurement of the membrane was carried out by immersing the membrane for 24 h in DI water and recording the final weight of the membrane. Afterward, the membranes were placed in a vacuum oven for 24 h at 60 degC, and the dry weight of the membrane was measured. Finally, the membrane porosity was calculated using Eq. (1)[42].(1)e=wt-worwxAxdx100%Where e is the membrane porosity (%), while wt and wo represent the weights (g) of the wet and dry membranes, respectively. rw shows the water density at room temperature (0.997 g.cm-3); A corresponds to the effective surface area (cm-2); d represents the membrane thickness (cm).
label: n

paragraph: Additionally, the average pore radius was analyzed using the Guerout-Elford-Ferry approximation by Eq. (2)[42].(2)r=8edQx(2.9-1.75e)exAxDPWhere e shows the water viscosity at room temperature (8.9 x 10-4 Pa.s), d represents the membrane thickness (m), Q is the volumetric flow rate of the permeate (m3.s-1), and DP shows the trans-membrane pressure (Pa).
label: n

paragraph: The material testing machine (UTS H001, China) was used to conduct membrane mechanical strength measurements based on thickness, tensile strength, and elongation break. The measurement was subjected to a 5 x 5 cm2 flat sheet membrane sample. The sample was placed on a sample holder and carefully clamped. The sample was stretched, and the elongation rate was fixed at 20 mm/min. The measurements were subjected to each membrane sample in triplicates. A contact angle meter (OCA25 Dataphysics Instrument GmBH, Germany) was used to measure a static contact angle and surface energy using the sessile drop method. The DI water at 25 degC was used as a probe liquid. The water was dripped on the membrane surface. After 3 s, its contact angle was measured. The contact angle measurement was conducted several times to obtain reproducible measurement results. The water uptake value of fabricated membranes was calculated using Eq. (3)[42].(3)WU=ww-wdwdx100%Where WU is the water uptake (%), ww and wd are the wet and dry weights (g) of the tested membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The photocatalytic-filtration (photo-filtration) performance of the fabricated membranes was evaluated based on the permeate flux and pollutants removal in NRW photo-filtration process. The photo-filtration test was conducted using a prototype of a membrane filtration system equipped with a feed tank, a pump, pressure gauge, a permeate collector, and a membrane cell modified with a UV lamp (Philips TUV- 30-watt, Netherland). Fig. 1(a) shows the photo-filtration cross-flow module setup used in this experiment. The UV lamp can be easily turned on or off to perform, whether on dark or UV exposure filtration. The actual sample of NRW was used as the feed for evaluating the permeate flux and pollutants rejection, which focused on phenol, COD, and NH3-N removals.
label: n

paragraph: Before measuring the wastewater flux analysis, the membrane was acclimated using deionized water for 30 min. This test was performed at 5 bar trans-membrane pressure with a membrane area of 12.57 cm2. The permeate flux was recorded every 30 min for 3.5 h for each membrane. The membrane water flux values were then calculated using Eq. (4).(4)J=VA.tWhere J and V are the permeate water flux (L.m-2.h-1) and the volume of the permeate (L). At the same time, A and t are effective membrane area (m2) and filtration time (h), respectively.
label: n

paragraph: The phenol, COD, and NH3-N concentrations were spectrophotometrically determined using reagents of HACH 183699, dichromate, and HI3824-025, respectively. The following Eq. (5) was used to calculate membrane pollutant rejection.(5)R=(1-CPCF)x100%Where R is rejection efficiency (%), Cp and Cf are the concentration (mg/L) of the pollutant in permeate and feed solution, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: The photocatalytic activity of the fabricated membranes was evaluated by assessing the phenol, COD, and NH3-N degradations rate using the sample of NRW as the feed. Firstly, 100 mL of NRW sample was diluted by adding 100 mL of DI water to reduce the pollutant concentration and make the countable photocatalytic degradation by the membrane composites. The membrane sheet of 5 cm in diameter was mounted onto the glass holder and was immersed into 100 mL of NRW sample. This experiment was carried out in a dark and closed chamber equipped with a UV lamp. The distance between the wastewater and the UV lamp was 10 cm. The complete illustration of the batch photocatalytic test setup can be seen in Fig. 1(b). Before the UV lamp was turned on, the membrane was immersed for 60 min in order to achieve the adsorption equilibrium state for ensuring that only the photocatalytic process was assayed. This photocatalytic process was conducted for 120 min, and COD, NH3-N, and phenol removals were measured every 20 min. The photocatalytic degradation kinetics using the composite membranes were further evaluated by applying the zero order and pseudo-first order kinetic models. The mathematical expressions of the applied kinetic models are represented in Eq. (6) and Eq. (7), respectively [44].(6)Co-Ct=kot(7)lnCoCt=k1tWhere Co and Ct represent the concentrations of pollutants at initial (mg/L) and at a specific time (mg/L), ko (mg L-1 min-1) and k1 (min-1) symbolize the rate constants of zero-order and pseudo-first order kinetic models, and t is the operating time (min).
label: n

paragraph: In this study, trapping tests were performed to investigate further the relevance, existence, and relative activity of the reactive species on pollutant degradations. Oxalic acid, benzoquinone, and methanol were used as the scavengers for holes, superoxide, and hydroxyl radicals, respectively [45]. The photocatalytic activity of the fabricated membranes was tested in a 100 mL NRW sample containing 2 mmol of the scavengers at 30 degC for 120 min under UV irradiation. After that, the concentration of phenol, COD, and NH3-N was measured to understand the effect of scavengers on the photocatalytic activity of the fabricated membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The stability test in terms of permeate flux and pollutant removal was carried out by performing filtration in the dark mode and under UV light irradiation for 15 h (900 min). The permeate flux was measured every 30 min, and the pollutant removal was analyzed at the end of the filtration process. To assess the fabricated membranes' reusability, three straight cycle experiments on permeate flow and pollutant removal were performed. The membrane was utilized in the filtering experiment for 3 x 210 min under UV light irradiation, with the permeate flow being collected every 30 min. The membrane was submerged in DI water for 30 min at the end of each cycle. After that, the membrane was gently cleansed with a water sprayer to remove any adherent dirt before being utilized again for the next cycle of testing. Three consecutive cycle tests were also conducted to evaluate the photocatalytic stability of the tested membranes. The approach for determining photocatalytic activity is the same as in section 2.6. The membrane was soaked in DI water for 30 min in between cycles before being employed in the following cycle test. The NRW sample was renewed to assure that the initial pollutant condition was the same in every cycle experiment.
label: n

paragraph: Using a resistance in series model, the resistance during filtration was assessed. The model considers all types of membrane fouling resistance, including intrinsic resistance (Rm), adsorption resistance (Ra), deposition resistance (Rd), and concentration polarization (Rcp), as the complete formula are shown in Eqs. (8)-(11), respectively [46].(8)Rm=DPexJi(9)Ra=DPexJa-Rm(10)Rd=DPexJf-Rm-Ra(11)Rcp=DPexJv-Rm-Ra-RdWhere DP is the trans-membrane pressure (Pa), e is pure water viscosity (Pa.s), Ji, Ja, Jf, and Jv are the initial membrane pure water flux (PWF) (L.m-2h-1), the measured PWF after fouled by static adsorption (L.m-2h-1), the PWF after fouled by actual NRW (L.m-2h-1), and the measured flux when operating in actual NRW filtration (L.m-2h-1), respectively.
label: n

paragraph: The effect of UV irradiation on composite membranes for producing photocatalytic activity can also be ascribed to the reduction of membrane fouling which is known as the antifouling properties. The total fouling ratio (RT), reversible fouling ratio (RR), irreversible fouling ratio (RIr), and flux recovery ratio (FRR) of the fabricated membranes were measured as the mathematical formula are given in Eqs. (12)-(15), respectively [46].(12)RT=Ji-JwJcx100%(13)RR=Jc-JwJix100%(14)RIr=Ji-JcJix100%(15)FRR=JcJix100%Where Ji, Jc, and Jw are the initial PWF (L.m-2h-1), PWF after cleaning (L.m-2h-1), and the permeate flux of wastewater (L.m-2h-1), respectively.
label: n

paragraph: Several analyses were performed to characterize the prepared photocatalyst composites. Fig. 2(a) depicts the micromorphology of the prepared ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite. The irregular structure dominates the micromorphology of this composite. Some aggregations can still be observed in the SEM image. This possibly occurred due to the high tendency of tiny particles to stick with others [47]. The elemental and oxide composition of the as-synthesized ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite were characterized using EDX, and the results are listed in Table 3. It can be seen that the composite mainly consisted of 24.13 %, 13.10 %, and 15.14 % of SiO2, ZnO, and MnO2, respectively, with low content of impurities such as sodium (Na) and copper (Cu) with compositions of 0.13 % and 0.81 %, respectively. The recorded Na and Cu compositions can be promoted by the tiny amount of Na and Cu in the SiO2 as the matrix material of the composite. Since the content is not significant, the negative impacts of the Na and Cu presence on the photocatalytic properties of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 can be neglected. The detected significant Zn and Mn signals in the EDX results revealed that the doping of ZnO and MnO2 into the SiO2 matrix was successful. Fig. 2(b) shows the particle size distribution of the synthesized ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite. This composite has various sizes of particle that distribute from 20 to 180 nm, and particle size of 60-80 nm dominates the distribution. It is also found that the average size of the composite is 78.54 nm. Smaller particle size is possible to facilitate a larger surface area of the active sites, thus can generate better photocatalytic performance. FTIR analysis was used to characterize the contained functional groups of the composite, as the results are compiled in Fig. 2(c). In all spectra, the fingerprint region that corresponds to the metal oxide bonds is observed at the wavenumber of 600 to 400 cm-1[48]. Moreover, a broad absorption peak at 1000 cm-1 that can be observed in the spectra of pristine MnO2 and ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite indicates the presence of Mn-O bonds [28]. A sharp peak at around 500 cm in ZnO and ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite correlates to the presence of Zn-O bonds [48]. These observed peaks that correspond to the presence of Zn-O and Mn-O groups in the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite indicate success attachments of ZnO and MnO2 in the composite.
label: n

paragraph: To further understand the characteristics of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite, an XRD analysis was carried out. XRD results present the diffractograms that correlate with the crystalline structure of the tested samples. Fig. 2(d) reflects the diffractograms of SiO2, ZnO, MnO2, and ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite. Based on the results, it is found that SiO2 and MnO2 seem to have an amorphous structure. Despite this, SiO2 show two sharp peaks at 33.21deg and 45.63deg that indicate the crystallite of SiO2[49]. Some small peaks are also observed in the diffractogram of MnO2, which closely correlates to the birnessite crystal phase of MnO2[27]. In contrast, the diffractogram of ZnO shows a lot of significant peaks. The peaks in the ZnO's diffraction pattern can be related to the wurtzite crystal structure phase based on the card number of JCPDS No. 0036-1451. Moreover, the XRD pattern of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite is dominantly attributed to that of ZnO, with also contains the patterns of MnO2 and SiO2, which signifies the coexistence of ZnO and MnO2 crystallite sites. This indicates the successful formation of the heterostructure of the composite [50]. It is also found that the peak intensity of standard ZnO is reduced in the synthesized ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite, which is caused by the more intense reflections due to the entrapped other oxides (MnO2 and SiO2) in the ZnO structures. This phenomenon corresponds to the formation of the heterostructure in the photocatalyst composite. Overall, the XRD results agree well with the previous FTIR results to support the successful doping of ZnO and MnO2 in the photocatalyst.
label: n

paragraph: BET-BJH analysis was used to show the sorption properties of the photocatalysts and their specific surface area, as shown in Fig. 2(e). Based on the results, the sorption isotherms of N2 for all photocatalysts are attributed as type IV with H3 hysteresis loop characteristics [51]. It suggests that the pore characteristics of all samples can be classified as mesoporous material, indicated by the quite noticeable envelope shape in the hysteresis loops. The mesoporous material has a pore size of 2-50 nm, which is usually associated with the detected pores as the gaps between nanoparticles. Furthermore, the BET surface areas of the photocatalysts were 182, 207, and 254 m2/g for ZnO, MnO2, and ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. This result indicates that the synthesized ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite has the largest BET surface area among others, which correlated to the utilization of SiO2 as the composite's matrix, thus providing a larger surface area. These findings are also in a similar shape to previously reported studies that also used SiO2 as the catalysts support [52]. The larger surface area of a photocatalyst might provide massive active sites for the photocatalytic process and enhance the degradation performance. The surface area also plays a crucial role in pollutant adsorption prior the photocatalytic degradation.
label: n

paragraph: The DRS analysis was performed to understand the light absorption behavior of the photocatalysts under UV-vis spectra. Fig. 2(f) depicts the response of the photocatalysts to light absorbance upon irradiation of UV-vis spectra. It can be seen that each sample shows a different response trend. SiO2 seems to not have an active light absorption either in UV or visible regions. ZnO shows a significant absorbance in the UV region, while MnO2 presents an active behavior in the visible light region. Meanwhile, the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite shows the light absorption activity in a region between pristine ZnO and MnO2. However, by looking it closer, the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite has the highest absorption of the light spectrum in a wavelength of around 350 nm, which is still in the UV light region. Therefore, the photocatalytic experiment should be performed using UV light irradiation instead of visible light irradiation. The bandgap energies of the photocatalysts were estimated using the Tauc plots, as depicted in Fig. 2(g). It can be observed that SiO2 has an undetected bandgap value, as previously suggested by the DRS results. Previous works reported that SiO2 has extremely high bandgap energy with approximately 5.00 eV [39]; thus, it cannot be estimated using standard light spectra of 250-700 nm. Pristine ZnO has a bandgap energy of 3.10 eV, indicating that the photocatalytic process should be performed under UV light conditions. Pristine MnO2 shows a bandgap of 2.20 eV, as shown by the significant light absorption in the visible light region. The ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite has a bandgap value of 2.65 eV, which is lower than that of pristine ZnO and SiO2 but higher than the pristine MnO2. This reduction of the bandgap value of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite is desirable and is reasonably caused by the incorporation of MnO2. However, despite the fact that the pristine MnO2 has the lowest bandgap energy, it does not reflect the best photocatalytic properties. It is due to a single element photocatalyst tends to have a higher electron-hole recombination rate, which is not satisfying [53]. Indeed, the main goal of MnO2 integration into the composite is to reduce the bandgap energy of the composite by inducing the oxygen vacancies in the lattice structure of ZnO and creating the heterojunction photocatalytic mechanism to reduce the electron-hole recombination [35]. This finding suggests that the doping of MnO2 into ZnO can influence the light absorption behavior of the synthesized composite and result in lower bandgap energy. The lower bandgap energy indicates that the photocatalyst requires lower photon energy to perform the photocatalysis, thus can improve the photocatalytic performance of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite.
label: n

paragraph: The surface and cross-sectional images of the neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membranes are compiled in Fig. 3. Based on the results in Fig. 3(a), it is found that the surface morphology of the neat PSf is relatively smooth, with some defects spotted. These defects might be formed due to different coagulation rates of polysulfone in the defect spots compared to the whole membrane surface during the phase inversion process. The embedded photocatalysts, i.e., ZnO, MnO2, and ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, on the surface of the modified membranes are observed, as shown in Fig. 1(b-d), respectively. The photocatalysts appear as tiny dots across the membranes' surface. The embedded photocatalyst on the membrane surface will become active under UV light irradiation to perform the photocatalytic process for pollutant degradations. For the cross-sectional structure, the neat PSf membrane attributed a sponge-like structure with spotted microvoid structures. This sponge-like structure reflects a low membrane's porosity due to a denser structure. It is found that the cross-sectional morphologies of the modified membranes with photocatalysts are significantly different from that of the neat PSf. The modified membranes attributed a similar finger-like structure to their cross-sectional morphologies. The finger-like structure is a typical characteristic of the cross-sectional morphology of membranes that are prepared using the NIPS method [54]. The finger-like structure formed right after the coagulation process, which separated the solvent and polymer. Polymer rich phase turned into a membrane matrix, whereas solvent rich phase turned into membrane pores that were usually in the form of finger-like structure. It is also found that PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 have fine constructed finger-like structures. It can be seen that the modified membranes with photocatalysts have a more massive pore structure compared to the neat PSf membrane. The massive pore structure possibly leads to creating higher membrane porosity, water uptake, and permeability [55]; thus, the modified membranes can perform better filtration performance. The embedded photocatalysts are found in the pore structure of the modified membranes, which is desirable to enhance membrane hydrophilicity. The synergetic effects of photocatalysts on the membrane's surface, the finger-like structure, and embedded photocatalysts in the membrane's pore structure are helpful in generating a significant improvement in the filtration process.
label: n

paragraph: To characterize the membranes' compositions, EDX analysis was performed, as the chemical compositions of neat PSf and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 are collected in Table 4. From the results, it is found that the neat PSf membrane is composed of 83.45 % of carbon (C), 11.09 % of oxygen (O), and 5.46 % of sulfur (S). Meanwhile, after the addition of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite into the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane, the membrane's composition significantly changed. Some new elementals are found in the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane's composition, including silicon (Si), zinc (Zn), manganese (Mn), and copper (Cu) with compositions of 0.22 %, 0.52 %, 0.34 %, and 0.06 %, respectively. These newly recorded elementals have correlations with the oxide compositions that contained the key oxide substances, i.e., SiO2, ZnO, and MnO2. These new recorded compounds also reflect that the addition of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst into the membrane was successful. Another essential piece of information from the EDX analysis is that the oxygen composition in the membrane increased after the addition of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst, meaning that the modified membrane contains richer oxygenated compounds. The rich oxygenated compounds on the membrane surface can enhance the membrane's hydrophilicity that leading to permeability improvement. In addition, the interfacial interaction between PSf and ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst is physical interaction that has a similar photocatalyst-polymer interaction with other reported studies [46,56,57]. Photocatalyst particles are attached physically to the matrix of PSf. It is obvious from the SEM images of the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane. Therefore, it can be concluded that there are no side reactions between photocatalyst and PSf matrix.
label: n

paragraph: Furthermore, EDX mapping distribution characterization is used to show the key elemental distribution in the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane. Fig. 4(a-f) reflect the elemental distributions of C, O, S, Zn, Mn, and Si, respectively. The dense distribution of C, O, and S confirms that the membrane is constructed by polysulfone, which is consisted of C, O, and S, as previously presented in Table 4. Furthermore, it can be seen that the elemental distributions across the membrane's surface are dispersed uniformly. The combined distribution of Zn, Mn, and Si also shows the remarkably well-dispersed elemental distribution, as represented in Fig. 4(g-h). The prominent dispersion of photocatalysts on the membrane surface can prevent particle aggregations. In this study, the photocatalyst dispersion is obtained by performing a constant agitation and conducting a 60,000 Hz ultrasonic homogenizer prior to the membrane casting. The ultrasonic waves are responsible for making the photocatalyst's dispersion in the dope solution, hence, preventing the agglomeration of the photocatalyst's particles. In the conventional membrane filtration, uniformly distributed photocatalyst on the membrane's surface controlled the surface hydrophilicity, while in the photocatalytic filtration, the uniform photocatalyst distribution also provides more extensive availability of active sites across the membrane's surface to boost the photodegradation of the pollutants. This photodegradation mechanism on the membrane's surface is helpful in fouling mitigation, thus, can improve the membrane's performance and durability.
label: n

paragraph: AFM analysis was used to investigate the surface roughness of the neat PSf and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membranes, as the results are presented in Fig. 5. The brighter region on the images reflects the relatively higher area, whereas the darker region means vice-versa. In two-dimension surface profiles, some quantitative properties are estimated, including the average surface roughness (Sa), root mean square of height data (Sq), and the height difference between the lowest and the highest peak (Sz). It can be seen that the neat PSf membrane attributed to a relatively smooth surface with 0.473 nm in Sa and 7.21 in Sz. In contrast, the modified PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane shows a rougher surface with a Sa value of 1.70 nm and Sz value of 31.7 nm, which is approximately 3.5 times rougher surface than that of the neat PSf membrane, as shown in the three-dimensional AFM images (right side). The increment in surface roughness can be caused by the relative porosity of the membrane and a change of interaction between solvent and non-solvent in the presence of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite. A membrane with a rougher surface possesses a larger filtration area [58]; thus, it can increase the membrane's permeability. The rougher membrane surface also reflects the presence of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalysts. The peak distribution is distributed uniformly, as it agrees well with the EDX mapping results and also indicates the massive availability of the active sites to perform the photocatalytic process.
label: n

paragraph: The crystalline structure of the neat PSf and modified PSf membranes with embedded photocatalysts were characterized using XRD analysis, as the results are represented in Fig. 6. It is found that the diffractogram patterns of all membranes show a similar pattern as the neat PSf. The patterns of all membranes exhibit a broad peak around diffraction angle from 15deg to 20deg [59]. This broad peak is a typical peak indicating the polysulfone polymer's backbone. The neat PSf membrane possesses a smooth diffractogram pattern without any distinct peaks, indicating that the neat PSf membrane is constructed by an amorphous polymer structure that is free from any crystal structure. Meanwhile, the modified membranes with photocatalysts addition demonstrate some tiny peaks on their diffractogram patterns, suggesting the presence of some crystallite sites from the photocatalysts on the polymer structures. For example, the diffractogram of PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane exhibits some tiny peaks at diffractogram angles of 31deg and 37deg that indicate the crystallite sites of ZnO, and a peak at 49deg signifies the crystallite of MnO2[27,28]. The observed weak tiny peaks can be associated with the uniformly dispersed photocatalyst across the membrane; thus, the detected peaks were not entirely prominent. This finding is supported by the EDX mapping results, as previously discussed.
label: n

paragraph: FTIR analysis was performed to analyze the developed functional groups in the fabricated membranes over a frequency range of 4000-450 cm-1. The FTIR spectra for the neat PSf and modified PSf membranes with embedded photocatalysts are depicted in Fig. 7. It can be visually observed that all the FTIR spectra of the membranes have a similar pattern, meaning that the membranes were constructed with the same polymer. The observed peaks consistently reflect the typical functional groups of polysulfone, such as a peak at 1585 cm-1, which corresponds to the stretching vibration of CH groups, and peaks at 1448 and 1241 cm-1 that belong to the stretching vibrations of OS = O groups of polysulfone [42]. From FTIR spectrum of M-04, which is PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, shows notable small peaks at 2974 and 1074 cm-1, which correspond to the Zn-O and Mn-O bonds, respectively, confirming the existence of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite.
label: n

paragraph: Pore properties characterization is important to evaluate the effect of photocatalyst loading on the physical properties of the fabricated membranes. Evaluations of thickness, porosity, and average pore size of the membranes are essential because these parameters cause some influences on the permeability, sorption of water, selectivity, and even the fouling tendency of the fabricated membranes [55]. Table 5 summarizes the results regarding the pore properties of the membranes. It is found that the photocatalysts doping increased the thickness of the fabricated membranes, from 35.43 um for the neat PSf to 46.31, 43.70, and 45.83 um for PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2. This can be caused by the swelling effects in the polymer structure of the membranes upon the addition of photocatalysts, thus, resulting in thicker membrane layers. The porosity parameter shows a similar trend with the thickness. The porosity of the membranes significantly increased with the addition of photocatalysts, from 42.16 % for the neat PSf to 63.13, 56.33, and 72.31 % for PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. The higher porosity of the modified membranes is promoted by the creation of void sites in the membrane body when phase inversion occurs. The photocatalysts are helpful in creating more gaps in the membrane body during phase inversion. These findings are also evident in the cross-sectional morphology of the membranes. The membranes with embedded photocatalysts have a similar porous and finger-like structure that makes it possible to create a more porous structure, as previously discussed. PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane possessed the highest porosity among other membranes, indicating that the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite can provide higher void formation during the phase inversion process compared to the pristine ZnO and MnO2. Membranes with higher porosity can perform better sorption of water and hydrophilicity, which can improve permeability. Additionally, the membranes' average pore radii were evaluated. Based on the results, it can be observed that the addition of photocatalysts into the membranes causes a slight increment in the average pore size from 40.32 nm for the neat PSf to 48.11, 45.78, and 42.76 nm for PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. This phenomenon can be correlated as the side effect of the gap formations due to the doping of photocatalysts. The formed gaps in the membrane's body are possible to increase the distribution of wider pores, which results in the larger average pore size of the modified membranes. Naturally, membranes with bigger pore sizes can generate lower selectivity. Nevertheless, the rise of the membrane's pore size is not too extreme; therefore, the negative impacts of pore size rising are not significant. It is also noteworthy that all membranes can be classified into ultrafiltration (UF) types since their average pore sizes still fall in the range of 10 to 100 nm.
label: n

paragraph: Mechanical strength analysis is quite critical to show the robustness of the membrane when they are used in the actual filtration condition. The membranes' mechanical properties also have correlations with the durability and service life during application for wastewater treatment. The membranes' mechanical properties, including tensile strength and elongation at break were evaluated, as the results are depicted in Fig. 8(a). It is found that the tensile strengths of the membranes are 4.73, 4.31, 4.26, and 4.68 MPa, and the elongation at breaks values of 45.03, 42.30, 38.72, and 43.70 % for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. Based on the results, it can be seen that the addition of photocatalysts relatively reduced the tensile strength and elongation at break of the membranes. This phenomenon is explainable that the photocatalyst sites in the polymer matrix create gaps between the polymer structure, which then weaken the polymer chains [60]. Corroboratively, based on the EDX and XRD results, they signify the presence of the crystallite sites in the modified membranes upon the photocatalyst addition. Due to the more gaps formed and the presence of crystallite sites, the polymer matrix structure becomes weaker, more brittle, and less elastic, which results in a reduction in tensile strength and elongation at break. The modified membranes PSf/ZnO and PSf/MnO2 have a little bit lower mechanical strength compared to that of the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane. It is explainable by the SEM results that found some aggregation structure of the photocatalysts in the cross-sectional image of PSf/ZnO and PSf/MnO2 membranes. The aggregations create gaps between the polysulfone matrix and weaken the mechanical strength of the membrane, while in the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane, the photocatalyst dispersion is much better. Hence, the mechanical properties of the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane are better than the other two modified membranes. Furthermore, previous studies suggested not to add inorganic fillers with a concentration of >2 %-wt because it can reduce the membrane's mechanical strength and also possibly cause agglomerations [61]. Nonetheless, the decrease of mechanical properties in the modified membranes was not too bad. Since the applied pressure on filtration was set at 5 bar (~0.5 MPa), which is still far below the critical tensile strength of all membranes; thus, the membranes' mechanical strength is acceptable, and all membranes can still be applied for the filtration process.
label: n

paragraph: Hydrophilicity is an essential characteristic of membrane-based technology for water and wastewater treatment applications. The hydrophilicity of the membranes explains the surface behavior of the water molecules. In this present work, the hydrophilicity of the membranes was examined using water contact angle measurement, as the results are depicted in Fig. 8(b). It is found that the water contact angles of the membranes were 81.55deg, 71.43deg, 73.21deg, and 65.59deg for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membranes, respectively. It can be seen that with the photocatalysts' addition, the water contact angle was significantly reduced. The lower value of water contact angle means a more hydrophilic surface characteristic. Hydrophilic membrane surface can generate more permeate water and also can mitigate the fouling tendency, especially for highly polluted wastewater [62]. The neat PSf membrane possessed the lowest water contact angle, suggesting that the natural character of polysulfone is less hydrophilic; thus, it is not recommended to use the pristine PSf membrane without any modifications for wastewater treatment purposes. PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane appeared as the most hydrophilic membrane, suggesting the lowest contact angle among other membranes. This can be due to the rich contained oxygenated groups such as Zn-O and Mn-O and the uniformly dispersed ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst sites on the surface of PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane, as revealed by FTIR, XRD, and EDX mapping results. The rich oxygenated groups and photocatalyst sites perform strong attraction van der Waals forces to the water molecules, thus, subsequently can enhance the membrane's permeability [62,63]. The better hydrophilicity of PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane compared to PSf/ZnO and PSf/MnO2 is promoted by the higher surface energy. Fig. 8(c) shows the estimated surface energy of the fabricated membranes. The estimated surface energies were 6.73, 23.54, 19.60, and 44.17 for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. Surface energy shows the magnitude of attraction force of the surface towards water molecules [64]. Higher surface energy correlates with the hydrophilic surface; thus, the membrane with higher surface energy has better hydrophilicity (lower contact angle). In a similar shape, the water uptake ability improved on the membranes with embedded photocatalysts. It is found that the water uptake abilities were 39.77 %, 65.22 %, 61.75 %, and 70.43 % for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. The neat PSf possessed the lowest, whereas PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 showed the highest water uptake ability. Hydrophilicity and porosity play an equally dominant for the sorption ability. The PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 showed outstanding hydrophilicity and porosity; thus, the water molecules can rapidly fill the void space inside the membrane. This intense water sorption ability can also be helpful in enhancing the membrane's permeability.
label: n

paragraph: Initial checking of the effect of photocatalytic properties of the membranes on the membrane performance was carried out by determining pure water flux (PWF). The filtration experiments were performed by filtering DI water for 120 min and were carried out in the dark and under UV light irradiation conditions. Fig. 8(d) presents the results of PWF for all membranes. In the dark filtration condition, it can be observed that the PWF value is higher in the modified membranes with photocatalysts compared to the neat PSf. The measured average PWF values were 17.43, 26.35, 23.28, and 28.74 L.m-2.h-1 for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. Under UV light irradiation conditions, PWF values further increase only in the membranes with embedded photocatalysts. The measured PWFs under UV light irradiation was 17.58, 29.01, 25.21, 31.97 L.m-2.h-1 for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 for respectively. These findings indicate that UV irradiation can improve the PWF in the membrane with embedded photocatalysts. The PWF improvement in membranes with embedded photocatalysts is caused by the increase of hydrophilicity during UV light irradiation. In the photocatalyst, the photo-induced holes can oxidize the superoxide radicals and create oxygen vacancies [65,66]. These oxygen vacancies tend to attract water molecules and generate adsorbed hydroxyl (OH) groups, thus enhancing the surface hydrophilicity [64,65]. The higher surface hydrophilicity led to providing a stronger attraction force to water molecules [64], which resulted in an improved PWF.
label: n

paragraph: Permeability profiles upon treating NRW using the fabricated membranes in the dark (conventional) and under UV light irradiation were thoroughly studied. The conventional filtration in the dark environment was conducted as the control variable, whereas the UV light irradiation was aimed to initiate the photocatalytic reaction on the membrane's surface. Fig. 9(a-d) compile the permeability profiles of neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membranes, respectively, in the dark and under UV light irradiation conditions. It is found that the neat PSf membrane (MM-01) shows insignificant permeability profile differences between in the dark and under UV light conditions. It obviously signifies that pristine PSf polymer is not a photocatalytic material. Meanwhile, improvements in permeability are observed in the membrane with the embedded photocatalysts. The modified membranes with embedded photocatalysts show distinct improvements in permeability after being irradiated by UV light. The UV light irradiation seems to have significant effects on increasing the permeability of the modified membranes. In the membranes with a single photocatalyst, PSf/ZnO membrane (MM-02) exhibited better permeability than that of PSf/MnO2 (MM-03) in the dark and under UV light irradiation. PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 exhibited the best and most stable permeability performance among other membranes. This membrane achieved a permeate flux of 23.54 L.m-2.h-1 in the dark condition, then improved to 27.31 L.m-2.h-1 when it was performed under UV light irradiation condition, as depicted in Fig. 9(d).
label: n

paragraph: It is also found that the modified membranes with embedded photocatalysts not only performed better permeability in photo-filtration conditions but also enhanced the permeability in conventional dark filtration conditions compared to the neat PSf membrane. This occurrence can be caused by some reasons. First, the embedded photocatalysts increase the surface hydrophilicity of the membranes, thus, enhancing the surface attraction forces to the water molecule and then generating higher permeability. Second, the rougher membrane due to photocatalysts addition creates a larger filtration area and increases the contact between water and photocatalysts' sites. Third, the addition of photocatalysts generates higher porosity and water uptake ability; thus, the modified membranes can absorb more water, which results in higher permeate flux. Fourth, when the modified membranes are irradiated under UV light, the photocatalyst initiates a photocatalytic process, which subsequently generates radical molecules to degrade the attached pollutants on the membrane surface; thus, the filtration process is not disturbed by the deposited pollutants. The fifth reason is that the photo-generated holes during photocatalysis can produce the superoxide radicals and create the oxygen vacancies on the active sites [65,66], thus subsequently increasing the surface hydrophilicity and permeability. In conclusion, in the dark filtration condition, surface hydrophilicity, pore properties, sorption ability, and surface roughness control the permeability of the membranes, whereas, in the photo-filtration condition under UV light, the photocatalytic process dominates the control of the permeability of the membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The removal efficiency by membrane filtration was evaluated by measuring the pollutant concentrations at the initial and the end of the process. In this study, NRW was used as the feed water, and the removal efficiency was measured based on some pollutant parameters, including TDS, phenol, COD, and NH3-N contents. The pollutant removal performance of the neat PSf and modified membranes are shown in Fig. 10. It can be observed that the membranes with different embedded photocatalysts show different removal abilities. The modified membranes with photocatalysts exhibit higher removal efficiency either in the dark or under UV light conditions compared to that of the neat PSf membrane. Furthermore, UV light irradiation improves the removal efficiencies of the modified membranes. In the dark condition, the neat PSf membrane removes 22.31 %, 18.75 %, 28.73 %, and 20.51 % of TDS, phenol, COD, and NH3-N, respectively. When the UV irradiation was performed in the neat PSf membrane, no noticeable improvements were captured. In contrast, the modified membranes with photocatalysts showed distinct enhancement when they were irradiated by UV light during the filtration experiment. PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane presents the best pollutant removal among the other membranes under UV light irradiation and in dark conditions, as shown in Fig. 10(d). In the conventional filtration condition, the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane exhibits 59.31 %, 53.43 %, 60.18 %, and 58.44 % of TDS, phenol, COD, and NH3-N removals, respectively, whereas, under UV light irradiation the removal efficiencies increase to 73.26 %, 68.33 %, 78.92 %, and 75.69 % for TDS, phenol, COD, and NH3-N removals, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: After being performed under UV light irradiation, the improved pollutant removals occurred for some reasons. First, the photocatalytic degradation process can be helpful in improving pollutant removal. The photo-generated radicals, either superoxide (0O2-) or hydroxyl (0OH) in the active sites (embedded photocatalysts), can react with the pollutant molecules by redox reaction and degrade them into small molecules [53]. Second, the defect-free surface and uniformly distributed photocatalyst on the membrane surface are also valuable for performing better pollutant removal. Third, the highly hydrophilic sites on the modified membrane surface also improved the pollutant rejection by performing repulsion forces against the pollutant (organic matter), which usually presents in different polarities [66]. Since the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite shows a prominent semiconductor property by attributing bandgap energy of 2.65 eV, uniformly distributed photocatalysts particles on the membrane surface, and the highly hydrophilic surface, the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane appears as the best membrane in pollutant removal compared to other membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Effects of adsorption and photocatalysis on photodegradation performance of the neat PSf and modified membranes were evaluated. This evaluation was done by measuring the pollutant removal, including phenol, COD, and NH3-N, under UV light conditions. The changing of concentration profiles (Ct/Co) for the tested membranes are shown in Fig. 11. It is found that prior to the UV light being turned on, there are small removals that occurred on all three pollutant parameters on the membranes with embedded photocatalysts. The removal before UV light irradiation can correspond to the occurrence of surface adsorption. This finding shows that the active sites of the photocatalysts can also perform pollutant adsorption besides photocatalysis. The rich oxygenated sites on the membrane surface also generate strong van der Waals attraction forces to the charged pollutant molecules, thus, resulting in adsorption performance [64,67]. Interestingly, the membrane embedded by ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 shows a slightly higher adsorption effect compared to other photocatalysts. This result is in agreement with the BET-BJH analysis, which reflects the more comprehensive sorption range and specific surface area that boosted the adsorption performance of the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane. Moreover, after the UV lamp was turned on, the pollutant degradations significantly improved, specifically in the membranes with embedded photocatalysts. In this state, photocatalysis plays the dominant role in pollutant removals. It is observed that the PSf membrane shows insignificant removal ability during the process, which signifies that the PSf membrane has no photocatalytic characteristics whatsoever. The modified membranes present the improved pollutant removal performance under UV light exposure and strengthen the finding that photocatalysis is far too dominant in the photodegradation of pollutants compared to the adsorption process.
label: n

paragraph: The characteristics of photodegradation of pollutants were evaluated further using two kinetics models, including the zero order and pseudo-first order models. These evaluations were done by determining the pollutants degradation rates of the fabricated membranes. Initially, the membrane sheet was mounted onto the glass holder and immersed in the NRW sample. This experiment was performed in a dark and closed chamber utilized with a UV lamp (see Fig. 1(b)). Before the UV lamp was turned on, the membrane was left in the NRW sample for 60 min in order to achieve the adsorption equilibrium state for ensuring that only the photocatalysis was performed for the pollutant removal. Fig. 12 (a-f) show the fitting plots of degradation kinetic on phenol, COD, and NH3-N removals, respectively, using zero-order and pseudo-first order kinetics, whereas the fitting parameters are listed in Table 6. Based on the results, it is observed that the neat PSf membrane (MM-01) did not show any removal performance under this photocatalytic experiment. The photocatalytic degradations of pollutants remarkably improved in the modified membranes with the embedded photocatalysts (MM-02 - MM-04). In addition, the pollutants' degradation rates of the membranes using both models follow this order: MM-04 > MM-02 > MM-03  MM-01. A higher rate constant represents faster photocatalytic degradation can be obtained. This indicates that the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 has the strongest photocatalytic power compared to other membranes. From the average coefficient of determinations (R2avg), it is found that the pseudo-first order kinetic model is a better fit than the zero order. R2avg values of pseudo-first order are 0.9489, 0.9394, and 0.9668 for phenol, COD, and NH3-N, respectively, whereas for the zero-order are 0.9401, 0.9338, and 0.9646 for phenol, COD, and NH3-N, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: In common heterogeneous photocatalytic degradation, reactive species including holes, superoxide, and hydroxyl radicals are the main substances to degrade the pollutants. In this study, trapping tests were performed to investigate further the relevance, existence, and relative activity of the reactive species on pollutant degradations. Oxalic acid, benzoquinone, and methanol were used as the scavengers for holes, superoxide, and hydroxyl radicals, respectively [45]. Fig. 13(a-c) depict the effect of scavengers on phenol, COD, and NH3-N degradations using PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membranes, respectively. It can be observed that the scavengers reduce the photodegradation efficiency on all membranes. This means that the scavengers disrupt the active species to react with pollutants. The relative order of active species' effects on photocatalytic degradation can be ordered as h+ > 0O2- > 0OH. It is also found that all active species play essential roles in pollutant degradation; eliminating one of them resulted in the reduction of degradation efficiency.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 14 illustrates the proposed mechanisms of the photocatalytic process using the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite. ZnO-MnO2 plays a vital role in the photocatalysis reaction, while SiO2 provides the adsorption of pollutant molecules to be closer to the photocatalyst, resulting in easier and faster degradation of pollutants [53]. In specific, when the composite is irradiated with photon energy from UV light, the electrons (e-) are excited from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB). In the CB, the photo-induced electrons transferred from the higher potential of ZnO to the lower potential of MnO2, while in the VB, the empty sites filled with the photo-induced holes (h+) that transferred from VB of ZnO to VB of MnO2[68]. In Fig. 14(a), it is observed that the CB of MnO2 is more positive than the energy level for superoxide radical (0O2-) generations; hence, the reduction reaction to generate 0O2- has less possibility of taking place on the CB of MnO2. Due to the excellent electron conductivity of MnO2, some electrons reacted with Mn4+ ions to form Mn3+[69]. Then, the Mn3+ ion can react with O2 to form Mn4+ and 0O2-. The VBs of ZnO and MnO2 appear more positive than the potential energy to generate hydroxyl radicals (0OH); therefore, the oxidation reaction can take place, as reflected in Fig. 14(a). In the VB of MnO2, the photo-induced holes reacted with water (H2O) or hydroxyl (OH-) molecules through an oxidation reaction to produce the hydroxyl radicals (0OH). As both generated radicals have strong reactivity, 0O2- and 0OH radicals reacted with pollutants to degrade them and resulting in CO2, H2O, and mineral acids as the products [28]. An illustration of mechanisms of pollutant degradation by the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite by heterojunction pathway under UV light irradiation can be seen in Fig. 14(b). The detailed mechanisms of the photocatalytic process of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 are as follows:
label: n

paragraph: Role of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite:(16)ZnO+hv-e-(ZnO)+h+(ZnO)(17)MnO2+hv-e-(MnO2)+h+(MnO2)
label: n

paragraph: Role of manganese ions:(18)Mn4++e--Mn3+
label: n

paragraph: Radical formations:(19)Mn3++O2-Mn4++*O2-(20)H2O+h+-H++*OH(21)OH-+h+-*OH
label: n

paragraph: Pollutant degradations:(22)Pollutants+*O2--Degraded products(CO2,H2O,mineral acids)(23)Pollutants+*OH-Degraded products(CO2,H2O,mineral acids)
label: n

paragraph: To assess the stability of the flux and pollutant rejection performance, the membranes were used to treat the NRW sample for 15 h, and the flux and pollutant rejection were calculated during this assessment, as the results are shown in Fig. 15(a). Based on Fig. 15(a), it is found that in the dark condition, the pristine PSf membrane (MM-01) experienced an extreme flux reduction during the period from 16.67 L.m-2.h-1 at the beginning of the process and leaving a pseudo-static permeability of 2.02 L.m-2.h-1 after going through 15 h of filtration. Meanwhile, in the same dark condition of filtration, PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane (MM-04) exhibited a significant improvement in the permeability compared to the neat PSf membrane. This membrane experienced a starting flux of 23.50 L.m-2.h-1 and maintained a pseudo-static flux of about 6.89 L.m-2.h-1 afterward. It is explainable by the increase of the membrane's hydrophilicity after being embedded by the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 nanoparticles, which play a key role in boosting the permeability of the membrane, especially in the dark (conventional) filtration condition. However, the membrane still struggled to maintain high and stable permeability, which signifies the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane in the dark condition has a limited capability to tackle fouling formation. Further permeability improvement was observed by irradiating the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane under UV light during the filtration process to carry out the photocatalytic activity of the membrane. It is found that the magnitude of the flux of this membrane is the highest compared to MM-01 (dark) and MM-04 (dark). Under UV light exposure, the membrane achieved an initial flux of 27.12 L.m-2.h-1 and can perfectly maintain a pseudo-static flux of 18.02 L.m-2.h-1 until the end of the filtration period. The UV irradiation on the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane also exhibited an outstanding pollutant removal ability. It is found that the pollutants removal of MM-04 (UV) was 74.31 %, 70.25 %, 80.93 %, and 76.55 % for removals of TDS, phenol, COD, and NH3-N, respectively. This finding suggests that UV irradiation triggered a photocatalysis reaction on the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite on the surface of the membrane, which destroyed the concentrated contaminants, thus, making it easier for water molecules to move through the membrane as well as contributing to improving the pollutant removal performance [70,71].
label: n

paragraph: The reusability test using three consecutive cycles of filtration was performed under UV light irradiation, and the results are presented in Fig. 15(b). At the starting point of the test, the measured permeabilities were 16.67, 23.55, 21.10, and 27.11 L.m-2.h-1 for neat PSf (MM-01), PSf/ZnO (MM-02), PSf/MnO2 (MM-03), and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 (MM-04), respectively. Based on the results, the neat PSf membrane experienced the lowest permeability and lack of flux recovery in the next cycles, which suggests that the neat PSf membrane is susceptible to fouling. Other membranes with embedded nanoparticles show improvements in the magnitude of permeability and flux recovery ability. After two cycles, the measured permeabilities at the beginning of the third cycle were 9.97, 18.55, 17.82, and 25.33 L.m-2.h-1, whereas, at the end of the cycle test, it was found that the membrane permeabilities were 1.55, 9.45, 7.32, and 17.03 L.m-2.h-1 for neat PSf, PSf/ZnO, PSf/MnO2, and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2, respectively. Hence, it is noteworthy that the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 appears as the best membrane in flux magnitude, stability, retrievability, and reusability compared to other membranes. Fig. 15(c-e) present the results of photocatalytic degradation abilities of the membranes upon three process cycles. It is found that different membranes exhibited different profiles of pollutant degradations. It can be observed that PSf/MnO2 shows the weakest photodegradation ability compared to PSf/ZnO and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2. It can be correlated to the weak absorption capacity of UV light energy by the membrane composite as revealed by UV-vis DRS results, thus, making it struggles to perform the photocatalytic process. On the other hand, PSf/ZnO and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membranes demonstrated the stronger photodegradation ability and retrievability under UV light irradiation. This is strongly correlated due to a strong UV light energy absorption capacity by these membranes [57]. PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 experienced the best pollutant degradation efficiency and showed nice degradation stability in three cycles of the process. Therefore, these results indicate that the fabricated photocatalytic composite membranes, particularly the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane, it has an excellent and long-lasting photocatalytic ability, which is desirable for NRW treatment.
label: n

paragraph: The antifouling properties of the fabricated membranes were evaluated through several parameters, including flux profile under certain conditions, resistance during filtration measurement, flux recovery ratio, and the ratio between reversible and irreversible fouling, as the results are compiled in Fig. 16. Fig. 16(a) represents the results of flux profiles under different conditions of filtration. Ji shows the initial pure water flux, Ja represents the pure water flux after the membrane was immersed in the NRW sample to cause static fouling, Jf represents the pure water flux after the membrane was used for NRW filtration, and Jv is the flux of actual NRW filtration [46]. According to the results, it can be seen that the modified membranes with photocatalysts show higher flux values compared to the neat PSf both in the dark and under UV light exposure, indicating the enhanced antifouling performance of the modified membranes. The maximum flux performance was achieved for the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane exposed to UV light irradiation, which can be due to the occurrence of photocatalytic reaction in the nanoparticle composite. This mechanism creates a maximum capability to degrade the attached foulants, resulting in a reduction of membrane resistance, thus creating higher permeability of the membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The partial elements of membrane resistance, including intrinsic (Rm), adsorptive (Ra), deposition (Rd), and concentration polarization (Rcp) resistances in the dark and under UV light conditions of filtration were assessed, and the results are depicted in Fig. 16(b). The neat PSf and PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 demonstrated the maximum and minimum membrane resistance in all conditions, respectively. In membrane filtration, lower resistance is more desirable in order to generate a higher permeate flux rate. When PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane was exposed to UV light irradiation, the resistance was reduced by about 52.43 % compared to the same membrane in the dark filtration condition. Moreover, the resistance reduction occurred in all constituting elements of resistance, suggesting that the photocatalytic properties of the membrane play an important role in preventing the formation of fouling on the membrane.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 16(c) depicts the total fouling ratio (RT), reversible fouling ratio (RR), irreversible fouling ratio (RIr), and permeate flux recovery ratio (FRR) of the membranes in the dark and under UV light exposure. The modified membranes exhibited lower fouling ratios compared to the corresponding value of the neat PSf membrane. Furthermore, the FRR of all modified membranes irradiated with UV light was higher than that of the neat PSf membrane, suggesting the improved antifouling activities of the modified membranes due to the photocatalytic process by degrading concentrated pollutants on the membrane's surface to prevent the fouling formation. However, no significant improvement regarding the antifouling properties of the neat PSf membrane (MM-01) was observed when it was irradiated with UV light. It is due to the fact that the neat PSf is not classified as a photocatalytic material. The values of RR and RIr of the modified membranes were lower than that of neat PSf. As an example, the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 (MM-04) has the RT value of 34.27 % in the dark condition, which consists of 44.15 % of RR and 55.85 % of RIr. Once it was irradiated with UV light, the total fouling ratio reduced to 21.26 % which 73.52 % is relevant to RR and 26.48 % is relevant to RIr. The declined RT value indicates that the modified membrane is more capable of preventing fouling occurrence [72]. Moreover, the reduction of irreversible fouling proportion when the membrane was exposed to UV light suggests that the pore blocking in the membrane by the pollutant molecules can be reduced due to the photocatalytic degradation effect of the ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 composite on the membrane's surface. In comparison with irreversible fouling, the reversible fouling on the membrane is repairable and easier to treat by a simple method such as conventional rinsing [42]. Therefore, performing the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane under UV light irradiation significantly improved the antifouling properties to prevent fouling formation and prolong the usability of the membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The basic properties and key findings of the prepared PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 irradiated under UV light that tested in the photocatalytic membrane filtration system are compared with other similar studies in the literature as summarized in Table 7. As comprised in Table 7, relative to other photocatalytic composite membranes, PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane shows comparable improvements in permeability, pollutant removal, flux stability, photocatalytic ability, and antifouling properties. Synergetic outstanding surface characteristics such as roughness, wettability, and porosity with photocatalytic activity from of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite resulted in those significant improvements. The utilization of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst composite in PSf for treating the highly polluted NRW was not the case in other reported studies in the literature. In conclusion, this present study can provide new insight into treating the contaminated water using integrated filtration and photocatalysis in a single membrane composite.
label: n

paragraph: This present study investigates the effects of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst addition in the polysulfone (PSf) membrane that performed a combined membrane filtration and photocatalytic process under UV light irradiation for natural rubber-laden wastewater (NRW) treatment. The photocatalyst composites were synthesized using the sol-gel method, and the membranes were prepared using the phase inversion technique. SEM and EDX mapping results show that the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane exhibited a smooth surface with a well-constructed finger-like structure and a pretty uniform dispersion of photocatalysts elementals on its surface. AFM results support the finding that the addition of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst resulted in a rougher surface image that increased the contact area, thus, boosting the membrane's permeability. Several new polar functional groups such as Zn-O, Mn-O, and Si-O-Si were confirmed in the FTIR spectrum of PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane. DRS results showed that the MnO2 doping in ZnO successfully improved the photo-sensitivity and photocatalytic activity of the composite, suggesting the reduction of the bandgap energy from 3.10 eV to 2.65 eV, which promoted the photocatalytic improvement. The addition of ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 photocatalyst also improved the membrane porosity, hydrophilicity, water uptake ability, and mechanical strength. Furthermore, the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane also exhibited enhanced performance on permeate flux, pollutant rejection, and photo-degradation ability. Reactive species (h+, 0O2-, 0OH) contributed as the photo-degradation agents. The photocatalytic kinetic evaluation suggested that the pollutant degradation behavior showed a better fit using the pseudo-first order kinetic model rather than the zero-order model, with the highest photocatalytic degradation rate achieved by PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane. Performing the PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane under UV light irradiation significantly improved the flux stability, membrane recyclability, and antifouling properties to prevent the fouling formation and prolong the usability of the membrane. In conclusion, according to all characteristics and performance, PSf/ZnO-MnO2@SiO2 membrane is found to be the most promising UV light-driven photocatalytic membrane for effective NRW treatment.
label: n
