paragraph: The wastewater produced by manufacturing is harmful for environment and wild and human health [1,2]. Pulp and paper industry is one of the most polluting industry in the world, consuming more than 900 million m3 of fresh water and disposing around 700 million m3 of wastewater per year [3]. During the production of paper in a thermomechanical pulp mill, a process water (ThMP), mainly consisting of hemicellulose and lignin, is leaving the mill to be treated at a wastewater treatment plant [4]. However, hemicellulose is considered a valuable polymeric compound, and if recovered from the process water it can be used for other purposes. There are many potential application areas for hemicellulose, such as oxygen barrier films, food coatings, hydrogels or biomedical applications [5,6]. For these applications, it is desired to purify the hemicellulose from lignin and low molecular weight compounds such as extractives and salts. Membrane filtration has previously been selected as a promising pretreatment method of this feed solution [4,7]. However, the separation of hemicellulose using membranes is challenging due to membrane fouling related issues [8-10]. Membrane fouling results in a significant decrease in total flux, along with the possibility of a complete loss of operational properties. Therefore, it is of high interest to produce and evaluate membranes with antifouling properties for the filtration of ThMP process water, to contribute to the development and implementation of membrane filtration processes in large-scale industries.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane hydrophilization is one of the widely used techniques for fouling mitigating. It can be carried out by coating [13] and grafting [14] as well as using hydrophilic polymers [15], co-polymers [16], oligomers [17] and nanoparticles [18] via blending technique. Both coating and grafting techniques require additional modification steps [19,20], that complicates the industrial production of membranes. Membranes modified via blending, e.g., by hydrophilic polymers [21], are often characterized by the washing out of the hydrophilization agent due to their affinity to water during the phase separation and further operation and are not effective for surface hydrophilization.
label: n

paragraph: Surface modification is an efficient method for membrane modification due to the location of the modification agent on the selective layer surface as well as on the pore walls of the selective layer and the possibility of agent to directly contact with the feed solution, resulting in more efficient separation and enhanced antifouling performance. Antifouling membrane performance could be improved by reducing the surface roughness, hydrophilization of the membrane surface and changing the surface charge [11,12].
label: n

paragraph: Polyelectrolytes are promising for membrane modification for improving membrane antifouling stability due to the presence of the hydrophilic and charged groups. When polyelectrolyte macromolecules are included in the membrane structure, they feasibly form a hydrated layer on the membrane surface and prevent fouling. Moreover, their ability to change the conformation, when external conditions are varied, makes it possible to impart surface self-cleaning properties to membranes. Membrane modification using polyelectrolyte solutions is often carried out by layer-by-layer (LbL) technique [22,23]. Polyethylenimine (PEI) [24], polyacrylic acid (PAA) [25], poly(allyl amine) hydrochloride [26], poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) [27], poly(4-styrenesulfonic acid) [28] are often used for preparation of the selective layer of composite membranes for microfiltration [31], ultrafiltration [29], nanofiltration [30], or reverse osmosis [32] via LbL technique.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane modification via the addition of the polyelectrolytes and hydrophilic polymers into the coagulant in non-solvent induced phase separation (NIPS) has shown to be a highly effective one-step method which requires no additional procedures [33-39]. It was reported that polyelectrolyte macromolecules added to the coagulation bath migrate to the surface of the nascent polymer membrane during non-solvent induced phase separation. Studies of the composition of the membrane selective layer revealed that polyelectrolyte macromolecules are mainly immobilized on the surface of the membrane selective layer as well as on the pore walls, but not on the surface of the bottom layer. This facilitates the formation of the thin layer of water molecules due to hydrogen bonding with hydrophilic groups of polyelectrolyte macromolecules immobilized on the selective layer surface which prevents the adsorption of the dissolved compounds during filtration. Thus, introduction of polyelectrolytes to the coagulation bath was found to be a facile, easy to carry out, cheap and effective method for reducing the membrane fouling [34-37].
label: n

paragraph: Liu et al. [33] suggested an one-step membrane preparation technique based on the modification of activated carboxylated poly(arylene ether ketone)s (PAEK-COOH) flat sheet membrane by crosslinking with PEI in the coagulation bath during the phase separation process. It was found that the membrane flux of the initial PAEK-COOH membrane was more than two times lower compared to the PEI modified membrane. Moreover, the water contact angle of the modified membrane selective layer was revealed to be 43deg, which was 20deg lower compared to the reference membrane. This is due to the immobilization of the hydrophilic PEI units on the membrane selective layer surface [33].
label: n

paragraph: Plisko et al. [34,35] and Hliavitskaya et al. [36,37] reported the modification of the polysulfone (PSf) and polyethersulfone (PES) ultrafiltration membranes, correspondingly, by addition of the cationic and anionic polyelectrolytes (commercially available flocculants) based on polyacrylamide containing poly(2-(acryloxy)ethyltrimethylammonium chloride) blocks (Praestol 859) [34,37] and poly(sodium acrylate) blocks (Praestol 2540) [35,36], in the coagulation bath during NIPS. It was found that polyelectrolyte macromolecules predominately immobilize on the surface of the selective layer and not on the bottom layer. It was shown that PSf membrane modifications by Praestol 859 and Praestol 2540 result in surface hydrophilization, surface roughness increase and greater negative zeta potential values at pH 7-10 compared to the reference membrane, as well as improvement of membrane antifouling stability in the ultrafiltration of human serum albumin solution, model humic acid solution and surface water ultrafiltration [34,35]. It was revealed that modifications of PES membranes with cationic and anionic flocculants Praestol led to decrease in water contact angle of the selective layer, increase in surface roughness and increase in membrane antifouling resistance in bovine serum albumin (BSA) solution [37] and during ThMP ultrafiltration [36,37]. Moreover, it was shown that PES membrane modifications by Praestol 859 and Praestol 2540 led to 2-7 [37] and 3-8 [36] times increase in flux, increase in fouling recovery ratio by 2 times and improvement of cleaning efficiency without decreasing membrane rejection with regard to hemicelluloses and lignin as reference components in ThMP ultrafiltration [36,37].
label: n

paragraph: He et al. [38] described an approach to obtain the antifouling layer on the membrane surface by a reaction enhanced surface segregation method. This technique included the addition of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) in the casting solution as a surface segregation agent and PAA as an additive in the coagulation bath. It was shown that application of PAA as an additive in the coagulation bath led to the significant surface hydrophilization, enhancing the negative surface charge and, besides, increasing flux recovery ratio values after oil-water emulsion and bovine serum albumin solution filtration [38].
label: n

paragraph: In this article, a further development of the method of PSf ultrafiltration membrane modification by addition of polyelectrolytes into the coagulation bath via NIPS was performed [34-37]. The goal of the study was to investigate in depth the effect of the concentration of PAA in the coagulation bath on the structure, hydrophilic-hydrophobic balance, zeta potential of the selective layer, separation performance and antifouling stability of the surface modified PSf membranes in humic acid solution and ThMP ultrafiltration. The novelty of this work is that the modification of PSf membranes using the addition of PAA to the coagulation bath is systematically studied for the first time. Moreover, the application of the developed PSf/PAA membranes for concentration of hemicelluloses from ThMP process water and study of the effect of PAA concentration in coagulation bath on the membrane separation performance, fouling resistance and cleaning efficiency has not been reported yet.
label: n

paragraph: Polysulfone (PSf, Ultrason S 6010, Mn = 55*kg mol-1, BASF), polyethylene glycol (PEG-400, Mn = 0.4 kg mol-1, BASF) and N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 99%, BASF) were used for membrane preparation without prior purification.
label: y

paragraph: Polyacrylic acid (PAA, Mn = 250*kg mol-1, Sigma-Aldrich) aqueous solutions were used for membrane surface modification and served as a coagulation bath. PAA concentrations in the coagulation bath were 0.4; 0.7; 1.0; 1.2; 1.5; 2.0 wt%. PAA solutions were prepared by dissolving selected amounts of PAA in distilled water at room temperature for 1 h using a magnetic stirrer.
label: y

paragraph: Membrane separation performance (rejection and flux) were investigated using aqueous solution of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP K-30, Mn = 40 kg mol-1, Sigma-Aldrich) and solution of lysozyme (Lys, Mn = 14.3 kg mol-1, Sigma-Aldrich) in a phosphate buffer (pH 7.2).
label: n

paragraph: 5*10-3 wt% humic acids solution (HAs) in tap water was used to evaluate the antifouling performance of the reference and modified membranes. The solution of HAs was obtained from the fertilizer "Hydrohumin" (Biochem, Belarus) which consists of the 50 wt% solution of humic acids in water.
label: n

paragraph: The thermomechanical pulp mill (ThMP) process water used for the ultrafiltration evaluations was provided by Stora Enso (Kvarnsveden Mill, Sweden). To avoid microbial growth, FennoCide BZ26 (Kemira, Helsinki, Finland) was added to the process water as a preservative. The composition of the ThMP process water is presented in Table 1.
label: n

paragraph: Kinematic viscosity (n, mm2*s-1) of the PAA aqueous solutions (0.15 wt%; 0.4 wt%; 0.5 wt%; 0.7 wt%; 1.0 wt%; 1.5 wt%. 2.0 wt%) at T = 20 degC was measured using Ubbelohde capillary viscometer (capillary diameter d = 0.56 mm).
label: n

paragraph: The polymer solution preparation technique was described in [40]. Polymer solution (20 wt% PSf, 10 wt% PEG-400 and 70 wt% DMAc) was applied on a glass plate using a casting knife with a gap height of 250 um at the room temperature. Distilled water and PAA aqueous solutions (0.4-2.0 wt%) were used as the coagulation bath during membrane preparation via NIPS. PAA concentrations in the coagulation bath and corresponding membrane abbreviations are presented in Table 2. Membranes were kept in distilled water at least for 24 h to remove the residual solvent.
label: y

paragraph: The time of membrane formation in NIPS was determined as the time from the moment of immersion of a nascent polymer film into the coagulation bath to the moment, when the precipitated membrane completely separates from the glass plate. Membrane formation time was determined for different coagulation bath compositions at T = 25 degC (Table 2).
label: y

paragraph: To study the composition of the selective layer and bottom layer of the membranes modified by the PAA addition to the coagulation bath Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) using frustrated total internal reflection method was applied. FTIR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Is50 IR Fourier spectrometer (Thermo Scientific(tm)) in the frequency range of 400-4000 cm-1 with an accuracy of 0.01 cm-1. The membrane samples were dried for five days before the FTIR studies.
label: n

paragraph: The water contact angles of flat-sheet ultrafiltration membranes were determined by the attached bubble method using a LK-1 goniometer ("Open Science", Russia). The membranes were fixed using double-sided tape in the optically transparent cuvette filled with MilliQ water in such a way that the studied surface was immersed in water and placed parallel the bottom of the cuvette. The bubble of air with the volume of 3 uL was produced with the microsyringe and it attached spontaneously to the membrane surface immersed in water. The geometric parameters of the bubble attached to the membrane surface were recorded with a camera after 60 s from the moment of attachment of the bubble and processed using the DropShape software. Measurements were performed selectively in triplicates for each membrane. Maximum measurement errors allowed were +- 2deg in variance.
label: n

paragraph: The membrane morphology (cross-section at different magnifications and the surface of membrane selective layer) was investigated using Phenom Pro scanning electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA) and Carl Zeiss scanning electron microscope. Membranes were cleaved by cryogenic fracturing in liquid nitrogen followed by the application of a gold layer using the cathode sputtering in a vacuum installation DSR (Vacccoat, UK).
label: n

paragraph: The surface structure of the membrane samples was studied using an atomic force microscope NT-MDT NTegra Maximus (NT-MDT Spectrum Instruments, Russia) equipped with standard silicon cantilevers and a rigidity of 15 N m-1.
label: n

paragraph: The zeta potential of the membrane selective layer was measured using a SurPASS 2 instrument (Anton Paar, Austria). An aqueous solution of KCl in MilliQ water with a concentration of 10-3 mol L-1 was used as the electrolyte. Zeta potential determination was carried out in the pH range from 2.5 to 10.0. Measured streaming potential data were converted to zeta potential with the Helmholtz-Smoluchowski equation using the instrument's software.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane pure water flux (PWF, L m-2 h-1) and flux of the studied feed solutions were calculated as a permeate volume per unit of the membrane area and per unit of time in ultrafiltration with stirring according to the Eq. 1[21,34-37].(1)J=VAt,where, J is the flux (L m-2 h-1), V is the permeate volume (L), A is the membrane effective surface area (m2), and t is the permeation time (h).
label: n

paragraph: The ultrafiltration studies were carried out at the room temperature, transmembrane pressure of 1 bar and stirrer velocity of 200 rpm in the Amicon type ultrafiltration cell with the effective membrane area 24.6 cm2. The ultrafiltration cell was equipped with magnetic stirrer; the pressure was created by balloon with nitrogen and controlled by manometer (Fig. S1, Supporting information). The ultrafiltration of pure water, PVP K-30, lysozyme and humic acids aqueous solutions was carried out in dead-end ultrafiltration mode with stirring.
label: n

paragraph: First, membranes were compacted for 30 min at 1 bar while pure water ultrafiltration with stirring. Directly after this, the membrane PWF was measured every 5 min until it became constant. This value was considered as membrane PWF. Thereafter, the water was replaced by either 0.3 wt% aqueous solution of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP K-30) or 0.5 wt% Lys solution in a phosphate buffer (pH 7.2). Flux (J, L m-2 h-1) and rejection coefficient (R, %) of the reference PSf and modified membranes were measured after 30 min of ultrafiltration at 1 bar and ambient temperature. The Lys contents were analyzed with an UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Metertech UV-VIS SP 8001) at a wavelength of 280 nm. The concentration of PVP K-30 was evaluated using a Rayleigh interferometer. The rejection was calculated using the Eq. 2:(2)R=1-CpCf,where Cp and Cf are concentrations of solutes in permeate and feed solution, respectively, which are proportional to optical densities.
label: n

paragraph: The membrane pH-sensitivity (dependence of pure water flux on the pH) was investigated by filtration of MilliQ water adjusted to different pH values (3, 5, 7, 9) using 0.1 M HCl and 0.1 M NaOH aqueous solutions. The procedure was the following: first, the studied membrane was pre-conditioned for 30 min while pure water ultrafiltration at 1 bar. Then, MilliQ water with pH 3 was placed into the filtration cell. The ultrafiltration was carried out for 30 min and flux was measured. Thereafter, MilliQ water with pH 5 was filled into the ultrafiltration cell and filtered for 30 min. The pure water flux was measured. The similar procedure was repeated for pH 7 and 9. Thereafter, MilliQ water was filtered during 30 min and the cycle started again. Overall, three filtration cycles were carried out to study reproducibility of the change of flux in response to the pH change.
label: n

paragraph: For the study of flux and rejection at least 5 membrane samples were measured and an average value was calculated. The relative error for flux measurement was found to be 5% and for rejection-0.5%.
label: n

paragraph: To evaluate antifouling performance of the PSf reference membrane and the PSf/PAA modified membranes 10-3 wt% HAs solution in tap water was used as a feed. MilliQ water was filtered for 30 min at 1 bar and stirrer velocity of 200 rpm to pre-condition the membranes and thereafter the PWF was measured. Then, the HAs solution was placed into the ultrafiltration cell. While filtration of 5*10-3 wt% HAs solution in tap water for 1 h, flux (JHAs, L m-2 h-1) and rejection coefficients were determined every 10 min. After that the membranes were cleaned with MilliQ water during 30 min of ultrafiltration and the PWF was determined. The flux recovery ratio (FRR, %) and total flux decline ratio (DT, %) were calculated according to Eqs. (3) and (4), correspondingly:(3)FRR=JWFPWF100%,(4)DT=PWF-JHAsPWF100%,where JWF is water flux of the washed membrane, L m-2 h-1, JHAs is the HAs solution flux, L m-2 h-1.
label: n

paragraph: Characteristics of the initial HAs solution in the tap water are presented in Table 3.
label: n

paragraph: The spectrophotometer UV/VISSP8001 (Metertech, USA) was used to analyze the optical density of HAs feed solution and permeate at the wavelength of 400 nm. Iron content was determined by an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (Vista PRO, USA).
label: n

paragraph: The UF experimental setup used for the filtration of ThMP process water included a 15 L feed tank with temperature regulation by a temperature control unit (Model MCM, Shinko, Technos Co., Ltd, Japan) and an immersion heater (Baker, Elektro-Varme, Sweden) (Fig. S2, Supporting information). The overall transmembrane pressure (TMP) was monitored by two digital pressure gauges (DCS40.0AR, Trafag AG, Switzerland) on the feed and retentate sides, and controlled using a needle valve on the retentate side. The crossflow velocity (CFV) over the membrane surface was measured by a flowmeter (FCH-34-PP-Chemica, B.I.O-TECH E.K., Germany) placed on the retentate side and the flow was set by a positive displacement pump (Hydra-cell D25XL, Wanner, USA). The setup was equipped with 3 identical and parallel membrane modules. Each module had a circular shape and an effective membrane area of 19.6 cm2. Scales (PL6001-1, Mettler Toledo Inc., USA) placed below each of the modules were used to calculate the permeate fluxes based on mass differences over time. The TMP was calculated as average pressure difference between the retentate and feed sides according to the Eq. 5:(5)TMP=i=1n(Pret-Pfeed)nWhere Pret - liquid pressure at retentate side determined by pressure gauge 1 (Fig. S2, Supporting information), Pfeed -liquid pressure at the feed side determined by pressure gauge 2 (Fig. S2, Supporting information), n - number of measurements (pressure was automatically measured every 10 s during ultrafiltration).
label: n

paragraph: The experimental procedure used during the UF of ThMP process water started with a cleaning cycle, for 1 h at 50 degC, using an alkaline solution of 1.0% (w/w) Ultrasil 10 (Ecolab, Sweden). The conditions during this cleaning cycle were kept constant at a TMP of 2.0 bar and a CFV of 0.5 m s-1. The same cleaning procedure was used also after the UF of ThMP process water. During the UF of the process water from the pulp industry, temperature and CFV were kept constant at 70 degC and 0.3 m s-1, respectively, while permeate fluxes were recorded for the TMP of 1.0, 3.0 and 5.0 bar, the average permeance in L m-2 h-1 bar-1 was calculated according to Eq. 6.(6)P=VAtTMP,where P is membrane permeance, L m-2 h-1 bar-1, V is permeate volume, L, A is the effective membrane area, m2, t is time, TMP is transmembrane pressure, bar.
label: n

paragraph: Between each process step, the system was rinsed with abundant deionized water prior to PWF measurements. These PWF studies were performed using deionized water after the UF of ThMP process water and after each cleaning.
label: n

paragraph: The operation conditions for the PWF measurements were at constant temperature of 30 degC and constantly kept CFV of 0.3 m s-1, while the TMP was increased from 1.0 to 2.0 bar and consecutively from 2.0 to 3.0 bar. The permeate flux measurements were carried out after reaching of steady flux state. Permeate and retentate flows were recirculated to the feed tank.
label: n

paragraph: The membrane permeance was calculated according to Eq. (6).
label: n

paragraph: The degree of fouling of the membranes was measured according to flux recovery ratios after rinsing with deionized water (FRRrinse, %), while the effectiveness of the applied cleaning cycle was measured according to the flux recovery ratios after cleaning (FRRclean, %). Both parameters were defined by the Eqs. (7) and (8):(7)FRRrinse=PrinseP0*100%,(8)FRRclean=PcleanP0*100%,where P0 is pure water permeance prior to the UF of ThMP process water, L m-2 h-1 bar-1, Prinse and Pclean are pure water permeances prior to and after the second cleaning cycle, respectively, L m-2 h-1 bar-1.
label: n

paragraph: During the UF of ThMP process water, samples of permeate and feed were collected while the permeate fluxes were recorded. The rejection (R, %) of hemicellulose and lignin were calculated according to Eq. (2).
label: n

paragraph: The following analytical procedure was performed as per the standardized NREL procedure [41,42].
label: n

paragraph: The concentration of hemicelluloses was determined using mannan as an indicator sugar for the softwood hemicellulose. To obtain monomeric forms of sugars from polysaccharides for analysis, an acid hydrolysis of 20 mL samples with 1.5 mL of 72% sulfuric acid was performed in an autoclave (Systec DX-150, Germany) at 121 degC for 1 h. The hydrolysates were thereafter filtrated through ceramic filters to separate soluble parts from acid insoluble solids. Further, the filtrates collected from this filtration step were diluted in deionized water before being analyzed by high-performance anion exchange chromatography with a Dionex ICS-3000 (Dionex Corp., USA) system. The system was equipped with a pulsed amperometric detector and a Carbo Pac PA1 as analytical column. Deionized water at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min-1 was used as eluent solution, while a 200 mM NaOH solution at a flow rate of 0.5 mL min-1 was considered for post column eluent addition. Finally, 170 mM sodium acetate and 200 mM NaOH solution was used as wash eluent solution at a 0.5 mL min-1 flow rate. Calibration standards used were glucose, galactose, arabinose, mannose and xylose solutions, with pre-defined concentrations.
label: n

paragraph: Each sample was diluted in deionized water prior to UV measurements in a spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV spectrophotometer UV-1800, Kyoto, Japan) at 280 nm wavelength. Triplicates were measured for each sample and an absorptivity factor of was considered [43].
label: n

paragraph: Measurements of total solids were performed in an oven for 24 h at 105 degC. The weight difference of the ceramic cups provided the total solids content in each sample. Thereafter, dried samples were put in a furnace using the following procedure to determine the ash content of the samples: 30 min at 250 degC and 180 min at 575 degC. To reach the temperature of 250 degC, temperature increase rate of 10 degC min-1 was considered while for the following temperature increase, 20 degC min-1 temperature ramping was performed. The ash content was the difference in weight prior and after the ashing procedure.
label: n

paragraph: Conductivity of the initial ThMP feed solution was measured at 30 degC using a WTW Conductivity Meter LF95 (Christian Berner AB, Partille, Sweden).
label: n

paragraph: FTIR spectra of the selective layers and the bottom layers of both the reference PSf membrane and PSf membranes modified via the addition of PAA to the coagulation bath are presented in Fig. 1. It was found that vibrations of PSf membrane matrix prevail both in the spectra of reference and modified membranes.
label: n

paragraph: It was revealed that the absorption bands with the peak at 1153 cm-1 are due to the PSf R-SO2-R group symmetric stretching vibrations (Fig. 1). The absorption bands at 1583, 1487 and 1106 cm-1 belong to the vibrations of PSf aromatic ring (CC bonds) [44]. Peak at 1243 cm-1 is assigned to the vibrations of -C-O-C- groups bound with benzene ring of PSf [45]. Stretching fluctuations of S-N groups are observed at 2850 and 2965 cm-1. The absorption bands at 1650 cm-1 correspond to the vibrations of the S=O in carboxylic groups of PAA immobilized on the selective layer surface (2-6 in Fig. 1) [46]. FTIR spectra of the selective layer of modified membranes were characterized by the wide absorption band in the range of 3000-3600 cm-1, peaking at 3420 cm-1. These broad peaks correspond to the vibrations of the O-H groups involved in the formation of hydrogen bound of the carboxylic groups immobilized on the surface of the selective layer (2-6 in Fig. 1). This was the result of the immobilization of the polyelectrolyte macromolecules into the PSf membrane selective layer when PAA is added in the coagulation bath upon membrane preparation by NIPS. It was found that an increase in PAA concentration in the coagulation bath yields the increase in the intensity of the peaks at 1650 and 3420 cm-1 in the spectra of the selective layer surface (2-6 in Fig. 1). This is due to the fact that more PAA macromolecules were immobilized on the surface of membrane selective layer. However, no evidence of immobilization of PAA macromolecules was revealed on the surface of the membrane bottom layer (7 in Fig. 1). This finding is in agreement with the results obtained in our previous works [34,35]. This fact can be explained in the following way: polymer film was cast on the glass plate and then immersed in the coagulation bath, so membrane bottom layer is blocked by the glass plate from the contact with coagulant until the membrane will be completely formed and spontaneously released from the glass plate. In this system the selective layer is the first to contact with the coagulant during membrane formation via NIPS. The diffusion of the coagulant occurs in the direction from the selective layer to the bottom layer across the nascent polymer film. Absence of PAA macromolecules on the surface of the membrane bottom layer is due to the low rate of their diffusion through the formed less porous and dense selective layer across the nascent polymer film during membrane preparation via NIPS [34,35].
label: n

paragraph: The effect of PAA concentration in the coagulation bath on the membrane structure is demonstrated in Fig. 2. The structure of the reference PSf membrane as well as the membranes modified by PAA consists of the thin selective layer, the transitional layer and porous membrane matrix pierced by elongated macrovoids. The reference PSf membrane was revealed to feature the porous transitional layer located near the selective layer and porous membrane matrix between large macrovoids (Fig. 2a). This morphology is a common structure formed by instantaneous demixing mechanism in NIPS. Addition of 0.4 wt% of PAA results in the change of the macrovoid shape: they become wider, shorter, some of the macrovoids become oval. The thickness of the transitional layer increased (macrovoids move farther from the selective layer); however, it remained very porous (Fig. 2b). It was found that starting from 0.7 wt% PAA in the coagulation bath and further increase in the PAA concentration the number of macrovoids decreases and a denser selective layer and less porous membrane matrix are formed (Fig. 2c-f). Moreover, the thickness of the transitional and selective layers increased with the rise of PAA concentration in the coagulation bath. It was previously found that the addition of the cationic or anionic polyelectrolytes (commercially available flocculants) based on polyacrylamide, Praestol 859 or Praestol 2540, respectively, to the coagulation bath does not influence the thermodynamics of the phase separation of the casting solution [34-37]. It was established that the key factor responsible for the change of membrane structure is a significant rise in viscosity of the coagulation bath. "Solvent-non-solvent" exchange rate during membrane preparation via NIPS decreased with the increase in coagulant viscosity. In other words, the in-diffusion velocity of the precipitant into the cast polymer film and out-diffusion velocity of the solvent out of the polymer film decreased [34-37]. Previously, it has been revealed that the addition of polyelectrolytes to the coagulation bath yields the increase in membrane formation time due to the increase in the coagulant viscosity [34-37].
label: n

paragraph: In this study it was found that addition of PAA to the coagulant also leads to the increase of viscosity (Fig. S3 A, Supporting information). However, this increase in viscosity is rather small compared to the addition of Praestol flocculants based on polyacrylamide [34-37]. For instance, when 2.0 wt% of PAA is added to coagulant the viscosity increases by 2.2 times compared to water (Fig. S3 A, Supporting information). The systematic dependence of membrane formation time on coagulant viscosity was revealed and presented on Fig. S3 B (Supporting information). When 1.0 wt% of PAA is added to the coagulation bath membrane formation time increases by 1.7 times (from 7 up to 12 s); and when 2.0 wt% of PAA is added - by 2.9 times (from 7 up to 20 s) compared to membrane formation time when water is used as a coagulant. So, it was revealed that PAA addition to coagulation bath leads to the slight increase of membrane formation time due to not very high molecular weight. It should be taken into account that membrane formation time as determined in this study is a global measure of kinetic processes during NIPS and will not reflect all mechanistic details; what happens at the interface upon contact between cast film and coagulant is certainly not fully covered. A possible reason of structural changes of membrane cross-section is the immobilization of PAA macromolecules in the membrane selective layer, which leads to the formation of thicker and denser selective membrane layer. Upon the contact with the coagulant a partly precipitated gel-like selective layer is formed and further diffusion of the coagulant happens through this formed layer. The diffusion coefficient of PAA macromolecules through the formed selective layer is lower compared to the diffusion coefficient of solvent and non-solvent. Hence, it is expected that the depth of PAA anchorage in polymer matrix will be in the vicinity of the selective layer and concentration of PAA will significantly decrease across the membrane thickness. The evidence for this is the absence of PAA macromolecules on the surface of the membrane bottom layer which was confirmed by FTIR and discussed above.
label: n

paragraph: It was revealed that PAA addition led to a decrease in a number of pores in the membrane selective layer and a decrease in the pore size (Fig. 3). This is due to the deceleration of phase inversion rate, caused by the coagulation bath viscosity increase. Pores of the selective layer of PA-2.0 membrane become so small that they can no longer be detected by SEM at the magnification used (Fig. 3e).
label: n

paragraph: The topology of the surface of membrane selective layer was studied using atomic force microscopy (AFM). It is known that surface roughness of the selective layer has a great impact on antifouling membrane stability [47]. The surface roughness of the membrane selective layer was analyzed for the reference membrane (PA-0) and membranes with high PAA concentration in the coagulation bath (PA-1.0, PA-1.5 and PA-2.0) (Fig. S4, Supporting information).
label: n

paragraph: It was found that the selective layers of modified membranes have a nodular structure typical of membranes obtained via NIPS. Further, it was shown that immobilization of the PAA macromolecules on the selective layer surface had only a weak influence on the topology and selective layer roughness (Table 4). However, it was revealed to be the minimum values of the roughness parameters, both average roughness (Ra, nm) and root mean square roughness (Rq, nm), for PA-1.5 membranes. According to this, the PA-1.5 membranes are characterized by a smoother selective layer surface.
label: n

paragraph: Zeta potentials of the selective layer surface of the reference and modified membranes were investigated via measurements of the tangential flow streaming potential. It is known that zeta potential greatly affects membrane separation performance as well as antifouling resistance. It was revealed that the zeta potential was negative for reference and modified membranes over the entire investigated pH range. Zero fit showed that the isoelectric point for PA-0 membranes was approximately at pH 3.4, for PA-1.0 membranes it was at pH 3.3, for PA-1.5 and PA-2.0 - at pH 2.5 (Fig. 4). Hence, the isoelectric point was found to decrease with PAA concentration in the coagulation bath. Decrease in the zeta potential of the selective layer surface of the reference membrane with pH rise are explained by the specific adsorption of anions of electrolyte (Cl-) and hydroxyl ions (OH-) whereas PSf has no dissociated (negatively charged) groups [48]. It was found that the zeta potential of the reference membrane is lower in absolute value than that of the membranes modified by PAA over the whole pH range. An increase in the PAA content in coagulation bath and, therefore, a density of immobilized macromolecules (Fig. 1) yielded the decrease in zeta potential of the membrane surface (Fig. 4). It was shown that zeta potential decreased when pH increased, that is due to the ionization of PAA macromolecules (pKa of the PAA is 4.5 [49]). These results are consistent with the data obtained in [35].
label: n

paragraph: A water contact angle characterizes the hydrophilicity of the membrane surface and impacts the antifouling membrane performance [34]. It was found that addition of 0.4 wt% of PAA into the coagulation bath during membrane preparation results in a dramatic decrease in water contact angle from 65deg for the reference PA-0 membrane down to 25deg. Further, increase of PAA concentration in the coagulation bath yielded the decrease in water contact angle down to 20-21deg for PA-0.7, PA-1.0 and PA-1.2 membranes. The rise of PAA concentration in the coagulation bath up to 1.5 and 2.0 wt% led to further hydrophilization of the surface of the membrane selective layer: the water contact angle became 17-16deg (Fig. 5). This is due to the increase in the density of immobilized polyelectrolyte macromolecules containing hydrophilic groups which was confirmed by FTIR analysis (Fig. 1). Carboxylic groups (-COOH) of PAA were solvated by the water molecules forming the hydration layer which prevents the absorption of proteins and colloid particles on the membrane surface [38].
label: n

paragraph: Membrane separation performance depends primarily on the selective layer structure (thickness, pore size and porosity). The membrane pure water flux (PWF) was found to decrease with an increasing the PAA concentration in the coagulation bath (Fig. 6A). For instance, PWF for PA-2.0 decreased by 2.2 times compared to the reference PA-0 membrane. This is the result of the formation of a denser selective layer and a decreasing of the selective layer pore size and porosity, which was confirmed by SEM (Fig. 3).
label: n

paragraph: The PVP K-30 rejection coefficient, on the contrary, was shown to increase up to more than 99% with the increasing of polyelectrolyte concentration in the coagulation bath, compared to 90% for the reference membrane (Fig. 6A). Decreasing of the pore size leads to the reduction of permeability of the PVP macromolecules and, therefore, to the increase in rejection coefficient.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane separation performance was also investigated by filtration of the 0.5 wt% lysozyme solution in the phosphate buffer with pH 7.2. It was found that the addition of 0.4 wt% PAA into the coagulation bath resulted in a lysozyme solution flux decrease in 2.6-2.8 times (Fig. 6B). However, further increase in PAA concentration did not affect the modified membrane flux, and it did not exceed 13-15 L m-2 h-1. The lysozyme rejection coefficient increased up to 99% for PA-2.0 membrane. This was the result of decreasing the pore size of the membrane selective layer (Fig. 3). Another possible reason is the higher adsorption of positively charged lysozyme macromolecules at pH 7.2 on the negatively charged membrane selective layer surface. The latter factor could promote the electrostatic attraction of lysozyme macromolecules to the membrane surface and facilitate the formation of a gel layer of lysozyme, which served as a secondary membrane and increased lysozyme rejection during ultrafiltration (Figs. 4 and 6B).
label: n

paragraph: It was found that pH of the feed solution affects the modified membrane performance due to the presence of PAA macromolecules on the selective layer surface and on the pore walls. It is known that the ion strength and pH variations cause the self-induced reversible conformation transition of the polyelectrolyte macromolecules: a stretched chain -- a globule. The degree of elongation of the polyelectrolyte chain coil increases proportionally to the degree of ionization due to the electrostatic repulsion of charged groups. Polymer chains in the stretched conformation probably covered a large membrane surface area thereby decreasing the effective pore size that resulted in a flux reduction.
label: n

paragraph: The dependence of flux changes on the pH of the feed water was studied for PA-1.5 membrane (Fig. 7). Polyelectrolyte units immobilized on the selective layer surface and inside the pores, being protonated at pH 3, assumed the globule conformation and therefore did not block the pores. Consequently, the membrane flux was found to be the highest at pH 3. Further proceeding to the base pH region induced the ionization of the carboxylic groups of the PAA with the formation of the negatively charged carboxylate groups. Repulsion of similar charged groups caused the transition of PAA macromolecules to the stretched conformation and partially blocked the membrane pores. Thereby, the membrane flux was decreased by 4 times, in the average, at pH 7 and 9 compared to the flux at pH 3.
label: n

paragraph: The reproducibility of results was demonstrated over three filtration cycles (Fig. 7). It was found that pH-sensitivity was maintained over the three filtration cycles. The increasing membrane flux in the second and third cycles was probably due to the washing out of PEG-400 from the membrane selective layer and pores. However, the pH-sensitivity of membranes was not lost. Thus, it can be stated that PAA macromolecules were strongly fixed in the PSf membrane matrix.
label: n

paragraph: The influence of PAA addition to the coagulation bath on the antifouling performance was investigated during filtration of the 5*10-3 wt% humic acids (HAs) solution in tap water. The antifouling performance of the reference PA-0 and modified PA-1.5 membranes was studied. HAs performance and antifouling parameters (flux recovery ratio (FRR) and total flux decline ratio (DT)) as well as permeate characteristics are presented in Table 5. It was found that HAs flux of the reference membrane PA-0 decreased from 120 to 102 L m-2 h-1 after 1 h of HAs solution ultrafiltration, however for the PA-1.5 membrane flux was constant during 1 h of filtration -- 68 L m-2 h-1. Pure water flux of the PA-0 membrane after filtration of the HAs solution decreased down to 87 L m-2 h-1, while water flux of the PA-1.5 membrane was the same as HAs solution flux. According to this, the PA-1.5 membrane was found to feature significantly higher antifouling stability than the reference one. Better antifouling stability of PA-1.5 membrane compared to the reference one was attributed to the smaller pore size of the selective layer of the PA-1.5 membrane compared to the reference PA-0 membrane (Fig. 3a, d); lower surface roughness (Table 4, Fig. S4, Supporting information) and significantly higher hydrophilicity (Fig. 5). Moreover, HAs molecules feature negative charge at pH 8.4 [51]. It was shown that selective layer surface of the PA-1.5 membrane is characterized by higher absolute value of negative charge compared to the reference membrane (Fig. 4). This results in the better repulsion of HAs molecules and PA-1.5 membrane selective layer.
label: n

paragraph: Based on the permeate characteristics after filtration of HAs solutions, it was shown that both PA-0 and PA-1.5 membranes were effective in surface water treatment, which usually contains HAs and fulvic acids (Table 5). However, it was found that the PA-1.5 membrane is characterized by higher iron removal from HAs solutions compared to the reference membrane, due to the electrostatic adsorption of positively charged iron ions on the surface of membrane selective layer of the PA-1.5 membrane with higher absolute value of negative charge compared to the PA-0 membrane at pH 8.4 (Fig. 4, Table 5).
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 8 presents the fluxes during the filtration of ThMP process water and the permeances of the PSf membranes. It was revealed that PAA addition to the coagulation bath during the membrane formation led to an increase in the negative value of zeta potential and hydrophilicity of the membrane surface (Figs. 4 and 5) and a decrease in the pore size and porosity (Fig. 3) of the selective layer, which led to the reduction in the attachment of fouling substances.
label: n

paragraph: The dependence of membrane flux during ultrafiltration of ThMP process water on transmembrane pressure (TMP) is shown in Fig. 8A. It was found that membrane flux increased with increasing the PAA concentration in the coagulation bath; only after using high PAA concentration about the same flux was obtained (PA-1.0 vs. PA-1.5). The enhanced fluxes can be related to an increase in antifouling resistance of modified membranes due to the substantial increase in selective layer hydrophilicity and negative charge that prevent the formation of the gel layer of dissolved substance on the membrane surface and the loss of permeability. In contrast, the reduction in PWF for the membranes with higher PAA content in the coagulation bath is due to the decrease in the pore size and porosity of the selective layer and increase in the thickness of the selective layer (Figs. 2, 3, 6). Thus, membrane morphology (especially pore size, porosity and selective layer thickness) is more influential on PWF than hydrophilicity, as reported in [50].
label: n

paragraph: Membrane permeances using pure water were studied before ThMP process water ultrafiltration, after rinsing with deionized water and cleaning with an alkaline agent after ThMP process water ultrafiltration (Fig. 8B). It was found that initial permeance of the modified membranes is lower than the permeance of the reference membrane. This is due to the decrease in pore size and porosity of the membrane selective layer and increase in selective layer thickness (Figs. 2, 3). However, permeances of modified membranes after rinsing were revealed to be higher compared to the PA-0 membrane. Moreover, it was found to be 2 times higher for the PA-1.0 membrane compared to the reference one (Fig. 8B). Permeance was found to increase by 2 times after membrane cleaning with the alkaline agent Ultrasil 10 both for reference and modified membranes compared to the permeance after rinsing with pure water. Nevertheless, membrane permeance after rinsing and cleaning did not exceed the initial permeance value, which indicates irreversible membrane fouling.
label: n

paragraph: Considering the results shown in Fig. 9, the flux recovery ratios suggest less irreversible interactions between fouling compounds in the feed solution and the membrane surface, especially for the membranes with high PAA concentration (PA-1.0 and PA-1.5). This could indicate that the enhanced hydrophilicity and more negative surface zeta potential of these membranes (PA-1.0 and PA-1.5) did not only improve the filtration fluxes of ThMP process water but also reduced the membrane-foulant interactions. In comparison to the reference membrane, increasing the concentration of PAA also resulted in an increase in the FRRs. Thus, PAA is efficient in reducing fouling accumulation on the membrane surface as most of the membranes with PAA are characterized by higher FRR compared to the reference membrane.
label: n

paragraph: According to rejection results (Fig. 10), an increase in PAA concentration in the coagulation bath during membrane formation had practically no impact on the rejection of lignin, however, the rejection of hemicellulose slightly increased. The results of total lignin rejection for the modified membranes (Fig. 10A) were between 26.5% and 31.5%. The reference membrane, without PAA addition in the coagulation bath retained about 25.9% of total lignin.
label: n

paragraph: The developed membranes were found to be more effective for the concentration of hemicellulose due to the smaller pore size of the selective layer compared to the reference PA-0 membrane (Fig. 10B). While the PA-0 membrane retained 91.3%, the membranes modified with PAA retained between 96.1% and 96.7%. The difference in retentions between hemicellulose and lignin also suggest the possibility to purify hemicellulose if these membranes are used for ThMP process water treatment in the pulp industry.
label: n

paragraph: A novel approach of preparation of PSf membranes with enhanced antifouling stability by addition of PAA to the coagulation bath via NIPS was developed. The effect of the polyelectrolyte concentration in the coagulation bath on the membrane surface characteristics (water contact angle, zeta potential, surface roughness), pore structure and separation performance was studied.
label: n

paragraph: According to SEM studies, addition of polyelectrolyte into the coagulation bath led to decrease in the number of macrovoids and formation of a denser selective layer as well as decreasing the pore size and porosity of the selective layer. This is caused by the increase in the coagulation bath viscosity with added PAA and results in the membrane PWF and lysozyme flux decrease and PVP K-30 and lysozyme rejection coefficients increase.
label: n

paragraph: It was shown that membrane surface becomes more negatively charged with PAA concentration increase due to the immobilization of PAA macromolecules on the surface of the membrane selective layer and inside the pores. Introduction of the PAA units into the membrane structure was found to enhance the membrane surface hydrophilicity. Modified membranes are characterized by the reversible pH-sensitivity; the PA-1.5 membrane was revealed to have flux at pH 3 four times higher than at pH 7 and 9.
label: n

paragraph: Modified membranes demonstrated better antifouling stability during HAs solution filtration compared to the reference membrane. For filtration of ThMP process water, the PA-1.0 and PA-1.5 membranes showed positive results both in terms of higher flux and FRR in comparison with the reference membrane and other modified membranes, without affecting the rejection of lignin and improving the retention of hemicellulose. The rejection coefficients of hemicelluloses of modified membranes increased compared to the reference membrane, which provides the possibility for the application of the developed membranes for the valorization of hemicelluloses from the ThMP process water in pulp industry.
label: n

paragraph: K. S. Burts: Investigation, Data curation, Formal analysis, Validation, Visualization, Writing - original draft. T. V. Plisko: Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Writing - original draft, Supervision, Writing - review & editing. A.V. Bildyukevich: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing - review & editing. G. Rodrigues: Investigation, Data curation, Formal analysis. M. Sjolin: Investigation, Data curation, Formal analysis. F. Lipnizki: Methodology, Writing - review & editing. M. Ulbricht: Writing - review & editing.
label: n

paragraph: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
label: n

paragraph: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.colsurfa.2021.127742.
label: n

paragraph: Supplementary material.
label: n

paragraph: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is one of the most common public health issues around the world due to its high morbidity, and millions of the patients die every year for lack of cost-efficient treatment [1]. Organ transplantation shows the best therapeutic effect so far and is used for CKD treatments especially in terminal stage. However, the high cost of organ transplantation is unaffordable for most CKD patients. The lack of donors and difficulty in organ matching also restrict the availability of organ transplantation. As a blood purification technology, hemodialysis has served as an alternative therapy for CKD since 1950s. Hemodialysis consists of a hemodialysis membrane-based dialyzer and a circulatory blood purification system, which together purify the blood coming from CKD patients and then circulate it back [2]. Hemodialysis is widely used among the dialysis and blood purification techniques because of relatively low cost and low treatment requirements. Moreover, as it is an extracorporeal process, side reactions seldom occur [3].
label: n

paragraph: Hemodialysis membranes are the core unit in hemodialysis. They are porous membrane allowing the passage of water molecules and small solutes while rejecting macromolecules with certain molecular weights. A few artificial and synthetic polymers such as cellulose acetate (CA) [4,5], poly(lactic acid) (PLA) [6-8], polyethersulfone (PES) [1,9], polysulfone (PSF) [10-15], and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) [16], have been used to prepare hemodialysis membranes. Among these polymers, PSF is distinguished because of its excellent mechanical property, chemical durability, and processibility. Also importantly, PSF is one of the few biomaterials that can remain stable in all sterilization conditions (steam, ethylene oxide, and gamma radiation, etc.) [11]. Besides, PSF-based membranes show superior clearance rate to uremic toxins [17] and have become a prime choice for clinicians administering dialysis. However, the relatively hydrophobic nature of PSF tends to cause adsorption of proteins during the hemodialysis process, which can further lead to serious even life-threatening complications due to activation of the complement alternative pathway [18]. Protein deposition on the membranes during dialysis also deteriorates the permeability and rejection performances of membranes. In addition, the hydrophobicity of PSF usually results in relatively poor hemocompatibility, so anticoagulants are always employed during treatments in order to avoid clot formation [19,20].
label: n

paragraph: Because of these issues, modification to PSF is usually prerequisite before it can be used in hemodialysis. To this end, different modification methods have been utilized. For instance, researchers have tried some surface modification techniques such as air-plasma glow discharge treatment on the pristine PSF membranes to improve their biocompatibility [11,21]. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) and heparin (Hep) were also grafted onto PSF membranes by plasma-induced surface modification to prepare PSF-PEG-Hep membranes [12]. However, constrained to the complexity of these modification methods, it is difficult to industrialize and apply to medical services. At the current stage, blending outstanding-biocompatibility additives with PSF to improve the biocompatibility of PSF-based membranes is the main method to prepare commercial hemodialysis membranes. PSF membranes blended with hydrophilic additives, including silibinin (SLB) [22], PSF-g-TPGS [13], and others [23,24], exhibited enhanced biocompatibility. Meanwhile, the additives can act as porogon. Although the hemodialysis performances of PSF-based membranes can be improved to some extent, the shear force between the circulating fluid and the hemodialysis membrane can lead to the wash-out of additives from the membrane surface during dialysis process, thus affecting the biocompatibility of the dialysis membrane [9,25]. Moreover, the types of hemodialysis membranes, sterilization method, storage period and preflush method can also cause the elution of additives [26-28]. Therefore, it is urgent to find a more effective and safe method to prepare PSF-based hemodialysis membranes.
label: n

paragraph: In our previous work, we combined PEG blocks with PSF by copolymerization to enhance hydrophilicity, and thus produced PSF-b-PEG block copolymer was used to prepare ultrafiltration membranes by NIPS [29]. The prepared membranes showed upgraded surface hydrophilicity and consequently high permeability as well as good fouling resistance. To be noted, the molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) of the prepared PSF-b-PEG membranes is around 42 kDa, where small/medium sized molecular toxins and macromolecular proteins can be separated. Meanwhile, as a hydrophilic and non-toxic polymer with high mobility and antifouling property to plasma proteins or platelets, PEG can improve the hemocompatibility and biocompatibility of PSF. Therefore, the hemodialysis performances of the PSF-b-PEG membranes are expected. In this study, we attempt to formulate dialysis-grade PSF-b-PEG membranes by NIPS without any additives or post-treatments. The morphology, permeance, solute rejection, hydrophilicity, protein adsorption, hemocompatibility and toxin clearance of the PSF-b-PEG membranes will be investigated.
label: n

paragraph: PSF-b-PEG block copolymers were obtained from Nanjing Bangding. The polydispersive index (PDI) was ~2.00, and the PEG block had a molecular weight of ~20 kDa, as provided by the manufacturer. Thermogravimetric analysis showed that the PEG content was 21 wt%. PSF (average molecular weight 22000 Da) were obtained from Solvay. PEG and urea (AR) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio.-Chem. Technology Co., LTD. Calcium chloride anhydrous (CaCl2, AR) and sodium chloride (NaCl, AR) were purchased from Xilong Scientific, LDC. N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, >= 99.0%) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., LTD. Lysozyme from egg white (LZM, 40000 U/mg) and p-Diaminobenzaldehyde (PDAB, AR) were obtained from Macklin. Bovine serum albumin (BSA, purity > 97%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Phosphate buffer solution (PBS) tablets were obtained from MP Biomedicals, LLC. All chemicals were employed as received. Deionized (DI) water was prepared in the laboratory.
label: y

paragraph: In order to fabricate homogeneous casting solutions (17 wt% to 25 wt%), a certain amount of PSF-b-PEG was added to NMP at 60 degC for enough time. Then mechanical stirring device was employed to ensure that the solutes were dissolved completely. The casting solution was deaerated overnight in a vacuum oven at 60 degC and then naturally cooled to room temperature. The casting solutions were scraped on the glass plate with a spatula to fabricate 300 mm-thick films. The films were placed in environment for several seconds before being put in deionized water. Then the membranes were rinsed with deionized water thoroughly to remove the remaining solvent and placed in deionized water for later use. The process for preparing PSF or PSF/PEG blending membranes was the same as above, except that the casting solution was composed of 18 wt% PSF and 82 wt% NMP or 16.6 wt% PSF, 4.4 wt% PEG and 79 wt% NMP.
label: y

paragraph: The membrane surface and cross-sectional morphologies were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S4800). The membrane cross sections were prepared by freeze fracture. A layer of gold particles was sputtered on the surface of the samples to increase its electrical conductivity before SEM examinations. Membrane hydrophilicity was analyzed by a contact angle goniometer (DropMeter A100, Maist), and the average value was obtained by testing at least 3 positions for each samples.
label: n

paragraph: Pure water permeance and rejection to protein (BSA or LZM) were tested by a unit (Amicon 8010, Millipore) with an effective test area of 4.1 cm2. Prior to formal testing, the membrane should be prepressed at 1 bar for 20 min to minimize possible compaction phenomenon. After that, the membrane was tested for 5 min at 1 bar to obtain permeability data. During the whole process, the stirring rate of the unit was 600 rpm to avoid concentration polarization. The membrane rejection performance was characterized by BSA or LZM solution (0.5 g/L). The BSA or LZM concentration was calculated with a UV-Vis spectrometer (NanoDrop 2000C, Thermo Scientific) at the wavelength of 280 nm.
label: n

paragraph: The membrane pure water permeance was determined by Eq. (1):(1)Permeance=VSxtxDPwhere permeance represented the permeance (L m-2 h-1 bar-1) for pure water. V was the volume of the permeation water (L). S is the effective test area (m2), t is the filtration time (h), and DP is the operation pressure (bar).
label: n

paragraph: The membrane protein rejection was determined by Eq. (2):(2)R(%)=Cf-CpCfx100%where Cp and Cf represented the solution concentrations (g*L-1) in the permeate and the feed, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: The mixed PEG solution was used to test MWCOs of the membranes by a module (Amicon 8010, Millipore). The mixed PEG solution was prepared by adding 0.5 g of each of six kinds of PEG with different molecular weights into 1 L DI water. The molecular weights of PEG were 1000, 4000, 10000, 20000, 70000 and 100000 Da, respectively. The test conditions were the same as before. PEG concentrations were measured via gel permeation chromatography (GPC, Waters 1515).
label: n

paragraph: The rejection was determined by Eq. (2) and plotted according to different molecular weight rejection. The point where PEG interception reached 90% was considered as the MWCO of the membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Theoretical mean pore size (ravg) was determined by Eq. (3):(3)ravg=16.73x10-10MWCO0.557where the unit of ravg was cm and MWCO was Daltons.
label: n

paragraph: 5 mL BSA solution (1.0 g/L) was added to weighing bottles. Then the membranes (size of 5.3 cm2) were inversed and floated on BSA solution. The weighing bottles were placed at 25 degC for 12 h to reach adsorption saturation. BSA concentrations were characterized in the same way as above.
label: n

paragraph: The membrane static adsorption amount was determined by Eq. (4):(4)SA=(Ca-Cb)xVSwhere SA represented the static adsorption amount (mg cm-2) on the membranes surface. Cb and Ca were the BSA concentrations (mg mL-1) before and after experiments, respectively. V was the volume of the BSA solution (mL) used, and S was the membrane area (cm2).
label: n

paragraph: The fresh platelet-rich plasma (PRP) was obtain from Shanghai Yuanye Biotechnology Company, China. PSF-b-PEG membranes and PSF membranes were cut into 10 mm-discs for the adhesion tests. The membrane discs were put individually in the 24-well cell culture plate and PBS solutions were added at 37 degC. After 1 h, replacing PBS solutions with 1 mL fresh PRP in each well. The membrane discs were incubated with PRP for 2 h at 37 degC. Then the membrane discs were washed mildly by PBS solutions for three times and treated with 2.5% glutaraldehyde. After 1 h, the platelets have been fixed to the membrane. And the fixed platelets were then dehydrated by graded alcohol-water solutions (20%, 40%, 60%, 80% and 100%, each concentration for 10 min), followed by drying overnight at room temperature. The dried membrane samples were then observed by SEM.
label: n

paragraph: As above, the membrane discs (diameter 10 mm) were individually placed in the culture plate and 100 mL platelet-poor plasma (PPP) solution was added to each membrane disc at 37 degC. After that, 100 mL CaCl2 solution (0.025 M) was dripped to each membrane disc. The mixture was softly stirred. The time when the first fibrin thread was noticed was recorded as PRT.
label: n

paragraph: 10 mm-size membrane discs were immersed in the normal saline solution for 40 min at 37 degC. After that, 200 mL whole pig blood was dropped and maintained at 37 degC for 1 h. Meanwhile, normal saline and DI water were used as the negative and positive control, respectively. The mixed liquids were centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 min. UV-Vis spectrometer was employed at 545 nm to measure the absorption of liquid supernatant.
label: n

paragraph: The HR was determined by Eq. (5):(5)HR(%)=AS-ANAP-ANx100%where AS represented the absorption value of sample liquid supernatant, AN and AP represented the absorption value of negative control and positive control, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: Hemodialysis simulation tests of the PSF-b-PEG membranes were evaluated according to the studies of Liu et al. [7,8]. The schematic diagram of the test process is shown in Fig. 1. The test area of the PSF-b-PEG membranes was 19.6 cm2. The mixed solution of urea (1.5 g/L) and lysozyme (0.2 g/L), and the solution of BSA (1 g/L) were simulated as blood, respectively. PBS solution was simulated as dialysate. They were forced through the dialysis mode in the reverse direction at the speed of 100 and 300 mL/min. The tests lasted for 6 h, afterwards 20 mL of the test solutions were taken from the outlet of the simulating blood for further analysis.
label: n

paragraph: The clearance of urea, lysozyme, and BSA solutions was determined by Eq. (6):(6)Clearance=QBiCBi-CBoCBiwhere CBi and CBo were the inlet and outlet concentrations of simulating blood, and QBi was the blood inlet flow (100 mL/min). The urea, lysozyme, and BSA concentrations were measured with UV-Vis spectrometer at 420, 280, and 280 nm, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: To study the stability of the PEG component in membranes, we analyzed their surface element distributions after water immersion. The prepared PSF-b-PEG and PSF/PEG membranes were placed in DI water for a certain duration, when the water was changed regularly to prevent bacteria formation. Newly prepared membranes and the membranes stored for a certain time were then characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher K-alpha).
label: n

paragraph: Water contact angle (WCA) data of the PSF membrane and the PSF-b-PEG membranes with a PEG content of 21 wt% were firstly observed, as shown in Fig. 2. The WCAs of the PSF-b-PEG membranes prepared under different concentrations were close, ~62deg, which was lower than the WCAs of PSF membranes, ~86.5deg. The improvement of the membrane hydrophilicity was due to the incorporating of PEG chains into PSF. When the casting solutions were cast on glass plate and immersed in DI water, the hydrophilic PEG chains migrated to membrane surface. PEG microdomains had a diameter of ~20-30 nm and were three dimensionally interconnected with each other, forming a randomly distributed continuous phase in the PSF matrix [29]. Due to the biocompatibility of PEG, the PSF-b-PEG copolymer membranes have potential use to produce biologically inert surfaces.
label: n

paragraph: When blood comes into contact with biomaterials, the first thing that happens is the adsorption of plasma protein. This is the foundation of platelet adhesion and activation of clotting, which further leads to thrombosis [30,31]. According to previous study, proteins prefer to be adsorbed onto hydrophobic materials. In the aqueous system, hydration on the surface of hydrophobic materials affects the subsequent protein adsorption process [16]. In this direction, hydrated protein molecules replace the interfacial water through electrostatic interactions to achieve thermodynamic equilibrium [32,33]. Consequently, membranes with hydrophilic surfaces are considered to have excellent anti-protein adsorption property. Static protein adsorption tests were conducted with BSA solution to study the biocompatibility of PSF-b-PEG membranes. During hemodialysis process, the upper surface of membrane is in contact with blood containing protein. Therefore, in order to avoid the influence of supporting layer, the BSA solution was only in contact with membrane surface by turning over the membrane. As shown in Fig. 3a, the BSA adsorptions on the surfaces of PSF-b-PEG membranes were at a similar lever, which were much lower than that of PSF membrane. Even for the membrane with highest BSA adsorption, the adsorption was only ~7.5 mg cm-2. SEM observation found that there was a large amount of BSA aggregated on the PSF membrane surface (Fig. 3 b). On the contrast, there were no obvious BSA aggregation on the PSF-b-PEG membrane surfaces as shown in Fig. 3 (c)-(g), which further demonstrates that the PSF-b-PEG membrane has excellent anti-protein adsorption ability.
label: n

paragraph: As basic factors, relatively high permeability and precise selectivity are required for hemodialysis membranes. The ultrafiltration performances of the PSF-b-PEG membranes were also measured. As shown in Fig. 4a, with the increasing of copolymer concentrations, the permeance of the PSF-b-PEG membranes gradually decreased from ~400 L m-2 h-1 bar-1 to ~100 L m-2 h-1 bar-1. The decrease of membrane permeance was attributed to the increase of internal mass transfer resistance with the increasing of skin layer thickness (Fig. S1). The rejection to BSA increased when the copolymer concentration was within 21 wt% but decreased with the further increase of concentration. It is probably because that the too high concentration of the casting solution causes the change of phase separation behaviors of PSF-b-PEG in skin layer, which finally leads to the abnormal separation performance. The rejection to BSA reached the peak of ~93.2% and the permeance was ~210 L m-2 h-1 bar-1 when copolymer concentration was 21 wt% (the membrane is named as SFEG-21). For the PSF membrane, the permeance was ~0.5 L m-2 h-1 bar-1, which indicated a significant performance improvement by using PSF-b-PEG. As the molecular weight of BSA is ~66 kDa, which is similar to that of human serum protein (HSA), a protein existed in blood, the results of BSA rejections can refer to the retention of albumin present in blood during hemodialysis.
label: n

paragraph: Hemodialysis membranes should act as a barrier for the transport of large proteins, while small and medium sized toxins can be filtered out. So MWCO is a very important parameter for hemodialysis membranes to check their selectivity. MWCO analysis of SFEG-21 was carried out and the result was shown in Fig. 4b. The MWCO of SFEG-21 was determined to be ~43 kDa, and the calculated pore size was approximately 6.2 nm, which further confirmed the potential use in hemodialysis. Besides, the rejection of SFEG-21 to LZM was ~10.7%, corresponding to previous results. As we known, dialysis-related amyloidosis is a common disease because of retention of middle molecular toxin, like, b-2 microglobulin (14000 Da). The clearance rate of middle molecular can be usually improved by increasing pore sizes, which decreases the risk of developing dialysis-related amyloidosis [34]. We note that high cutoff (HCO) can be used to get rid of cytokines and interleukins for patients suffering from sepsis, acute pancreatitis, and even multiple myeloma [35].
label: n

paragraph: Cross-sectional and surface morphologies of the SFEG-21 membrane were characterized by SEM. According to Fig. 5 (a) and (b), SFEG-21 membrane exhibited a typical asymmetric finger-like pore structure composed of a dense skin layer and a highly porous sublayer featured as finger-like cavities, which was similar with PSF membrane (Fig. S2 (a) and (b)). The SFEG-21 surface image showed that the pores of the skin layer were too small to be represented by SEM, whilst the PSF membrane showed some small pores and gap structure on the membrane surface. Although there were some small spherical structures on SFEG-21 membrane surface, the integral membrane surface roughness was relatively low (Fig. S3). Low surface roughness can also avoid large amounts of protein adsorption [13].
label: n

paragraph: Platelets play an important role in maintaining hemostasis while the aggregation of platelets in blood can promote thrombus formation. SEM images were used to study the platelet adhesion behavior on membrane surface. For hydrophobic surfaces, such as pristine PSF or PLA membranes [1,10], large amounts of platelets aggregated on membrane surface. As shown in Fig. 6 (a) and (b), there was obvious platelet adsorption on the whole PSF membrane surface. And the adhesion of platelets all exhibited reticulate pseudopodia structure, which indicated the activation of platelets. By contrast, only little platelet was observed on the SFEG-21 membrane surface (Fig. 6 (c) and (d)). PEG is well-known for its super anti-fouling ability to resist protein adsorption [11]. The presence of abundant ether bonds in PEG can tightly combine with water molecules via hydrogen bonding, forming a hydration layer near the surface. The hydration layer is a physical and energetic barrier to prevent the biocomponents from adsorption the polymer surface [36]. Therefore, for the PSF-b-PEG membrane, the PEG chains distributed on membrane surface allow an anti-protein surface, which efficiently suppress the adsorption and aggregation of platelets. Since PEG and PSF are covalently bonded, we can expect that this good anti-adsorption performance of the PSF-b-PEG membranes can be maintained for a long time rather than gradually declines along with the time.
label: n

paragraph: PRT was used to observe clotting time or to determine the absence of clotting factors [37]. When the clotting factor VIII is activated, the thrombin is generated from the clotting progenitor through stepped-activity. After that, thrombin promotes the conversion of fibrinogen from plasma to fibrous protein, which is the basis of thrombus formation. Due to the addition of calcium ions and the activation of factors VIII, fibrous protein cross-links with each other and becomes stable and insoluble. According to the experiment results, the PRT of pristine PSF membrane was 311 +- 5 s. In addition, the PRT of SFEG-21 membranes was prolonged substantially to 409 +- 10 s compared with PSF membranes. The prolonged PRT indicated that the activation of fibrinogen on SFEG-21 membranes was inhibited, owing to the enhancement of membrane hydrophilicity because of PEG chains [38]. It is worth noting that the time is much higher than that of the modified hemodialysis membrane, such as polydopamine-coated PLA membranes (230 s-244 s) and heparin-immobilized PLA membranes (270 s-280 s) (Tab.1). All these results indicated that SFEG-21 membrane surface not only prevented platelets adhesion and weakened the damage to erythrocyte but also inhibited blood coagulation. By using PSF-b-PEG as the membrane material, the hemocompatibility showed significant improvement.
label: n

paragraph: During hemodialysis, blood keeps flowing through the dialysis membranes. In this continuous process, erythrocytes may rupture and release hemoglobin (known as hemolysis) because of the interaction of erythrocytes with the membranes. HR is then employed to determine the extent of injury of the erythrocytes caused by the dialysis membranes. An HR below 5% is considered harmless by ASTMF-756-08 standard. In vitro hemolysis tests were employed on SFEG-21 membrane, and the HR of SFEG-21 was 0.48% +- 0.01%, not only much lower than 5%, but also lower than that of PSF membranes, which was 0.55% +- 0.03%. This result showed that PEG on the membrane surface could inhibit the release of hemoglobin from cells. In general, SFEG-21 membrane has excellent anti-hemolytic activity under this condition.
label: n

paragraph: As shown in Table 1, with relatively high water flux, moderate BSA rejection and outstandingly low hemolysis ratio, the SFEG-21 membranes exhibit superior hemodialysis performances including hemocompatibility compared with other literature works and also commercial hemodialysis membranes. For example, compared to an extensively used commercial hemodialysis membrane (F60S, Fresenius), our SFEG-21 membrane exhibits nearly doubled flux while the rejection is similar. Also importantly, the hemolysis of the SFEG-21 membrane is much lower than the commercial one (0.48% vs. 1.6%). This is mostly because of the PEGylated surfaces and pore walls of the membranes. Besides, we note that the SFEG-21 membranes were fabricated by one-step NIPS process, without using any additives or post-treatments, which can also promote their potential applications in hemodialysis.
label: n

paragraph: The dialysis performances were tested with a solution of urea, lysozyme and BSA as the simulating blood, and PBS solution was employed as the simulating dialysate. The solute clearance rate of urea, lysozyme and BSA were shown in Table 1. It was found that the SFEG-21 membranes showed good clearance to small molecules (urea) at 69.9 +- 5.1 mL/min and to medium molecules (lysozyme) at 46.4 +- 2.2 mL/min after dialysis tests for 6 h, which is close to that of the chemical modified PLA membrane (the urea clearance is over 70 mL/min and the lysozyme clearance is 40 mL/min) [7]. The good clearance of SFEG-21 is owing to their large pore size, excellent hydrophilic and interconnected membrane structure. It is worth noting that small and medium molecular toxins are removed while the beneficial large molecular proteins should be retained in dialysis [42]. The loss of BSA during the 6 h dialysis simulation is used to characterize the loss of beneficial proteins [43]. According to the experimental results, the loss of BSA of SFEG-21 membranes is 8.7 +- 0.6 mL/min. BSA molecules is described as a prolate ellipsoid with a molecular weight of about 66 kDa. The dimensions of BSA have been given as 14.1 nm for the major axis and 4.2 nm for the minor axis. The MWCO of SFEG-21 membrane is around 43 kDa, and the pore size of SFEG-21 is determined to be 6.2 nm, which is smaller than the major axis of BSA. Therefore, the membrane can retain most of the BSA in the dialysis simulation process.
label: n

paragraph: As mentioned above, the possible leaching-out of additives can deteriorate membrane performances and even cause serious safety issues. Thus, the stability of additives is one of the most important properties of hemodialysis membranes. We characterized the surface PEG contents of the SFEG-21 membranes before and after a period of storage in water, to study the stability of PEG components. PSF/PEG blend membranes were chosen as the control group. For better comparison, the addition of PEG to PSF was 21 wt%, and the concentration of the casting solutions was fixed at 21 wt%. To avoid the possible influence of other contaminants during XPS analysis, the membranes were stored in DI water.
label: n

paragraph: Specifically, the stability of the membranes was determined by characterizing the change of oxygen (O 1s) on the membrane surface before and after immersing in DI water for a certain time. O 1s was probed within the scope of 525.08-545.08 eV by narrow scan. The peak at the binding energy of 533.1 eV (Ph-O-Ph) and 531.6 eV (SO) was assigned to O 1s in PSF chains, and the peak at 532.3 eV (C-O-C) was derived from the O 1s of PEG chains [44]. Therefore, the ratio of the area of C-O-C peak to the area of O 1s peak (areaC-O-C) can indicate whether the PEG components are lost during use process. As shown in Fig. 7a, the areaC-O-C of SFEG-21 before and after immersion for three months did not change noticeably because of the covalent bonds between PEG chains and PSF chains. This result indicated the excellent stability of PEG in the SFEG-21 membranes. For PSF/PEG-21 membrane (Fig. 7b), although PEG was partially dissolved in NIPS process, it tended to accumulate on the surface of membrane due to the good hydrophilicity of PEG. Therefore, the areaC-O-C of PSF/PEG-21 before storage is comparable to that of SFEG-21 membranes. However, after three months of immersion, the areaC-O-C of PSF/PEG-21 decreased significantly, from 37.7% to 30.1%. This means that PEG of the blend membranes is easy to be washed out in operating process. By comparison, it can be found that the use of block copolymers as material can basically solve the problem of leaching-out in the process of operation and thus avoid the complications of patients.
label: n

paragraph: The fabrication of hemocompatible and biocompatible PSF-based hemodialysis membranes by one-step NIPS of a block copolymer, PSF-b-PEG, was introduced in this work. Copolymerization of PEG chains into PSF enhanced the membrane hydrophilicity and resulted in better performances, including higher permeability, lower BSA adsorption, less platelet adhesion, extended PRT, and lower HR compared to PSF membranes. The PSF-b-PEG hemodialysis membranes also had high urea and lysozyme clearance as well as low BSA clearance, which promises the removal of toxins and retention of beneficial proteins. Meanwhile, the PSF-b-PEG membranes showed excellent stability in water environment. This simple and effective method to prepare high-performance hemodialysis membranes possesses broad prospects in CKD treatments.
label: n

paragraph: Dinglei Zhong: Investigation, Data curation, Writing - original draft. Zhaogen Wang: Validation, Writing - review & editing. Jiemei Zhou: Methodology, Writing - review & editing. Yong Wang: Conceptualization, Supervision.

paragraph: The following is the Supplementary data to this article:Multimedia component 1Multimedia component 1
