label: n

paragraph: Data will be made available on request.
label: n

paragraph: Membrane separation technology is widely used in separation [1,2], concentration [3,4] and purification [5,6] process, possessing the advantages of high rejection coefficient, low energy consumption, convenient operation compared to the traditional technology. Polymeric membranes have been produced in a large scale up to a million square meters per year relying on a nonsolvent induced phase inversion (NIPS) strategy [7-12], which can be further divided into the liquid induced phase separation (LIPS) and vapor induced phase separation (VIPS) according to the phase state of the nonsolvent. During the phase inversion process, a homogenous polymer solution is transformed into the solid-state membrane, which is induced by the exchange between the solvent and nonsolvent. Thermodynamics of casting solution and kinetics in phase separation process are two key factors that determine the final morphologies, structures and performances of polymeric membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Thermodynamics is related to the phase equilibrium among the components of the casting solution, which can be well described by a thermodynamics phase diagram based on the Flory-Huggins theory [13-16]. Iwao Teraoka [17] gets the binodal curve and spinodal curve through theoretical calculation. Consequently, the thermodynamics phase diagram is divided into stable, metastable and unstable regions by two curves, which therefore determines the morphological evolution [18]. We can get cellular-like or nodulous structure via nucleation and growth (NG) mechanism through binodal curve separation and bicontinuous structure via the spinodal decomposition (SD) mechanism. The rapid diffusion or pouring of nonsolvent into the casting solution usually causes high porosity. Generally, membranes with finger-like structure will be produced via instantaneous demixing while a sponge-like structure will be obtained via delayed demixing [16,19,20]. The fast LIPS often results in an asymmetric structure with dense skin layer and finger-like sublayer [15,21,22], while the VIPS process can slow down the diffusion of gas/liquid, leading to a better control of morphology [23]. A combination of VIPS and LIPS enables a unique morphology control and relative quick membrane forming process [10,24-26].
label: n

paragraph: Polyphenylsulfone (PPSU) is a poly (aryl sulfone) polymer with long-term thermal stability (the glass transition temperature, 220 degC the degradation temperature, 503 degC), high mechanical strength, stiffness and high resistance to organic solvent, alkali [20] compared to other sulfone polymers [13,27]. It was found that PPSU nanofiltration membranes were resistant to ethyl acetate, n-hexane, diethyl ether, iso-propanol [15]. Shi et al. [28] introduced the sulfonated polyetheretherketone into PPSU vanadium flow batteries and got an ultrahigh chemical stable membrane. However, most of PPSU microfiltration or ultrafiltration membranes showed a relatively low permeability due to its hydrophobic nature of rigid biphenyl moiety and insufficient control of micro-structures [10,13,20,25,27,29-32]. Besides, the low solubility of PPSU in the commonly used polar aprotic solvents such as N-mwthylpyrrolidone (NMP) and DMAc limits the massive adding of pore forming agent such as PVP and polyethylene glycol (PEG) [13,27]. Sulfonated polysulfone (SPSf) are also widely used in the casting solution to control the membrane morphology. For example, Li et al. [33] investigated the effect of SPSf on the compatibility and morphology of polyethersulfone based membranes. Results revealed that membranes with sponge-like structure were successfully prepared and showed excellent water permeability and good antifouling ability. At the same time, Hu et al. [16] found that pregelation of SPSf and water was a good way to tailor the structure of membrane and a small amount of SPSf had a great effect of membrane. Authors also found that the synergy of SPSf and H2O during the membrane formation process could lead to the formation of surface pores and the increase of membrane hydrophilicity. In addition, nonsolvent additives have a more significant effect on membrane morphology because it can lead to the gelation of casting solution which exhibits three-dimensional structure, leading to a delayed demixing. Lin et al. [34] investigated the effect of H2O as a nonsolvent additive on the structure of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) membrane. It was found that macrovoids were completely suppressed with the presence of water. The reason on macrovoids suppression was strongly related to the formation of PMMA gelation induced by water. Hence, due to the significant positive influence of SPSf and water on membranes, they were adopted in this work.
label: n

paragraph: The purpose of manipulating membrane structures is to make them better be used to solve real problems and particulate matter (PM) pollution in water and oil-containing wastewater are two of them.
label: n

paragraph: Particulate matter pollution in water detrimentally affects living quality of people, posing a serious health threat to the public. Researches showed that particle size below 2.5 mm can penetrate human bronchi and lungs [35]. It is still a great challenge to remove PM in water. Electrospun polymer membranes and inorganic membranes were found to be applied into the treatment PM in water. For example, Wang et al. [36] prepared a highly porous electrospun polyacrylonitrile for the treatment of nano plastics in water. It was found that the membrane had a great rejection of 0.1 mm polystyrene (PS) at a low pressure (0.6 psi). Gui et al. [37] prepared several inorganic membranes by incorporating SiO2/ZrO2/Y2O3/MgO/ZnO nanoparticles into Ti-48Al-6Nb porous alloy and all membranes showed great performance in PM treatment.
label: n

paragraph: Further, oil-containing wastewater treatment is still a challenge in the world. In all technologies which were used to treat oily water, membrane technology had many advantages such as low operating costs and small environmental footprints [38]. For example, Yang et al. [39] prepared a membrane by co-depositing of mussel-inspired polydopamine (PDA) and polyethyleneimine (PEI) on a polypropylene microfiltration membrane. As a result, PDA/PEI coating endowed the membranes with ultra-high water permeability reaching 100 L/(m2h) under gravity with a rejection coefficient of 98% in the separation of dichloroethane.
label: n

paragraph: The objective of this work is to prepare bicontinuous PPSU microfiltration membranes via V-LIPS process and explore the morphology evolution mechanism. Meanwhile, the physiochemical properties and the application for nanoparticles and oil/water separation were also investigated.
label: n

paragraph: PPSU (P875330, Mw = 54,634 g/mol), n-hexane were purchased from Macklin (China) and SPSf (25% sulfonation degree) was supplied by Shandong Jinlan special polymer Co., Ltd. (China). PVP K30 and isooctane were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). DMAc, nano-silica, decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5, water solubility is 17 mg/L [40]) and bovine serum albumin (BSA) were all purchased from Aladdin (China). Deionized water was used as nonsolvent additive and coagulation bath.
label: y

paragraph: A casting solution with the composition near the binodal curve was more likely to form a membrane with bicontinuous structure because it had more chance to enter the unstable region rapidly or directly [18]. Thus, a precritical casting solution was prepared in this work. Meanwhile, according to the work by Li et al. [33], SPSf had a great compatibility with polyethersulfone (PESU) at the ratio of 16:84. In consideration of PPSU and PESU both belong to sulfone polymers, the same ratio was adopted in this work. At the same time, a low concentration of polymer would be good for the formation of a membrane with a high permeability so 15 wt% would be a good choice for this work. The steps for preparation of such a precritical casting solution were as followed:
label: y

paragraph: First, a certain amount of DMAc was added into the flask, and then different weight percentage of water staring from 0% and then increasing by 0.5% at a time was dropped into DMAc. Afterwards, PPSU (12.6 wt%), SPSf (2.4 wt%) and 20 g PVP (20 wt%, calculated by extra method) were dissolved in DMAc (decreasing from 85 wt% by 0.5 wt% a time) and mixed thoroughly under constant stirring for enough time until a homogeneous solution was formed if possible. The water weight percentage of the casting solution which cannot form homogeneous solution was recorded. Finally, the casting solution prior to the cloudy one was defined as precritical casting solution. To further investigate the properties of the above-mentioned polymer solution, the viscosity and the light transmittance were obtained by a rotational rheometer (Physica MCR-301, Austria) and UV/VIS/NIR Spectrophotometer (Lambda 950, USA).
label: y

paragraph: The formation conditions of membranes are presented in Table 1. PPSU and SPSf were dried in vacuum oven at 80 degC for 24h before being used. The polymers and additives were dissolved in DMAc under constant stirring at 70 degC until a homogeneous solution was formed. The solution was allowed to settle and cool to room temperature followed by degassing. The solution then was casted onto a glass plate by hands using a casting knife (Biuged BD201, China) with a gap height of 200 mm and immediately transferred to a programmable humidity and temperature tester (BPS-50CL, China) with the condition of 25 degC and 100% relative humidity (RH) for a period of time (from 0 to 30 s). Both air humidity and exposure time can influence the water adsorption into the membrane. And the adsorbed water in the pristine film from the air essentially influenced the porous structure evolution. Herein we varied the exposure time in 100% humidity to better control the water intrusion into the membrane. After that, the glass plate was immediately taken out and immersed into water coagulation bath maintained at 25 degC until the membrane was peeled off from the glass plate. The resulted membranes were transferred into a fresh deionized water bath at room temperature for 24h, and dried in air before testing and analysis.
label: y

paragraph: The surface and cross-sectional morphology of membranes were studied by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Hitachi S4800, Japan). Before measuring, membranes were air dried and fractured in liquid nitrogen followed by coating with platinum.
label: n

paragraph: The surface topography of the membranes was investigated by atomic force microscope (AFM, Bruker Dimension Icon, USA). Area of 50 mmkh50mm of each membrane was scanned with a scanning rate of 0.498 Hz.
label: n

paragraph: The dynamic contact angle of membranes was measured by an optical contact angle meter (OCA25, Germany). Membranes were cut into appropriate size and mounted onto the glass slide. A drop of deionized water about 3 mL was dropped on the surface of dry membranes. Three random points of each sample were measured to minimize the error.
label: n

paragraph: Measurement of maximum and mean pore diameters were conducted by "bubble pressure" method [41] using a membrane pore size analyzer (BSD-PB, China). At the same time, a software called Nano Measurer was used to measure pore size of the upper part, middle part and lower part of 'hour glass' structure.
label: n

paragraph: The porosity of membranes was measured by dry-wet method. Firstly, membranes with size of 2 cm x 2 cm were maintained in deionized water and then they were taken out for wet weight measurement after mopping water on surfaces. Secondly, membranes were put into a vacuum oven with controlled temperature of 60 degC for 24 h and then they were taken out for dry weight measurement. The porosity of membranes was calculated by equation (1):(1)Porosity=Ww-WdrwAd100%where Ww is the wet weight, Wd is the dry weight, rw is the density of pure water (g/cm3), A is the membrane surface area (cm2) and d is the thickness of wet membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Micro-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) (Cary 660, USA) was used to investigate chemical functional groups on the surface of membranes. The spectra were collected at the wavenumber from 400 cm-1 to 4000 cm-1 with spectral resolution of 2 cm-1.
label: n

paragraph: The degradation temperature of membranes was measured to investigate the thermal stability of membranes by a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA/DSC1, China) at a heating rate of 10 degC*min-1 under nitrogen atmosphere.
label: n

paragraph: To investigate the mechanical properties of membranes, tensile strength and elongation at break were measured by a universal testing machine (Instron 5567, China). Membranes were cut into strips with width of 10 mm and enough length. Thickness was measured by a digital micrometer (CHY-CA, China). The stretching rate was set at 10 mm/min. Three different parts of membranes were tested and then average values were obtained.
label: n

paragraph: According to H. Caquineau et al. [42], the quality of pristine membrane could be measured. The casting solution was cast on a glass plate one after another with a thickness of 200 mm and one was immediately transferred to an electronic balance (BSA224S, Sartorius) placed in the programmable humidity and temperature tester where temperature (25 degC) and humidity (100%) were well controlled, while another one was put in the room atmosphere (25 degC and 60% RH). The mass variation of the membrane during VIPS was obtained by readings from the electronic balance. The viscous solution was casted to a rectangle film with a certain area (10 cm x 10 cm) to assure the comparability of different membranes.
label: n

paragraph: Pure water flux of membranes was measured by a self-made cross-flow filtration system with an effective area of 6.16 cm2. The filtration operation was carried out with deionized water at a pressure of 0.2 bar for 1h. The pure water flux Jw can be calculated by equation (2):(2)Jw=VAxTwhere V is the volume permeated water in 1 h (L), A is the efficient membrane area (m2) and T is the permeation time (h).
label: n

paragraph: The antifouling property of membrane was investigated by 1 g/L BSA normal saline solution. There were two BSA filtration stages and three pure water filtration stages and each fouling stage was 30 min. Between the interval of pure water stage and BSA filtration stage, 20-min pure water rinse was applied to clean the fouled membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The membrane M3 was used to investigate the rejection coefficient of SiO2 nanoparticles simulated polluted water and surfactant-stabilized oil in water emulsions.
label: n

paragraph: A certain amount of SiO2 nanoparticles was dispersed in deionized water to form simulated nanoparticle polluted solution (100 ppm) under ultrasonic-assistant stirring for 6 h.
label: n

paragraph: M3 was chosen as a sample for the filtration using a self-made cross flow device under the pressure 0.2 bar for 12 h in a mode of concentration of feed solution. Dynamic light scattering (DLS, Zetasizer Nano ZS, UK) was employed to detect the size distribution of SiO2 nano-solution. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, NexION 300X, USA) was applied to analyze the concentration of SiO2 nanoparticles in the permeate solution. Meanwhile, the recovery of filtration flux of SiO2 filtration experiment was also conducted. The experiment was conducted for 3 cycles and each cycle was 4 h. During each cycle, the membrane was simply rinsed by water to demolish the participated SiO2 nanoparticles on the surface of membrane.
label: n

paragraph: Furthermore, to investigate the water-in-oil emulsion separation ability of membrane, n-hexane, isooctane and D5 water-in-oil emulsions (10,000 ppm) were made by adding them respectively into deionized water with continuous mechanical stirring for 12 h 0.1 g L-1 Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (SLS) was used as surfactant. M3 was chosen as a sample for the filtration using a self-made cross flow device under the pressure of 0.2 bar. The experiment was conducted in 5 cycles and each cycle was 5 min. The oil concentration of permeate solution was calculated by the carbon concentration which was detected by the total organic carbon analyzer (MultiNC2100, Germany).
label: n

paragraph: The rejection coefficient of SiO2 nanoparticles and oil-in-water emulsions were calculated by equation (3):(3)Rx=Cx0-Cx1Cx0x100%where x could be n or e for SiO2 nanoparticles or oil-in-water emulsions respectively. Cx0 and Cx1 are concentrations in feed and permeate solution.
label: n

paragraph: The flux of M3 for SiO2 nanoparticles and oil-in-water emulsions under the pressure of 0.2 bar were also studied and they were calculated by the following equation (4):(4)Px=VxSx*Dtxwhere x could be n or e for SiO2 nanoparticles and oil-in-water emulsions respectively. Vx is the volume of permeate solution, Sx is the effective area of membrane, Dtx is the operation time.
label: n

paragraph: The camera photos, viscosity and light transmittance of the polymer solutions with different weight percentages of water were shown in Fig. S1 and Fig. 1. It could be seen from Fig. S1 that the polymer solution with 3 wt% of water was opaque, indicating the phase separation of such polymer solution. Furthermore, the viscosity and light transmittance were detected. Results obtained from Fig. 1b showed that the viscosity under shear rate of 5 rs-1 decreased from 2994 +- 4 mPa s (no water adding) for to 2607 +- 1 mPa s (1.0% water adding), following by a continuous increase of viscosity from 2854 +- 5.5 mPa s, 2903 +- 7.5 mPa s to 2945 +- 3.5 mPa s, respectively. There was a leap of viscosity (e.g., 3762 +- 31.8 mPa s) when the water weight percentage is 3.0%. It was interesting that the polymer solution without the addition of water had the highest viscosity compared to others (except 3.0 wt%), which indicated that PPSU and SPSf had better compatibility when no water was added. A relatively small amount of water would interact with -SO3- of SPSf or -CO of PVP through hydrogen bonding to disentangle the macromolecular chains between SPSf and PPSU, which therefore caused a decreased viscosity. When more water was added into the solution, more serious macromolecular chain aggregation and entanglement occurred to enhance the viscosity, and a leap of viscosity indicated the phase separation of the mixed polymers.
label: n

paragraph: The similar solution behavior can be observed from Fig. 1b. The light transmittance at wave length of 800 nm of polymer solution without water (72.3%) was about 12.6 times higher than that of polymer solution with 2.5 wt% (5.74%) while it soared to 499 times
label: n

paragraph: Higher than that of 3.0 wt% (0.145%), which also indicated the occurrence of phase separation in the polymer solution with 3.0% water. Meanwhile, according various literatures [16,18,22], there would be occurrence of precipitation in casting solution if phase separation occurred. However, it could be seen from Fig. S1 that no precipitation was observed for polymer solution with 2.5 wt% water. Moreover, the polymer solution with 2.5 wt% water owned a relatively high viscosity and low light transmittance, indicating the composition near the binodal curve. Thus, the solution with 2.5% water was chosen as the precritical casting solution for the following membrane preparation.
label: n

paragraph: Mass variations of nascent pristine membrane during VIPS process were presented in Fig. 2. It could be seen from Fig. 2a that the mass of nascent pristine membrane kept increasing in the first hour under the condition of 100% RH. Detailed figure showed that vapor was rapidly absorbed and diffused into the membrane in the first 30 s, e.g., the membrane mass increased by 0.52g in 3000s, in comparison, the vapor adsorption was much slower in room atmosphere(60%RH), e.g., the pristine membrane mass only increased to a mere 0.22g in 3000s in Fig. 2b, and even after that, the mass increment was largely slowed down. Both water intake from the humid atmosphere and solvent evaporation from the membrane mutually influenced the mass variation of membrane. Even in the first 30s, the rapid mass increase indicated a certain amount of water diffusion into the polymer solution, which induced the phase separation in the membrane during VIPS.
label: n

paragraph: The SEM photographs of membrane M0 were presented in Fig. 3. It could be seen that M0 fabricated with NIPS process possessed a typical asymmetric structure with finger-like and macrovoids combined sublayer and dense skin layer. The top surface was smooth and the bottom surface had large pores. A fast diffusion of solvent into the coagulation bath would lead to the rapid aggregation of polymer in the interface so that the dense skin layer was formed. The dense skin layer would hinder the exchange of solvent and nonsolvent from the top surface, then the solvent inside the membranes would be absorbed by the polymer poor phase to form macrovoids. Large pores on the bottom surface were unclosed faces of macrovoids. The finger-like structure could be attributed to the coarsening and coalescence caused by unequal tension between the polymer poor phase and rich phase [33].
label: n

paragraph: It could be observed from Figs. 3 and 4 that membranes M1~M6 displayed a sponge-like cross section with a 'hour-glass' pore distribution from top to bottom, where the large pores were near the top surface and the minimum pore region lied in the cross-section several microns below the top surface, then the pore size increased towards the bottom surface. In order to better show the 'hour glass' distribution of pores in the cross section of membranes, clearer and larger SEM photos were shown in Fig. S2. It could be seen from Fig. S2 (M0~M6) that the minimum pore sizes lied in the region which was away from the top surface for a certain distance and pore sizes increased towards the top surface and bottom surface from the minimum pore sizes region. For better showing the lower part of 'hour glass' structure, a SEM photo of M6 (M6L) was also shown in Fig. S2. It can be seen from the SEM picture (M6L) that pore sizes near the bottom are larger than those near top. Such a change can also be explained theoretically. During the phase separation process, water enter the forming membrane from the top to the bottom. Thus, polymer poor phase near the bottom has more time to grow-the closer to the bottom, more time for polymer poor phase to grow. Thus, pore sizes increase towards the bottom. It was showed in Fig. 4a that the depth of the upper part of 'hour-glass' structure increased in an approximately linear way. The 'hour-glass' structure depths for M1~M6 are 8.1 mm, 15.8 mm, 20.0 mm, 25.8 mm, 29.4 mm and 36.5 mm while the whole cross section was about 150 mm. Meanwhile, average diameters of the upper (I), middle (II) and lower part (III) were shown in Fig. 4c. It could be found that upper part owned the largest pore size (e.g., M3: 640 nm) and middle part had the smallest pore size (e.g., M3: 210 nm), while the lower part had moderate diameters (e.g., M3: 370 nm). At the same time, diameters of all three parts increased from M1 to M6 as shown in Fig. 4c. The specific values were shown in Table S1. Interestingly, it could be observed from Fig. 5a that the inside of upper part skeleton of 'hour-glass' structure was cellular-like while the lower part is solid (Fig. 5b).
label: n

paragraph: Once the PPSU membranes were placed in the VIPS chamber, large number of nuclei were formed on the top surface due to the contact condensed water in humid atmosphere. These water nuclei would join together to form small water droplets as an increase of exposure time in VIPS. Thereafter, small droplets were free enough joining each other to form larger ones. As the process proceeded, water would cover the whole membrane surface, and a liquid layer would form finally [43]. During this process, the water absorbed on the top surface would diffuse into the bulk of the membrane. A precritical casting solution was used in the fabrication of membranes indicating the composition of casting solution was near the binodal curve. For some parts of the upper part of the 'hour-glass' structure, as water penetrated into the bulk, the composition near top surface passed the binodal curve and phase separation occurred via a nucleation and growth mechanism so that cellular-like structure was formed in these parts. With increasing the residence time in vapor, more water penetrated into the membranes, the composition entered unstable region directly through the critical point or passed a narrower metastable region very quickly so that bicontinuous structure was formed via a SD mechanism or became much closer to the spinodal curve. Afterwards, the polymeric membrane was immersed into the coagulation bath and had contact with water. Consequently, the composition entered into the unstable region and bicontinuous structure was formed. The parts with cellular-like structure were wrapped by the bicontinuous structure as shown in Fig. 5, polymer rich phase was squeezed so that the cellular-like structure inside the skeleton was a unique conical shape. Interestingly, the pore sizes decreased from the top surface to lower position in the upper part. DMAc tended to segregate to the membrane surface and caused a solvent gradient and viscosity gradient [42]. Before the solidification of membranes, the formed bicontinuous structure would coarsen and coalesce in order to reduce the free energy between the polymer rich phase and poor phase. As a result, it was easier for a lower viscosity region to form larger pore size than that was high. Consequently, a gradient pore distribution was formed. With the increase of exposure time, the depth of the upper part of 'hour-glass' structure increased from M1 to M6. This phenomenon could be attributed to the vapor penetration into pristine membrane during the VIPS process. It could be observed from Fig. 2a that in early 30s, mass variation of a pristine membrane increased approximately in a linear way, indicating the water intrusion into the viscous film. Linearly increased water adsorption induced linear evolution of porous structure in the upper part of the membrane, while it influenced less on the middle part of the membrane due to restricted diffusion in the viscous solution. Therefore, the depth of the upper part of 'hour-glass' structure increased from M1 to M6.
label: n

paragraph: For the lower part of 'hour-glass' structure, a total bicontinuous gradient morphology was obtained for M1~M6 compared to M0 with finger-like structure in the middle and macrovoids in the bottom of cross section. Simultaneously, it was solid inside the skeleton. Water intake from VIPS process could account for this. During the VIPS process, a certain amount of water was absorbed into the lower part of 'hour-glass' structure, making the composition closer to the binodal curve. The composition, meanwhile, quickly entered the unstable region after immersing into the coagulation bath so that phase separation was conducted via SD mechanism. Consequently, a bicontinuous structure with solid skeleton was formed.
label: n

paragraph: From another point of view, the existence of nonsolvent H2O in the casting solution induced gelation due to the hydrogen bonding formed between H2O and -SO3- of sulfonated polysulfone [16]. The hydrogen bonding network slowed down the transfer and diffusion between the solvent and nonsolvent during the phase separation, which was in favor of the formation of bicontinuous structure. For M0, the network is not strong enough to hinder the nucleation and growth of the polymer poor phase so finger-like structure and macrovoids were found in the cross section. With an increase of time in VIPS, more water penetrated into the membrane so a stronger three-dimensional network was obtained, leading to the formation of bicontinuous structure.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. 3 also depicted the top surface structure of membranes. There were variable-sized pores on the surface of membranes and it seemed that the mean pore size increased while quantity of pores decreased when the exposure time in VIPS increased from 5s to 30s. The reason was the coarsening and coalescence of polymer rich phase. As a result, smaller pores coalesced into bigger ones along with lesser pores on the top surface. The bottom structure was also shown in Fig. 3. There were pores which are smaller than top surface and more evenly distributed.
label: n

paragraph: To further explain the mechanism of such a structure, a membrane fabricated only using VIPS process, and the cast membrane was put into the VIPS chamber with 25 degC and 100% RH for 10 min and then the membrane was taken out in air until the phase separation was completed. The result was shown in Fig. 6. It could be seen that the membrane had less-connected structure in the cross and cellular-like structure was inside the skeleton. It also had a smooth top surface and bottom surface. Obvious coarsening and coalescence behaviors could be found in the cross section and a smooth
label: n

paragraph: Top and bottom surface.
label: n

paragraph: AFM photographs of top surface were presented in Fig. 7. It could be seen from the photographs and that VIPS had a considerable impact on roughness of membranes, while the increase of time in VIPS rarely influenced membranes' roughness. M0 possessed the lowest roughness because the fast diffusion between solvent and nonsolvent during the phase separation which entailed a relatively smooth skin layer. Meanwhile, the adoption of VIPS led to the formation of pores on the surface of membranes. These variable-sized pores increased the roughness of membranes.
label: n

paragraph: The physical and chemical properties of the membrane were shown in Fig. 8. The chemical composition of the prepared membranes was investigated by FTIR as shown in Fig. 8a and Fig. S3a. All membranes showed typical spectra of PPSU polymer. The peak at about 1651 cm-1 was assigned to CO and the peaks at 1293 cm-1 and 1321 cm-1 were assigned to OSO. The peak around 1149 cm-1 was ascribed to C-S which indicated the existence of SPSf. Specially, the intensity of CO bond stretch of M0 was obviously stronger than other membranes which indicated that more PVP was retained in M0. This phenomenon also explains the peak at about 3400 cm-1. During the phase separation process, less PVP was washed out of the membrane due to the dense skin layer of M0 so that they aggregated on the membrane surface.
label: n

paragraph: Fig. S3b and Fig. 8b showed the dynamic contact angle of membranes. For membranes M0~M6, the initial contact angle was less than 90deg. It took about 10deg minutes for the contact angle of M0 decreased from 75deg to 10deg, while membranes M1~M6 showed instantaneous wetting behavior in about 2s. The addition of PVP and SPSf significantly enhanced the hydrophilicity. During the membrane forming process, PVP molecules and -SO3- chains of SPSf moved to the surface of membranes due to strong affinity among PVP, -SO3- chains and H2O to reduce the interfacial free energy correlating with FTIR results.
label: n

paragraph: The fabricated membranes with different exposure time in VIPS process were evaluated for their performance in terms of pure water flux and the results were shown in Fig. 8c. It could be seen that pure water flux increased with the residence time in vapor. For example, the pure water flux of M0 was found to be 72.1 +- 3.0 L/(m2h), and then increased to 594.9 +- 20.3 L/(m2h) for M1 followed by an increase to 941.1 +- 32.4 L/(m2*h), 1340.9 +- 12.5 L/(m2*h), 1715.9 +- 24.9 L/(m2*h), 2167.7 +- 43.1 L/(m2*h), 3045.7 +- 42.7 L/(m2*h) for M2, M3, M4, M5 and M6 respectively. The initial increase of pure water flux from M0 to M1 was attributed to the improvement of membrane hydrophilicity, the increase of porosity and the disappearance of the skin layer. For membranes with exposure in humid air, pure water flux increased with the increase of exposure time in VIPS due to the increment of mean pore size.
label: n

paragraph: The porosity, maximum and mean pore diameters of membranes were depicted in Fig. 8d. For M1~M6, it could be seen that pore size increased along with the increase of exposure time in VIPS. Obviously, maximum pore diameters appeared in the region near the top surface. As described in section 3.3, with an increase of time in VIPS, the polymer concentration near the top surface decreased, which made for an easier coarsening and coalescence behavior for bicontinuous structure. As a result, M6 possessed the largest pore diameters. Meanwhile, polymer poor phase tended to grow more easily when exposure time in VIPS was longer, which could be attributed to an increased mean pore diameter from M1 to M6. For M0, the mean pore diameter and maximum pore diameter was larger than that of M1 and M2 which was due to the polymer poor phase growth during the phase separation. The porosity of membranes was 88.6 +- 0.72%, 81.9 +- 1.58%, 84.5 +- 0.67%, 85.7 +- 1.60%, 85.2 +- 1.08%, 84.9 +- 1.1% and 86.2 +- 1.6%, respectively for M0~M6.
label: n

paragraph: At the same time, M3 possessed a good thermal stability with a degradation temperature at about 380 degC as shown in Fig. S3c.
label: n

paragraph: It can be seen from Fig. S3d that tensile strength of membranes increases from M0 to M6, with 0.77 +- 0.06 MPa, 1.48 +- 0.11 MPa, 1.77 +- 0.05 MPa, 2.08 +- 0.11 MPa, 2.45 +- 0.14 MPa, 2.81 +- 0.20 MPa and 3.42 +- 0.30 MPa, respectively. M0 has a macrovoids and finger-like combined cross section. Such a cross section often leads to a lower tensile strength compared with sponge-like structure so M0 has the lowest tensile strength (with elongation at break of 0.99% +- 0.19%). For M1~M6, the increase of tensile strength can be attributed to the coarsening and coalescence, which promoted a stronger skeleton.
label: n

paragraph: In order to investigate the filtration performance, M3 was chosen to test its antifouling ability, separation performance for SiO2 nanoparticles contaminated water and water-in-oil emulsions.
label: n

paragraph: In Fig. 9c, the filtration had been carried out for 12 h, and the concentration of SiO2 nanoparticles was measured by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES). It could be observed that the flux of M3 decreased from 512 L/(m2*h) to 185 L/(m2*h) with the increase of filtration time from 1h to 12h. Also evident is the fact that the rejection coefficient kept as high as 96.2% even after 12-h filtration, while that of the first hour was 99.0%. The pore size distribution of M3 and Dynamic light scattering (DLS) data of SiO2 nanoparticles as simulated pollutants and photography of solutions before and after filtration are exhibited in Fig. S5, Figs. 8a and 9b respectively. The obtained results revealed that the as-prepared SiO2 nanoparticles contaminated water before and after filtration had an average particle size of approximately 324.7 nm and 222.7 nm, while that of M3 was about 229 nm. Also evident was the fact that the contaminated water after filtration was much more transparent than the one before filtration. This was due to the excellent filtration performance of M3 which enabled the concentration of contaminated water decreased from 100 ppm to approximately 1 ppm after filtration.
label: n

paragraph: According to the results of DLS, the diameter of some SiO2 nanoparticles was below the minimum pore diameter of M3. As a result, some of these nanoparticles passed the membrane, which led to the rejection coefficient was 99.0% in the first hour. However, it was observed that the flux in the first hour was 512 L/(m2*h) which was much lower than that of pure water flux (1354 L/(m2*h)). SiO2 nanoparticles were stuck in the pores in the membrane. With the filtration proceeding, the rejection coefficient decreased slightly due to the concentration polarization. Meanwhile, flux recovery of M3 during the filtration of SiO2 was tested which was shown in Fig. S4 in which 1-4 h was the first cycle, 5-8 h was the second cycle and 9-12 h was the third cycle. It could be found that filtration flux of 5 h (471.9 L/(m2*h)) was about 93.0% of hour 1 (507.2 L/(m2*h)), while hour 9 (393.6 L/(m2*h)) was 77.6% of that of hour 1. It demonstrated more SiO2 nanoparticles penetrated deeply into the membrane and stuck in the tortuous pores, which were not readily cleaned by the simple rinsing. The comparison with other reported literatures on the performance of nanoparticles separation was shown in Table 2. It could be seen that electrospun membranes and inorganic membranes were reported before. Compared to these membranes, the performance of M3 needs to be further improved by some potential modification such as anti-fouling modification.
label: n

paragraph: At the same time, the antifouling property of the membrane M3 was investigated with pure water filtration and fouling with 1 g/L BSA normal saline solution, respectively. The whole process included three pure water stages and two fouling stages, which was shown in Fig. 9d. It could be seen that the initial flux of M3 remained at a stable state at about 1354.0 L/(m2h). After the first fouling stage, the flux of M3 decreased to 1115.0 L/(m2h), which signified that M3 suffered from fouling. However, the flux at fouling stage remained approximately 80% of the initial value, which could be attributed to the fast speed of the contact of water with membrane surface (Fig. 8b). After stage II, M3 was cleaned with deionized water for 20 min. Apparently, the flux of M3 after clean increased to 1225.5 L/(m2h) which was about 90.5% of the initial value signifying a good antifouling property. The experiment was carried out a second time to assure the phenomenon observed, the flux at stage V was 1156.6 L/(m2h) still reaching 85.4% of the initial value. The rejection rate of BSA in stage II and IV were 4.5% and 5.2%, indicting the sample is a micro-filtration rather than ultra-filtration membrane.
label: n

paragraph: The separation performance of M3 for oil in water emulsions, which were n-hexane/water, isooctane/water and decamylcyclopentasiloxane/water emulsions, was also investigated. The separation performance was evaluated by a self-made cross-flow device. The results in Fig. 10 showed that membrane M3 could efficiently separate the oil droplets with high water permeation and oil rejection. The water permeation flux in
label: n

paragraph: The first cycle was 604.9 +- 11.7 L/(m2h), 535.5 +- 8.2 L/(m2h), 505.1 +- 14.7 L/(m2h) for n-hexane/water, isooctane/water and D5/water, respectively and remained at a high value of 508.4 +- 12.3 L/(m2h), 470.5 +- 8.2 L/(m2h) and 414.1 +- 20.7 L/(m2h) after 5-cycle separation, which indicated a good recyclability. A similar phenomenon was observed for the rejection coefficient, which was 99.5 +- 0.1%, 99.5 +- 0.1% and 98.3 +- 0.1% for n-hexane/water, isooctane/water and D5/water. After 5-cycle separation, the rejection coefficient was still in the vicinity of >99%, >99% and >98%, respectively.
label: n

paragraph: It should be noted that further hydrophilic modification on membranes may improve the anti-fouling performance of membranes. e.g., Hydrophilic oligo(ethylene)glycol methacrylate (OEGMA) [46] or tannic acid (TA) [47], was anchored on membrane surface to improve the membrane fouling to organic matters or oils. Meanwhile, M3 had good performance in oil-in- water separation in comparison of other polysulfone [48-50]or polyethersulfone [51-53] membranes which were also applied into oil-containing water treatment.
label: n

paragraph: PPSU/SPSf microfiltration membranes were successfully fabricated from PPSU/SPSf/H2O precritical casting solution using DMAc as solvent and PVP as a pore forming agent via V-LIPS process. The morphology and performance of PPSU based membranes were significantly affected by the exposure time in VIPS process. The fully bicontinuous structure membranes were obtained when the exposure time in VIPS exceeded 5s. Meanwhile, it was a unique 'hour glass' structure of cross section with cellular-like structure inside the skeleton of the upper part and a solid one inside that of the lower part. The performance was significantly improved by the VIPS process, such as high porosity and good wettability behavior. The pure water flux of membrane with exposure time of 30s in humid atmosphere reached 3045.7 +- 42.7 L/(m2h). Membranes also possessed good thermal stability and antifouling ability. Meanwhile, membranes showed good rejection coefficient and filtration flux in the treatment of nanoparticle contaminated water and oil-in-water emulsions, with 99% and 512 L/(m2h) for the former and 604.9 +- 11.7 L/(m2h) and 99.5 +- 0.1%, 535.5 +- 8.2 L/(m2h) and 99.5 +- 0.1% and 505.1 +- 14.7 L/(m2h) and 98.3 +- 0.1% for n-hexane/water, isooctane/water and D5/water, respectively. Our research shed lights on the fabrication of PPSU membranes with 'hour glass' structure for microfiltration via V-LIPS process. In the future, PPSU microfiltration membranes would be potential candidates in oily and nano-particle involved water treatment.
label: n
